author: Elizabeth Wright
title: Lacking in Depth
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2016
content: I feel as if this book is truly lacking what the other Harry Potter books had. It's not just the descriptions I miss, it's the complexities of the characters. I knew going into this that it's a play - not your typical Harry Potter book. Yet, I still feel as if it's missing the kind of depth that was carefully woven into the original books. For example, the scenes are very short. What could have been beautifully written in a novel format seems to be short changed into a clumpy collection of short sentences within just a few pages. The scenes are not long enough to really feel any connections to the characters. They feel choppy and rushed almost.  The main characters, Albus and Scorpius, have so much potential to blossom into beloved characters, but it's just not shown in this book. Considering this is what most Harry Potter enthusiasts have been waiting for, it just didn't feel up to par for me.

author: JFlorie
title: Not as good as I had hoped
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
content:
I am a self professed Harry Potter nerd so of course I had to order this book to read.
If you are unfamiliar with a play script you may have been disappointed in the flow. The brilliance of a script is that it allows the director to set the scene and stage when it is put on. I wasn't expecting the in depth detail and description of other Harry Potter books. However, the flow of the book (play) made it overtly obvious that JK Rowling did not write this. She had input but it lacked her special touch.
The story was good. It wasn't the best but it was decent enough for me. I did miss the descriptive writing and wish JK would redo this as a full novel and delve deeper into some of the characters and their relationships. This was a little predictable in the outcome. It was still enjoyable. It just lacked much of the Harry Potter magic we have come to know and love.

author: Casey
title: Glorified fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I have been a huge Harry Potter fan since I was a kid and I was super excited to finally get my hands on new content from the Harry Potter universe. To me, this was a huge disappointment. I'm familiar with scripts and I know they don't read the same way, but this felt like they didn't even try to make it believable. It was lazily written, character development from the other seven books was ignored, and I didn't find the plot believable at all. This books saving grace was the relationship between Scorpius and Albus, it was clear that that was well thought out and it actually felt like it could happen.

This script is basically glorified fanfiction and I wish I could obliviate the memory of reading it, not because I didn't like it but because it causes me to lose respect for the world as a whole. They reveal some things that have no place in the Harry Potter universe (SPOILER his daughter and her mother SPOILER) and because of that I have decided that I'm going to accept this new content as fanfiction instead of an addition to the universe.

author: Caitastrophe
title: I didn’t like THE CURSED CHILD
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content:
In any case, here’s my unpopular opinion for the month: I didn’t like THE CURSED CHILD.

I was tentatively excited when I heard about the play and then more so when I heard they were releasing the script. Now before you say that I didn’t like it because of the script format, let me just say that I’ve done stage acting in the past and still read Shakespeare for fun. Scripts do not kill my enjoyment of a story, at least not if that script is written well.

This one I would say was written ably, but not precisely enjoyably. It’s one of those “the grammar was excellent, but the story… eh?” moments for me.

I wanted to like this book, y’all; I really did. It just fell flat for me.

I think my big issue was the lack of wonder or hope that the original Harry Potter series held for me. Even during some of the darkest moments of the series, there was still as sense of fun and wonder from Harry discovering the wizarding world and comparing it with the hell that was his life with the Dursleys. This book didn’t feel like it had any of that wonder. Instead we had a rush through 3-4 years of Harry’s son being utterly miserable at Hogwarts followed by a plot driven by one of my least favorite plot tropes. I’m not mentioning what trope here just on the chance some of you are yet to read it – I hate spoilers as much as the next reader LOL. But rest assured, it’s a pretty common plot device, and it just felt tired here as opposed to a unique take on it.

Some have said it read like bad fanfiction, only without the happy ending for any onscreen explicit slash couples, and I have to admit, that’s not an inaccurate description of it.

I do know several people who enjoyed it, but I just was underwhelmed overall. I’ve still got tentative hopes for the FANTASTIC BEASTS AND WHERE TO FIND THEM film, but this play probably won’t be one I’ll spend my money on in the event that it makes it to US theaters.

author: Nichole

author: MD Resident
title: Meh. Mediocre. Okay.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
It was meh. Not necessarily outstanding, but not horrendously unbearable either. Mediocre.
If you look at it as "the much-awaited final installment to the critically acclaimed Harry Potter series," you're sure to be disappointed, because this book definitely did not live up to the hype. It was filled with gaping plot holes, much of it read like fan fiction, and the characters were just caricatures of themselves. Harry has been reduced from the shining, confident young man in the Deathly Hallows to a sniveling, self-pitying, insensitive middle-aged bozo we see in Cursed Child. It’s more torture than the Cruciatus Curse to read about him. Hermione is no better. Now the Minister for Magic (I loved that), she has lost all of her creativity and ingenuity that made her my absolute favorite character in the Harry Potter series. Ron was seriously excruciating. It seemed like he was only in the book for comic relief. While the HP series was interspersed with bits of humor from Ron, Jack Thorne seemed to think that is his only role in the story. It nearly broke my heart. And Albus- why, why, are you SUCH an unlikable character, Albus? I mean, I tried. I honestly tried to like him. But he was so self-pitying, so “Oh-my-god-feel-bad-for-me-I’m-Harry-Potter’s-son” that I wanted to slam him into the nearest brick wall. I mean, he couldn’t even see past his argument with Harry to be a decent friend to Scorpius!! Why, Albus, why?? And Rose
However, there were many things in the book worth the almost-20-dollars that it cost. Scorpius Malfoy was such an amazing character; he and Draco Malfoy were the stars of the story, in my opinion. Albus being sorted into Slytherin was an ingenious touch, though most of us saw it coming. And Draco was SO COOL!! He was hands-down the best character in the book. I’ve always liked Draco, but I really wanted him to become friends with the trio, and it happened!! I was beyond ecstatic. Though most people thought the Time-Turner concept was hackneyed and cringe-worthy, I found it to be somewhat intriguing. The fact that a simple Engorgement Charm could cause Voldemort’s reign to endure was fascinating to me. And that an Expelliarmus Charm could cause Ron and Hermione never to get married? Wonderful. But I groaned aloud when Draco MAGICALLY had another Time-Turner…. Like, seriously? That was such a plot-mover. And Delphi. Seriously, you couldn’t come up with anything better than Voldemort having a daughter?? Really?? The rumor part of it (where everyone thought that Draco was Voldy’s son)- that was cool, and I kind of wished he was so that the plot would be so much more interesting. But no. Delphi, this not-even-remotely-likeable girl, had to be the one who wanted to resurrect the Dark Lord again. I had so many questions at this part that it wasn’t even funny. But Act 4 made it all worth it. I teared up at the ending, and the story made sense logically, after they tied up some loose ends.
So all in all, it was okay. Meh. Definitely not what I expected, but a refreshing twist on the series all the same.

author: Trin
title: A fun, but flawed trip back into the Potter-verse
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content:
The most difficult thing about reading this is that the intended method of consumption is as an audience member in a theater. Performed well, I might give the production another star, but as a book it suffers significantly. As a screenplay it can come alive when dialog is active, but it is difficult to read any rapidly changing scenes as happens during the setup of the story. It also takes a bit of getting used to when emotion is conveyed via stage direction instead of prose.

Ultimately, the thing that bothered me most is the choice to change how an aspect of magic works, the element that the story is built entirely around. While a fun adventure was birthed from it, we end up with a story that doesn't feel as cleanly crafted or thought out as the previous books or movies.

If you can put aside these two detractors, the story offers a fun trip through nostalgia, a new entry in the joys of friendship, and some touching moments of the relationship between parents and their teenage children.

author: David Green
title: Exactly what it says on the tin -- with all that that implies
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
Reading this book awoke a philosophical question in me. Unfortunately, it wasn't based on the plot of the story itself. Rather, I found myself wondering, "Is it fair to rate down an item for being exactly what it says on the tin?"

Ultimately, I decided it was--because of how it was sold. While I enjoyed the story here, as a read it suffered for being precisely what it claimed to be--a rehearsal script. Advice that is given to many aspiring authors is "show, don't tell," but this as a script spent much of its effort telling the actors what to show. That's certainly appropriate for a script, but as a read it felt wanting. And there is the rub for most of the book. I think there really is a good story inside waiting to get out, but without being fleshed out by prose, by a deeper exploration of the characters' thoughts and actions, it doesn't really work overall. I think it probably makes a perfectly serviceable play, but as a read, not so much.

I'm not criticizing scripts per se--I've actually read a novel written in a script format that worked out MUCH better (MCA Hogarth's Spots the Space Marine: Defense of the Fiddler--a different genre but highly recommended)--but in this case, this isn't a novel written in a script format; it's a script sold as a novel. And THERE is the issue I have: This was being marketed like a novel, and it doesn't really stand alone in its own right as that.

I would much rather have had a novelization of the play, or else have this not marketed in hardback with all of the hype and hoopla that surrounded the other Harry Potter releases, but as a special edition paperback. As it is marketed and produced, it doesn't really feel like it matches what is delivered.

As far as the story goes, I have seen people write it off as (sometimes "bad") fan-fiction, and claim that the characters are inconsistent. I can certainly sympathize with those claims, and I understand where they come from, but I am willing to give it the benefit of the doubt and say that if this script were well-acted, it would alleviate at least some of those concerns. Personally, I enjoyed the tale. But again, the limitations of the format within the medium lend this book to exactly that sort of criticism.

At the end, I am not disappointed with my purchase, but I feel there are numerous ways in which this could have been made better, in the marketing, in the execution, and in the delivery.

author: Jessica G.
title: Am I reading bad fanfiction?
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2017
content:
I wanted to love this. I had been waiting for this. I was left disappointed.

Let me start by saying that I am a HUGE Harry Potter fan. I have read the books countless times. I think they are excellent books for children to read because of what they teach them. Yes, the fantasy is nice, but the core values of the books? The heart of the books are where they really shine. Harry Potter and the Cursed Child has taken what we loved about all of these characters and completely obliterated all of that. Harry Potter had many character flaws, but I don't believe for a second that he would have made his son feel unloved or separated him from his only friend. Family was the most important thing to him. Love and friendship were his whole thing.

Then, okay, I can see Hermione Granger being appalled at how poorly the ministry was run. I mean, children broke in multiple times! So, she becomes Minister! Don't you think she'd tighten up security?

The characters didn't seem like more grown up versions of their younger selves. They didn't seem anything like...anything I'd ever read. There seemed to be inconsistencies within the realm as well. It was just a bit of a confusing ride.

author: Book_Dragon
title: The good and the bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I love the story that she was trying to tell but I do not like the format in which she told it. I really hope that the next one is not like this but I have a feeling that it will be.

author: Alexis
title: Meh...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2017
content:
Good news, bad news. The good news is that by the time I finished this book I surprisingly did not regret reading it. There were many parts throughout reading it though where I wished I never picked the book up. Overall though, I don't consider my $8 purchase of the Kindle book a total waste, though I don't see myself going back to it again. The voices of these characters read like a fan fiction with few fleeting moments of capturing the real magic. The ending resolved everything well enough that you don't finish feeling totally robbed.

*spoilers ahead*
The characters voices were definitely off. There were things I feel JK would have never had characters say to eachother or do. Such as the poly juice potion kiss scene with hermoine. Also, snapes character was very chummy, which did not suit the way he was written for all 7 books! Once they concluded who Delphi was, the book got better for me and it seemed to have a purpose. And I also enjoyed the flash backs to the tri wizard tournament.
I know a play is going to lack the depth of a novel but I still feel like the first half of the plot fell short.
The story focused so much around Albus and Harry that other characters were sloppily thrown together. I doubt Hermoine and Ron would've raised such a snob and bully as Rose was. In fact, Hermoine and Ron's personalities seem to be so lost entirely in this that you wonder if they're actually still friends with harry beyond what they went through in the past. Also, where was James in all of this, or Lilly? James, much like Rose, mostly served to be a bully at the start of the book then fade into the background. Harry and Hermoine were written as very self serving type characters, while Ron was a trophy husband that occasionally served as comic relief. Draco actually seemed to be one the most interesting and likeable characters of this entire book.

author: Robert
title: Not a worthy successor to the first seven
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content: It has some interesting ideas but there's not much there. Maybe as a stage production it has some entertainment value. But it book form it's flat.

Professor Dumbeldore needed to be stronger and maybe show a better connection between he and Harry. I personally would have liked it better if it were a book where these characters could be developed better. In the beginning of the play there was too much jumping around and that's where  I feel the two boys friendship could have been developed better in their classes and house. Neville was mentioned as being a professor. Could have had the two boys learning in Neville's class.

I care that authors get paid. This was just short.

author: Maggy Fulton
title: Crazy Fan Fiction- Fun at Times
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
What a ride, this book, or script I guess isn't the next Harry Potter book every book store or sign you've seen is advertising it as. I was prepared for this, and also prepared for the fact it wasn't written by J.K. Rowling. But in the end, it kinda left me with the feeling of: "what?"

I love all the Harry Potter books, so very very much, but the bottom line is, this book didn't need to be released, it's meant to be experienced as a play if anything. I haven't seen it, but I hear it's apparently amazing, and hey, maybe it translates better, but overall, and I think many will agree- this feels like a CRAZY fan fiction.

This is for a couple reasons:
-It does so many crazy things, all in one book, that it kind of loses Harry Potter magic, and seems to rely all on shock value. Not only that, but things that also just don't seem believable for the universe. You suspend your disbelief for the first half, but by the end, I wasn't having any of it.

-Nothing new is introduced. What really adds to the fanfic feel, is that nothing new comes into play. There are no new creatures, no new wondrous location, this very much stays in the confines of what's already been laid out, and just seems to go over J.K. Rowling's original impressive world. Only she could introduce new elements into this story, and it's sorely missed here.

-The plot is decent at times, but only because of all the Harry Potter nostalgia it injects. There's nothing really new here, just a ton of fan theories come to realization. And they are the most BASIC of fan theories. The most basic crazy thing you could think of when you finished Deathly Hallows, is probably in this book, it just felt like there was no imagination.

-The plot also has a feel of giving no time for character. Every scene is characters saying: "it's time to go here" no real time for character moments. When they strike, they strike hard and well, particularly between Harry and his son.

-Kinda sappy as well. I'm not against the message of friendship and love, but this book gave me some seriously eye rolling moments.

BUT it's not all bad, I'm gonna go SPOILERS now, and this is the stuff I enjoyed:

GOOD:
-Albus: An interesting character, and while him being sorted into Slytherin was very much a "Ok, this is the thing they're going for moment" I enjoyed the character himself, not wanting to follow the family legacy.

-Harry Himself: I really did like Harry Potter in this book. Seeing the character, even in his forties, have flaws, and being a bad father and accepting of certain elements of his son he claims to be accepting of, was very well done.

-The Time Travel (to a point): The idea of Albus time travelling and saving Cedric is an idea I very much enjoyed, but the scenes where they actually travel back were too short for anything other than their objective to happen, and that isn't interesting.

-Scorpius and Draco: Scorpius is a fun sidekick to Albus, and I liked seeing him dealing with a family legacy, but in a different way. He added levity, even though it felt unrealistic due to his upbringing. I also really enjoyed hearing Draco's point of view on events. Seeing this character matured felt believable, and his story was tragic and relatable.

-Some Nice Scenes: Scenes like Snape finding out Harry named his son after him, and Harry watching his parents death and savior of him are dramatic scenes I've always wanted to see, and in the end, played out very nicely.

Now the not so good SPOILER stuff:

-Delphi: Like seriously, you're telling me Voldermort did Bellatrix? No, nope, not really

-Voldermort: I also found it kinda lazy the story felt the need to go back to Voldermort as a main threat. The whole point is his arc is over. Find a new threat. Wouldn't it have been a lot more interesting if Albus was the villain alone, or at least his inner demons were?

-Hermione: So Hermione has become exposition lady? Ok, I'm not cool with that.

-Lack of Characters: The cast felt very stilted, I didn't like how in every scene the same 6 characters kept popping up randomly. It just didn't feel like the WIZARDING WORLD, full of fun characters. I get it, it's a play, but it's HARRY POTTER!

-The Resistance: On top of lack of characters, it didn't feel realistic having a "resistance" just made up of Ron, Hermione and Snape. It was weird, the characters didn't act like themselves, just weirdness all around.

-The Dialogue: This dialogue was...odd.

SO in the end, Cursed Child has some great moments, but at the end of the day it's fan fiction, that being said, enjoyable fan fiction that I kept reading, so...

title: Love the story but very disappointed with the format
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: I'm somewhat ashamed to admit that I was totally confused and disappointed when I opened this book. I *knew* it was either based on a play or had a concurrent play produced with the same name and I *knew* it wasn't a JK Rowling solo authored work. But somehow I still expected more of a novel. Especially since it's been advertised as the eighth BOOK in the series. It's a great story but it's a pain to read as its awkwardly formatted and poorly edited (I found several typos). I wish JK Rowling and her publishing team could have just had us wait a little longer until the story was fully novelized. I didn't experience the same immersive magic that I experienced with the other 7 books although I feel that the plot and story events were equal to those in the other books. I felt I was just reading it to get to the end.

content: It's a play so it's a fast read. But it lacks that certain something that makes it's predecessors so great. It would be a terrible gateway into the series, it relies heavily on knowing the characters, and as I mentioned, some of them don't quite seem to be themselves, time passing and maturity can't account for the changes. title: you're disappointed at the things they had to leave out
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content:
You know when you read the book, then watch the movie, you're disappointed at the things they had to leave out, including the characters' thoughts and part of the plot, and that sometimes things aren't pictured as you imagined them?

Then imagine reading just the script of the movie, without the pictures and wonderful visual effects, without the expressions on the faces of the actors -- and of course all the extras that the movie left out are STILL left out....

And that's kind of how reading the script of "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" feels. It's okay, but it could have been so much more.

author: Andrew Finkelstein
title: Decent book, but with unrealistic character motivations
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2016
content:
(Spoiler alert)

It was enjoyable to read a new chapter in the world of Harry Potter. For that, i am grateful. This story, however, has two primary plot holes that made the character motivations feelvunrealistic.

1) Why was Albus so focused on saving Cedrick Diggory? This was the entire premise of the book, and it just felt like a reach to me that someone who he'd never met could motivate him so much to jump off a train, flee campus, and go back in time.  Perhaps if it were rewritten there could have been a stronger motivation from Scorpius? I didn't buy Albus's, though.

2) Once they returned, after rectifying the past, why did Scorpius lie about having the timeturner to the older wizards? It seemed to me like they had learned their lesson after returning. For Scorpius to "take matters into his own hands," it just feels out of character for "timid Scorpius" and overall it is at odds with what it seems they've learned from the first half of the book when they went back in time.

The two above details are incredibly important because they motivate progression in the book, so for me not to believe them, i couldn't buy into the rest of the book.

Again, it was enjoyable to re-experience the characters, but otherwise this did not live up to the Harry Potter name.

author: Jake Lonergan
title: Shouldn't a script be in some sort of loose leaf binder?
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content:
This had the makings of a great story. Except it wasn't a story, not a book story, it was a script. Would it really have been so difficult to flesh it out like a proper book? At times, the script format seriously got in the way of my enjoyment of, or even coherently following, what was happening in the story.

I've purchased every book (hardcover or Kindle), almost every DVD, every HD-DVD, every BluRay and went to every movie but this time I feel a little screwed by JKR. Was this laziness? Knowledge that her fan base would buy the book no matter how flimsy the structure? I see a couple of other novellas listed but I'm afraid to buy them now that I understand her newfound lack on interest in high quality work.

Too bad, this could have been an outstanding book. Oh, well.

author: Azure
title: SPOILERS
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2016
content:
I enjoyed the read, but there were some MAJOR plot holes and blatant absurdities riddled throughout. (E.g. 40-year-old Hermione guards a top-secret artifact with three grade-school level riddles. The Trolley Witch is actually the Terminator. Polyjuice potion takes a month to brew, but the excuse to not use it is that they can just transfigure Harry into Voldemort because plot convenience. How did Albus get his wand back to fight Delphi? Why was Ron morphed into Fred Lite?! Wait, so Cedric becomes a DEATH EATER out of embarrassment? Convenient spilling of love potion and magical reaction on a blanket to send a message forty years into the future!!! Aaaaand the list goes on.)

Ahem. My point: next to everything felt contrived. The writers *not Rowling, she did not write it but did endorse it* simply reused the premise of Prisoner of Azkaban (which, in my humble opinion, had the weakest plot lines of all HP books), threw in some dramatics and teenage angst from an unlikeable and underdeveloped main character (Albus Potter), and rehashed Voldemort. Again. The book's saving grace was Scorpius Malfoy, whom I absolutely adored. He alone would have gotten five stars. He was engaging and funny, and the only character within the context of the story I cared about at all.

But I ramble.  A rating of three stars suits this goofy, vapid read because as I said, it was fun and enjoyable; but overall, it lacked depth and the kind of storytelling magic JK Rowling turns out. Also, Scorpius. I could read eight books about him and Albus (because come on, despite my dislike of Albus, the bromance between the two was still adorable) and enjoy them no matter how wreckless the plot was; which is probably why I didn't give the book 1 star. The plot itself is hackneyed and lacking, but at the very least I got a few laughs from it.

author: L. C Glover
title: Uninspired play that does not add much to the Harry Potter World
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2016
content:
Overall: The story was moderately interesting.  It involves time travel which can be very interesting if done well.  But, this was not done particularly well.  You knew what was going to happen by definition -- no other way than to suddenly change Harry Potter Canon material which is not going to happen with this play.

The writing style / dialog style was a bit off putting for me.  I really did not like the Ron and Hermaine's tone.  The way the characters were portrayed in the future was not very flattering.  I know it is supposed to interject the grind of real life but why do I want too much real life if my escapist reading?

The concept of Voldamort having a child is interesting.  Frankly, if she wanted to really have her revenge then she could have easily done it on the hapless characters in this book.

The content from the play could be an interesting addition to the Harry Potter canon but it needs to be rewritten and definitely not as a play.

I was expecting more for the book.  Harry Potter material does not work particularly well as a play in general anyway.

Summary:
If you are looking for a Harry Potter reading fix, then pick it up but prepared to be annoyed with the play and the author.

author: j.r.
title: The answer to why Harry Potter's life unfolded the way it did.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I liked this book much better than I liked book 7 of the series. This book starts at a time several years later than when book 7 took place, yet the action time travels through much of Potter lore as it attempts to explain why certain events needed to happen as they did.

In this book, Harry and Ginny have three children, and at the start of the book, their second son, Albus, is starting at Hogwarts. Against most odds, Albus, and Draco's son, Scorpius, become best friends. Scorpius develops a crush on Ron and Hermione's daughter Rose. Both Albus and Scorpius feel the weight of being their father's sons, albeit in different ways. For some reason, Albus decides that he needs to save Cedric Diggory from death during the Tri-Wizard Tournament--but his attempts bring about changes that he never imagined and lead to a confrontation of the families against Voldemort and his daughter to ensure that their future remains intact.

title: Not great as her books

content: I enjoyed the story but reading a play is not the same as reading her story form.  I missed the descriptions and I found it was over before it began.  I really wish it was could have been a regular book too.

author: Ricardo Gutierrez
title: Fun for what it is
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2017
content: This is a fun script but when compared to the harry potter books it doesn't stand well. However this was an interesting story that introduces you to new characters as well as revisiting the ones we have grown to love. It also demonstrates where the wizarding world stands so many years after voldemort fall. Recommend it to harry potter fans but ask them not to expect it to be as good as deathly Hallows or prisoner of Azkaban.

author: Valerie Backus
title: Started our promising and took a hard left turn...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I went into this knowing that it was a script and there wouldn't be a lot of character development/detail that the novels had. There were so many plot holes, I wondered if I was reading a glorified fan-fiction.

The characters that I grew up loving were nearly unrecognizable. I get that people grow and change through the years, but I found little to no similarities in them. It started out very promising and took a hard left turn.

author: SMM
title: A disappointment with a few highlights
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content:
We waited and we waited and we hoped and then we waited some more and then we got it. Another Harry Potter story! In a very unconventional form.

The Cursed Child is about Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy, the children of Harry and Draco respectively, and their first few years at Hogwarts dealing with their lineages.  It is also about and adult Harry, Hermione, Ginny, and Ron as they deal with their lives as parents.  This book really focuses on the relationship between parent and child, and what it means to be a good father or son.

First of all, this really isn't another Harry Potter book.  It lacks the magic that the original seven had, but that's not that surprising upon reflection since this is a play and Rowling isn't the main author.  It's her story, yes, but Jack Thorne is a playwright, so really, it's his writing.  And since it's his writing, and intended for the stage, it just doesn't come off the page like I was hoping.  Rather than being relaunched into the favorite world of my childhood it was like reading poor fan fiction.

Beyond getting the voices of the characters pretty much completely wrong, a bunch of unnecessary cameos, a storyline that made only the littlest of sense, and a strange (and disliked) turn of events at the very end, this wasn't a horrible book.  It just let me (and I'm sure quite a few others) down.

I don't want to spoil anything so I'm not going to go into what I really disliked about the book here.  If you want to rant, though, hit me up on twitter and I'll share all my in-detail problems with their full spoiler glory. (shameless twitter promotion: @tsundokusam)

Here's what I did like: the new characters.  Albus and Scorpius are gems!  Scorpius in particular will now always have a special place in my heart because he's absolutely adorable and just precious.  I liked the beginning of the book and what happens when Albus gets to school.  I also really liked Rose, though I wish we could have spent more time with her character.  The relationship between Ron and Hermione was pretty cute, too, and Ginny and Harry are really given the opportunity to show us why they fell in love.

Returning to the Wizarding World has been great, but it seems that it missed out a lot of what we wanted.  Here's to hoping Fantastic Beasts does a much better job.

author: J. L. Gribble
title: Excellent characters, but not the adventure I would have wanted to see them in
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2016
content:
Like many readers, I had a difficult time falling in love with the play that continued the story of the both the original and next generation of wizards from the Harry Potter universe. Since I hadn't read anything in script form in over a decade, I spent a lot of time trying to figure out whether my problem was with the unfamiliar storytelling style. Unfortunately, I finally had to admit that while there was much to enjoy about this tale, the rest of it came up lacking.

Though Prisoner of Azkaban was my favorite of the original novels in the Harry Potter series, which I know is true of many other readers, what I loved about it wasn't the time travel aspect. While it was interesting to see different versions of a future with a grown Harry Potter and companions, it detracted from a story that should have been about the relationships between parents and children.

On the other hand, I loved reading about a Potter sorted into Slytherin House and a Malfoy who wasn't at the top of the totem pole. These were the sort of different futures I wanted to read about, not awkward encounters made even more gimmicky through the use of Polyjuice Potion.

Though the character was intriguing, I saw the major reveal regarding the main villain miles away. In the end, while I loved the new characters, I'm disappointed that this was the adventure that we saw them in. So as I happily add Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them to my personal Harry Potter canon, I'm afraid that this play will linger on the outskirts, keeping company with other exceptionally good Harry Potter fanfic that is fun to read once and never really remember.

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2017
content: This is supposedly Harry Potter 8. When I first heard this was being released, I freaked out, even though I really only loved one of the original seven books. When I found out it was in screenplay form, I was a little confused. Having read it, I am even more confused. The story is solid, but writing is lacking. There are few descriptions of anything in the book. It really counts on the reader knowing what everything and everyone is supposed to look and be like. This is a good read if you are a fan of the series. If you aren't it wouldn't make much sense. I don't know why she wouldn't just novelize this. To me, this is just a really lazy way of making a lot of money. Three stars.

author: Momma124
title: Albus enters Hogwarts expecting an experience like his father’s full of heroism and success
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2017
content: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, a play by Tiffany and Thorne, picks up the infamous story of Harry Potter nineteen years after J.K. Rowling’s novels end. Arguably, this script should not be seen as the “eighth book” in the series, but rather an added bonus. The story follows Harry Potter’s middle child, Albus. Albus enters Hogwarts expecting an experience like his father’s full of heroism and success. However, what he finds is something entirely different. Albus befriends the rumored son of Voldemort, Scorpius, Malfoy’s son. They struggle through Hogwarts as outcastes who do not live up to what society wants them to be. After Albus overhears a conversation Harry, now a ministry worker, has with a supposed old acquaintance who wants to bring his son back from the dead, Albus and Scorpius secretly embarks on a mission of their own to become heros. However, their plan ultimately backfires, and the boys learn a hard lesson when the reality of the future is ever changed by their actions. The boys, along with their parents, fight to save the new world from dark magic and restore life. The play tells the tale of identity, friendship, and family. The script is very well crafted. The playwrights hit many subjects fans of the Harry Potter series have been dying to find out about. However, the play can be perceived as fan fiction as it was not written by the original author and does not contain the same vibe as the original novels. Perhaps the most disappointing part of the script, is that not all characters are true to the novels. Dumbledore, once a wise, brave man, is portrayed as weak and selfish which is a huge let down. Ron Weasley is portrayed as the ‘dumb’ friend, and George Weasley is entirely left off from the play. Overall, the story was exciting and kept me entertained, and the message the story has is very valuable meaning. I think it is worth the read for Harry Potter fans, but one does need to accept the play is not necessarily the reality of the Harry Potter series.

author: Michelle Llewellyn
title: This Will Never Become a Classic
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2017
content:
This is a script. Some of the stage directions include characters feeling "overwhelming fear," "sinking feeling in pit of stomach," while things and characters are levitating on every other page. Someone actually executed all this on a stage? And if I have to read "time...turns over, thinks a bit..." one more time.
I would never want to see this play performed live.
The story is a little better. Voldemort is rumored to be coming back but, never fear, the millennial wizarding generation is here to save us all.
There is so much time traveling in this book, Doc Brown and Marty are crying their eyes out somewhere.
All of the male characters are in love with each other while the female characters don't really contribute much to the overall plot.
And they all lived happily ever after.
Appropriate for Harry Potter fans of all ages, this script contains no swearing, nothing offensive. Read it just to say you did.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not good or Bad - just disappointing and flimsy
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: As a megafan and worshipper of JK Rowling - I am disappointed to say the least. I read the spoilers so knew what was coming but the blow of it still sucks. There are so many plot holes and go-backs on canon that my head spins. I keep trying to make sense of all the mistakes but I just can't. I am so sad. On a bright side there is some really cool bits with hermione and Ron - they prove that their love for each other makes each other the best version of themselves. I also love that scorpius is such an awesome geeky goofball and is a mixture of Harry, ron and hermione so albus really lucked out getting him as his friend. Albus was angsty and angry but that's not a character flaw though. I like that he's angsty I just didn't like him so much - pure slytherin narscisist haha. Anyway it's not a bad story, it's not good though and I'm surprised Jk Rowling approved this story and says it's canon when it goes against many other things she says is canon. I spent the night really upset about this but I have let it go and in my mind this isn't canon - it's fan fiction. This doesn't help in any way the 7 books - it cheapens them.

author: Lady Von Lemonflipper
title: A Let Down
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content:
You may have seen a few reviews that suggest this play reads like fanfiction. It absolutely does, and here's why:

-The play basically takes every "what if" and applies it to this nonsensical story.
"What if this person showed their face again?"
"What if this person had a kid?"
"What if this person lived?"
"What if this person was eviilllllll?"
It's a little much. And the villain? Geez, really? I really can't consider them canon. It doesn't even make sense. There is no way the villain would even exist. (This probably makes more sense, if you've read the play. Staying spoiler-free!)

-The play seems to completely disregard its own universe's established rules.
I'm talking about the (potential spoiler) flipping time travel. The Harry Potter series has always used the Novikov self-consistency principle; you cannot change the past through time travel, you can only fulfill it. Yet in the play, if you go back in time and mess with stuff, you're gonna see major consequences. If this type of time travel is possible, SOMEONE would have at least SUGGESTED in the books to use it to destroy Voldemort before he posed a threat.

-Many of the characters don't seem like themselves.
I'm lookin' at you Harry. I was honestly rooting for Draco in this play, which is not something I ever thought I'd do.

Some good things:
-It's a quick read. It doesn't drag on, so if you still want to read it, you won't drudge through. It took me about 5 hours.
-Some of the stage directions were amazing. I know that may seem trivial, but the way they were described had me imagining sitting in the theater, watching it unfold. And it was great.
-Scorpius. He rocks.
-Some scenes are good. Yes, most of it reads like fanfiction, but some things that happen actually make sense, and I liked seeing their impact, although I wish the Hogwarts years were expanded upon. I was actually really curious to see more of how the kids handled school.

So. I give it three stars, because it's alright as a standalone play. In terms of how it fits in with the Harry Potter storyline... eh... it's not great. I feel bad saying that, but it really wasn't the story it could've been.
Give it a read, see for yourself. Maybe you'll love it!

author: zipporah
title: Mundane, not in keeping with the original Potter novels
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content: Unlike many reviewers, the screenplay format of the book didn't bother me at all. It's what I was expecting based on the description and, since it's been several years since I've read in that format, I thought it might be rather fun. What I didn't particularly care for were the tempo and the story line itself. Knowing that this was written to be performed live on stage and having spent much of my younger days in both school and community theater, I found many of the scenes ridiculously short. I also found the dialogue quite mundane and the story line itself didn't feel in keeping with the seven Potter novels. Fortunately, it was a very quick read so I was able to get through it and set it aside quickly.

author: Jena
title: Meh.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: *CONTAINS SPOILERS* It was just... okay. It was way too light. It covered way too much time. We didn't get to know the characters like we did in the real books because the play covers way too much ground in way too little time. The Minister of Magic thing was irritating and doesn't even match Rowling's writing on Pottermore. The reader can see glimpses of Rowling here and there,  but it is fleeting, and not enough to carry the story. Dumbledore...sobbing? The whole scene was a mess and a complete deviation from his character. The sentence structure wasn't even on point with his character. It was a light read; much too light to really be considered part of the Rowling dynasty. I look forward to Fantastic Beasts and I'm loving the stories she recently released on Pottermore.

Given Rowling's immense talent for exposition, this book is like watching a Harry Potter movie through cellophane, you can get the story, but something is clearly lacking. The plot seems to wrap up the Harry Potter stories neatly, and I guess that is its purpose. Readers wanted more, and the author has had enough. Definitely a read for Harry Potter fans, but disappointing to me.

title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Didn't really live up to the original Harry Potter Legacy for me.

author: Semaj
title: The Author Was Wandless
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
I enjoyed visiting with the now middle-aged principals of the Harry Potter books, but even though J. K Rowling may have suggested this plot, the writing was below her standards for teen-age or adult fiction. My grandson, now 23, who had devoured each volume the day it came out in the US, was hugely disappointed. He would have given it no better than 1 star.

To look at the consequences of actually being able to revisit a historical choice was an interesting premise, but the teenage revolt against parental domination was old hat and the generational misunderstandings unrealistic and too easily resolved.

author: Dave
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: The style was more like a script than a novel.

author: Richard L. Hageman
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: disappointed!

author: Susan
title: Lost in Translation
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
content:
Ok. I get that this is a stage play and that they published the script. However, a stage play is all about visuals that are not necessarily spelled out in the script. Likewise, a book has a lot of color and descriptions to set the scene. This book is not an adaptation. It's the script. Period. No color, few descriptions of scenes, very little to get the imagination going. It's dull and lifeless. More time should have been spend translating this to book form.

The other title I was going to give this review is "Hail! Hail! The Gangs all Here!"  Because, wow! The ENTIRE gang is all here. Even the ones who died in the battle of Hogwarts get to make an appearance. I heard one reviewer call this book fluff for the Potter fan club. That certainly fits. Ms Rowling's tries to hard to get everyone a bit part in her story. It just falls flat.

author: Ignacio Luza
title: Fun, but not as fun as the original books.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
content: I don't have a problem with the script format... Fun, but the story is definitely not up to par with the original books.

author: J. Lewis
title: It's a good story, but...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: A nice book, but missing the whimsy and magic that comes from J.K. Rowling's writing style.  I don't want to spoil the plot or any of the story, it's a nice extra for Potter fans who wonder how Harry and the gang are after Hogwarts.  But I was able to get through it in an hour and a half, afterwards I wasn't left with that feeling I get after finishing a Harry Potter book.  That aching for more.  Mainly because it was written by other people, which is why many refer to this as the authorized fanfic.

author: Andrew D. Fraser
title: swing and a miss
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2017
content: Didn't really care for it.  As a script, it had too much stage direction.  As a story it didn't have enough descriptive passages.  This would have been far more successful had it been a novelization of the script.

author: Larry
title: Disappointing but it's still Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: Just a variation of the old science fiction theme of what would happen if you travelled back in time to change things and the unintended consequences that would come from it. A disappointing sequel to the series. Still, it's Harry Potter so it is a must read.

author: Ms. Gray -Houndz
title: Play format distracted the story
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2017
content: I just couldn't get into the playwright format.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good book for a Preteen
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I don't realize that this was NOT written by JK Rowling until I was well into the book and was surprised by the characters. That's my fault.  I would recommend this book for a preteen, not a good read for adults.

author: Kindle Customer
title: ... my interest but would have preferred it to read like a book not a
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
content: Kept my interest but would have preferred it to read like a book not a play

author: Susan P. Miller
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: Not my favorite!

author: Nay
title: I expected more..
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content: I really enjoyed the story behind it however, I do not like the way it's formatted. I felt disappointed that they put a play into a book and called it a day. I wanted an actual story/book to fill my imagination. But I guess this is what we get when the writer doesn't care.

author: Chadwick Ritchie
title: omgoddness
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: so this weekend i went up to mighan. and I was reading the fifth Harry  potter wich it pretty good.

author: Jingyuan D.
title: Three Stars

content: A little disappointed with this one.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2017
content: I was expecting more.

author: Chris_D_in_Oregon
title: Arrived on time and as described.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content: Arrived on time and as described.

author: MD
title: Script not book
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: Disappointed, it was a script and not a story like the other Harry Potter books.

author: Nick Tommarello
title: Not what I expected...
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2016
content: I enjoyed a lot of the beginning and how the trio was living their lives, but I believe the majority of the rest of the story and plot is so crazy that it's unbelievable. Voldemort has a child?! No thank you. It should probably receive less than three stars, but I love Harry Potter, so what the heck!

author: Samantha
title: Kind of depressing.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2018
content: As a Harry Potter fan, i felt that i needed to read this. It wasnt bad but not as good as  the first series. Keep in mind with this book that Harry and his friends are in new roles and face very realistic troubles that come with adulthood, such as parenting and focusing on a career. But i did enjoy some unexpected turns, heartfelt moments, and connections to the previous story.

author: CMac -Amazon Addict!
title: I REALLY wish that it was put into normal novel form - it's frustrating to read in this form
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
content: Hard to red in the form of a play - I was hoping for more of a novel involving the cast. I can't understand why they could not re-write the book in the form of a novel instead of presenting it this way. The kids are having trouble reading it and getting into it in this form just as much (if not more) as the adults in the house. Silly move to send it out as a play and not a book

author: cascadingharmony
title: the plot is good and shows some promise
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content:
First of all, you miss a lot not having it written by Rowling. Some of the dialogue feels really stilted and unnatural. Having said that, the plot is good and shows some promise. I wonder if it would be better live (remember that it's a draft of the final play script). What I really wish is that Rowling would write the novel version...THAT would be a great read!
To sum up, if you can't stand reading things in play format, don't purchase. BUT, if you don't mind different writing mediums, go for it!

author: John Colp
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: i think i would have liked the story the play was based on better than the play...

author: Usanee Morris
title: Not like what I expected
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content: I have read all 7 of harry potter books and can't find the words to tell you how much I love them. I was very excited when I saw the 8th harry potter. But after I read the book I am quite disappointed. It was nothing like Harry potter that I love in my childhood. No more delicated detail in the story. It now became just like those roughly made movie plots that you can find anywhere nowaday.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Pretty good
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I am a Harry Potter fanatic and was excited about this release. It is definitely not the same as previous. It ignored some great characters that were in previous books.

author: Ninja
title: I enjoyed this. As you have probably read in the ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2017
content: I enjoyed this. As you have probably read in the other reviews, it does not hold a candle to the skilled writing of the Harry Potter series however I didn't expect it to. It is a screen play, surpisingly easy to read for one however it is still something that was made to be seen not read. I am a Harry Potter fan and it was fun to be back in Hogwarts and in the magic that JK Rowling created. This book doesn't immerse you in the world it creates like the main HP series does however it is still enjoyable.

author: Sweet-n-Rad
title: I wanted to like this, but it didn't have the same magic ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2017
content: I wanted to like this, but it didn't have the same magic that the other stories had. It was interesting, but somewhat stale. I'm sorry. I still love all things Potter!

author: Katie Fujarski
title: Like everyone else
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: Like everyone else, I had expectations for this story. I found it interesting and engaging, but now I feel that I need to see it on stage for I feel like from the book alone I'm missing a certain something that I can't quite put my finger on. It is definitely not as well written as the novels and feels, at the same time, both a natural extension of the story and completely out of place. Maybe seeing it on stage would make me like it more...

author: dramaprof
title: Oddly disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2019
content: I was surprised at how clumsy the dialogue is. Then I discovered that J.K. Rowling didn't write it. She came up with the story, and a playwright fleshed it out. It's not nearly as magical to read as everything she has written herself. However, I hear the production is amazing, and I'm looking forward to the opportunity to see it!

author: Irene Wendy Wode
title: The characterization in Act 2 can be painful. If you can get through that
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2016
content: This is less well-written than a lot of Harry Potter-derivative stories I have read. The characterization in Act 2 can be painful. If you can get through that, though, acts 3 and 4 are pretty good.

author: TJ Gregson
title: Seems unnecessary
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: When Draco called Harry "Harry Potter" instead of "Potter",  I knew that this was in trouble.

author: Caryn C
title: It's a script - feels like fan fic
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: I went into this book knowing it was a play and that I would be reading a script. I also knew that it wasn't written by J.K Rowling herself but was approved by her. Even knowing all this before reading I was still disappointed. It felt like some off brand fan-fic. I don't accept this story as canon and even the dialogue from many of the characters doesn't seem to fit them.

author: David M. Tomer
title: very different from original series, but read it anyway
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content:
While it IS a must read for fans of the HP series, it is very different.  Characters do not seem well developed... for a while I reminded myself it is much harder to develop characters in a play (we are all aware this is a play, right?  In fact, maybe two... or just one in four acts).  [mild spoilers ahead?]  But even many of the familiar characters seem relegated to serve as plot devices... this one to insert humorous lines even though he/she is too smart to say them; that one to serve as the voice of authority even though he/she appears less mature than in the novels.  The plot might even be a little strained for the purpose of including a number of unexpected (i.e. deceased) characters from the novels.  A family member described it as a lot like a fan fic.
All that is not to say it isn't imaginative and dark and a welcome exploration of some of the emotional issues confronting old and new characters.  Someday I expect I will try to see a performance just to see how the scripted effects will look.

author: Barbara Loeb
title: I DIDN'T KNOW IT WAS A PLAY, AND FOUND ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016
content: I DIDN'T KNOW IT WAS A PLAY, AND FOUND IT MUCH LESS ENJOYABLE READING THAN THE OTHER HARRY POTTERS.

author: Fernando Ugarte
title: Watch out, this is a theatre play, not a novel  (but it is worth reading any way)
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2016
content: I was disappointed when I saw that this was not a novel written by Rowling, but the script for a theatre play written by several authors. Nevertheless, once I started reading, it was difficult to stop, as even in the absence of detail regarding the environment, feelings, background or motivation, the dialogues carried out the story quite well.

author: K Chippendale
title: Average at best
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: Seemed more like fan fiction than a literary work, feels out of place in the Harry Potter canon, much like the epilogue to the 7th book.

author: Mom of Pie

author: Dustin M. Waibel
title: Just trying too hard
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2016
content: I really appreciate the attempt here, and I do love many moments of this story. What I can't abide by though is, the blatant attempt to make this just a story to make Potter fans happy, in lieu of a good story. As someone who was wearing a "Gryfindor Quidditch" t-shirt while reading this, I wish the authors had branched out instead of just playing "what if?" for hundreds of pages. I can't get much more specific than that without spoilers, but suffice to say, I enjoyed the story but was quite underwhelmed.

author: Amazon Customer

author: Audrey
