author: Scarlett.Ian
title: It's hard to say this, but this is not the same Harry Potter that I grew up reading.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2016
content:
Okay so first things first, I am a HUGE Potterhead; I read my first Harry Potter book when I was in the 4th grade and I've been in love with the series ever since.  I own every movie, every book (including all the mini books released – Quidditch through the Ages, Tales of Beedle the Bard, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them), and I have read each of the 7 books so many times that I could probably tell you the entire story without cracking a single book.  So naturally when I hear that almost 10 years after the last book was released that a new book would be published, I could not wait to read it – to be honest I am surprised it took me so long to get my hands on it.  I think subconsciously I was worried I was building up the excitement too much and that this play would fail me.  I read this over Thanksgiving weekend, but I haven't posted about it because I've needed this time to reflect.
This book is actually a play, in case you hadn't heard.  I wasn't a fan of reading plays when I was in school, so I make it a habit not to read them in my adulthood; but hey – I had to make an exception for this one.  I knew ahead of time and prepared myself; that I can deal with.  I think my biggest (and really only?) issue with this book is that I can't really tell that it was a J.K. Rowling/Harry Potter book.  The writing styles were different, the characters were different & acted differently and it just didn't have the same kind of flow that I came to expect of a Harry Potter book.  Don't get me wrong – this is a good play, IF you go into with the mindset that it is NOT a Harry Potter book.  It seemed kind of rushed, and I actually was able to read it in a 12ish hour period.  Even on my 7th or 8th read of Sorcerer's Stone it takes me longer than that to thoroughly enjoy.
This is, unfortunately, probably the lowest rating I have given a book and it breaks my heart that it is a Potter book that is receiving such a low star rating.  But I cannot in good conscience give it a higher rating.  Maybe if it wasn't an official HP book?  Or maybe even if J.K. Rowling's name wasn't on it?  I'm giving this 3 stars because, if I separate it from my previous love for HP, it is a good play.

author: Fantasylover
title: Play acting waste of time and paper.

content: Why a play?  A book would have been better.  Wish she would quit fooling around and write what we want to read.  More Harry Potter.

author: Shannon
title: It's a fast read
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: Somewhat predictable. Definitely not J.K. Rowling's best, but still an OK read. This is a really fast book to read, for the simple fact that it is printed in script format, which means it tells you who is saying what and what is going on with the staging for the play. If you are a Harry Potter fan looking for a detailed explanation of time between the defeat of Voldermort to the how and when Harry and Ginny get married and what happens when Harry and Ginny see their son Severus off on the Hogwarts Express, you will be disappointed. Enjoy this book for what it is: a story that takes place over a small snippet of time.

content: A swing and a miss.  I am a Potter head, but this format left me cold.  I can do Shakespeare, but this was just the wrong format for Harry.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good if you like disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content: As a huge Harry Potter fanatic, I  so desperately wanted to love this screenplay. What a disappointment. It felt nothing like the seven books and the whole thing was just upsetting in general.  Not a fan.  I would definitely still go see the show though,  maybe the character  development and interactions will play out differently (read: better)  on stage.

author: Matt Posner
title: Plays can have great characterization and style, but this is lacking in both
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
It's nice to have a new story with Harry Potter characters, even if it's a play which cannot include the details supplied by the actors and the staging. That said, the story is rather a mess. SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS. The dialogue is not at the level of Rowling's; many elements seem to have been inserted into the plot in order to satisfy fans who want to see familiar characters in particular contexts; extensive teasing of a love affair between two boys goes nowhere and should either have been used or removed; numerous characters become purely functional and somewhat interchangeable role-players in the plot, particularly Hermione, Ginny, and even Harry. Draco Malfoy is unrecognizable. The villain is both predictable and, to a great degree, underutilized.

I can understand that JK Rowling probably just wants to write Cormoran Strike right now, but frankly she should have made sure this was written at a higher standard. I think of the complexity of character development in, say, The Casual Vacancy, which is like a short version of a Tolstoy novel, and wonder why she couldn't get this play to be a little better about it. Plays can have great characterization and great style. No doubt I will read this again after a while and find more nuances than in my quick rush-through, but I wish still it had been better.

author: Gina Marmol
title: Fans shouldn't stay away
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2016
content: Wasn't like the others but still worthwhile, especially if you're a fan of the series...seriously, how can you possibly stay away? Still, a bit slow in some parts. I have to say you have to admire Rowling for trying something new! Script/play mode is not my thing, but I got over it.

title: Three Stars

content: Not exactly what I expected. Would have been better in book form than play script. It was nice to see the potter team back together though

author: Fishergirl Seattle
title: Seriously disappointed.

content: When I pre-ordered this book months ago, I thought it would be a story. I thought that the "rehersal" part of the edition, was an included extra, not that the whole book would be written as a play. I am seriously disappointed.

title: A nice story
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2016
content: I loved the Harry Potter books. The reading of this play just does not stack up to one of the books. I would love to see her write some more books similar to the originals.

author: Sterling Sound
title: People, it's a script.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Very mixed feelings about Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. Read 3 Acts so far - I get why people are angry. But people, it was explicitly stated by J.K. Rowling and on the book jacket, that this was a script. I think many people aren't used to reading a play, because it is very easy to read, you just have to picture what is going on on stage. But I agree...the dialogue and plot are not very true to the essence of the original books. I mean, the plot holes alone! I'll have to go back and reread the originals again after finishing this script. Still excited to see the play in person though.

author: Bell
title: Book arrived damaged
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Super excited to receive the book today! I was surprised to see that it isn't a real difficult reading level for my kids. The only complaint that I have is that the book was slightly damaged. On the front cover in the middle the book it was a little bent and wrinkled. Of course it doesn't effect the way it reads but it does effect the appearance. I wouldn't normally complain but it is a brand new book. So am only rating it a 3 star because of the damage to the book.

author: Ashland
title: Disappointing :(
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2016
content: I'm not sure if it's because this book was written as a play but I just wasn't a very big fan of it. I didn't even finish it and I have loved the Harry Potter series all my life.

author: Tilly
title: then perhaps it would have been best to have left it at the seven books instead ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
What I wouldn't give for a time turner to go back when this was conceived and warn JK Rowling to come up with her own plot for the script or just maybe write an 8th novel. If there's one thing I've always wanted that someone else had it was her imagination. Unfortunately, in The Cursed Child it seems to be non-existent. So I'm wondering if she didn't want to revisit Harry, then perhaps it would have been best to have left it at the seven books instead of handing over the reins to someone else.

Like the rest of you, I'm a huge Harry Potter fan. I'd pre-ordered it with a couple of other books but it wouldn't be here till Sept and I was NOT going to wait that long to return to the world of Harry Potter. So out I went first thing the morning of it's release and picked it up. Four hours later my giddiness had turned to confused wonder. What had I just read?

I had no problem with it being a script. I thought it kind of exciting to get Harry's story in a different medium. I've done theater in the past and a good script is like a good book; you can easily get lost in the story. Sadly I think this is where The Cursed Child suffers the most. Sure the plot is not the best (ok not great at all given the soooo many different ways this could have gone) but as Harry Potter fans we're used to characters with complex feelings and histories. We've already been opened up to the immense wonder of that world and it's people. As a script this limits us to what we see and hear. We aren't allowed the into the heads of the characters and as a result complex inner turmoil and character development we get in the books are lost. Instead emotions are verbalized which in turn, all too often in this case, leads to some cheesy dialog. I might have been able to forgive some of the character inconsistencies if this had been in novel form and motivations were better fleshed out.

As it were I was left wondering what had happened to the characters we all knew and loved. Harry was...well not at all like Harry. If this book did one thing for me it made me look back on my life (I'm 39 so thought I could relate to Harry at this point) and all it's trials and tribulations (and there have been some big ones) and wonder how much I've changed. I can honestly say nothing to the degree of Harry. I get it, he's had a traumatizing past, he's now a family man with a stressful job but this is like Harry in a midlife crisis. As one reviewer stated all Harry wanted was a family. It was the most important thing to him next to friendship yet here he was acting like a petulant child. I related far more to younger Harry than this one. Your experiences shape you as a human but with good people surrounding him I would have thought Harry would have grown up to be a better adjusted adult. And as for Harry's excuse he didn't have a father...well I know some pretty amazing fathers that didn't have ones of their own. Besides he seemed to do just fine with James and Lily.

As for Albus I spent my time wishing I could put him in a time out. The rest of the characters seemed to be nothing more than shells of their former selves. Harry described Ginny as bold, fierce and funny but I got nothing of this from her, Ron was not Ron and Hermoine...well there were moments I could see her and moments not so much (ie. turning into a warrior in the future-wow that one threw me for a loop). Voldemort having a child with Bellatrix and Cedric turning into a death eater as a result of embarrassment were also a stretch for me.

So why 3 stars (and this is a low 3)? Mostly because it's Harry Potter. I was at least able to return to that world whether I liked it or not (Hey we can't always change our own world to how we want so I'll have to accept Harry's as it is as well-or just make up a new story in my head). It wasn't all bad. There were a couple of good quotes and of course it was nice to see some of the old characters again. I think my favorite part of the script was the involvement of Draco. I enjoyed getting a glimpse into his life and seeing how he changed. I also enjoyed Scorpius and how he turned out so differently from his family. In fact, I would have loved to have seen more of their story. I think they would have made a more compelling plot.

Oh well. As it is I can say I read it. Will it be going on my keeper shelf? Nope, I'm pretty sure my seven other books would set a banishing charm on it. For now I'll keep my sight on Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (making sure not to set my hopes too high).

author: Amazon Customer
title: If you enjoy reading plays...
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2016
content: I always crave more about Harry Potter and enjoyed learning what happened next in the lives of Harry and the other characters in the Potter books.  I like to read plays and visualize the stage scenes in my mind.  However, if you do not like to read plays, you probably will not enjoy this book.

author: Marijean sahyouni
title: Disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: The book is okay.  Disappointing story, but I think it would be cool to see on stage.  I think the effects are what will make this good.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Play the Play
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2016
content: NOTE: This is a play and it is written in that format. While it does not have the depth of JKR's normal books, it does have the same feel. I felt it would be better for you to have you and your HP friends each act out a part because it does not have the same growth or exploration of characters as the books. While it is a good topic to explore on, the play format, like the movies, does not have the time for you to really get to know the new characters as reading the books would allowed you to. It is interesting to see Harry and the gang grown up and how the next generation is, but it feels that the situation is plot driven to allow certain events to happen as oppose to real character motives. I hope JRK allows the HP universe to expand to allow other writers the freedom carry on the story or to delve into other aspects of the universe (hopefully the movie "Strange Beasts.." will allow that).

title: Good book but not as good as the others
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2017
content: I liked the book but it wasn’t as good as the others. The fact that was for a play may it harder to be engaged

author: Amazon Customer
title: It's an average script with famous characters
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content:
If it were a stand-alone play without the Harry Potter name, people would point to its many parts and say it took from this and that story. Words from some tv show or long ago movie.

The direction is very precise yet I can't help but think that the writers had a specific tone for characters speaking certain lines that are lost on the reader. Plus the set, if this were done as close to concept as possible, feels like it's too cinematic for the stage. Special effects up the wazoo and whatnot.

Finally, the magic wasn't even part of the story. It seemed put on. Or forced on. The brilliance of the Harry Potter series lies in that fantastic world of magic and how wondrous and commonplace it was. That universe just became fleshed out as the years wore on. It's not here.

But, as stories go, it's simple and straightforward. A story of parents and children and how we can never have the parents we want, or the children that we thought we could shape. That space is where the conflict really lay. And it's pretty typical.

author: K Bilz
title: Meh
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2016
content: I do actually like reading plays, so that wasn't the thing that detracted from my rating. The story was entertaining, but there were some flaws in the time travel progression (I'm rather picky about my time travel) and some of the stage directions/actions were contradictory. It's fun to think about the Harry Potter universe all grown up. I was just hoping for something a little better... different... more (not sure what)?

author: Sabrina Boutin
title: A pale comparison.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
You know how sometimes Disney makes an okay movie with a slew of famous voice actors? And you know how sometimes Disney makes a sequel to those okay movies with completely different voices, thereby making the sequel to the okay movie even less okay than the first?
That's how I feel about 'Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.' It is a pale comparison to JK Rowling's original 7 Harry Potter books. It feels somehow plastic, not nearly as real.
When I read the 7 original books, I could not put them down. Was absolutely, incredibly enthralled by them. They remain my favorite books even now. When I read this newest one, my brain would connect that I was reading something and then it would go "Oh, yeah, that Harry Potter book." It wasn't something I NEEDED to ick right back up.
So, ya, if you're a hardcore Potterhead, than you should read a copy. But it isn't going to enrich your life or your understanding of the wizarding world.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Expected a novel, not a sreenplay
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content: Have not read yet...but not quite what I had expected

author: Cricket
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: interesting, not heartstopping.

author: John
title: Accio Nostalgia
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
If you're expecting to find deep, complex themes/plots comparable to books 1-7 in this play, then you will be sorely disappointed. The Cursed Child is a quick, fun read that will satiate your potter-cravings but don't go in with too much expectations. I was very generous to give this a three star review. Had it been a fully fleshed out novel, it would've probably been different. It's a play so obviously we can't expect the writer's imagination to translate into production (there are some things magic can't do in the rigid frames of reality). It's great seeing the trio again but the play was written by another writer so the dialogues are obviously less Rowling-esque, not to mention the characters themselves. The characters don't feel like Rowling's creation, but more like some writer's interpretation of them. Hermione's character is the way I imagined she would be, tough strong, independent, and witty. Other than her, I couldn't really relate to Harry and Ron again. I wasn't sure if it was because of the nineteen year gap between Deathly Hallow and this book and their personalities just changed or if they were rewritten. I couldn't find a hint of their usual charm in the book. Besides that, I loved Scorpio and Albus! Scorpio stood out the most to me-- funny, pure, smart, reserved, and a closet adventurer! There's a lot of potential for this boy. His story is unique and interesting but all too familiar. This boy will have a book with his name on it for the next generation of potter heads.

Overall, there are numerous plot holes in the story but if you don't think too much, if you're only here solely for your love for the series, then you should be fine. I appreciated the fan service that was scattered throughout the book (and there are plenty to that will get you cheering and teary from nostalgia) but it could've been written better.. Three stars is the best I can do.

author: Lindsey Johnson
title: Not a must read.

author: Eva Melusine Thieme
title: Did JK Rowling really write this? Meh.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content:
Ho-hum. Most books, you either like them or you don’t. For this one, I can’t decide.

Maybe it’s because I give JK Rowling a bonus for being brilliant and she could copy the phone book and I’d still read it happily. Or maybe it’s because I missed these characters so much that I would have given anything to see them again, so to speak, even at the cost of having to read a mediocre book.

Because that’s really what it is, a mediocre book. My first gripe is that you can tell it wasn’t written like JK Rowling’s other books, aside from the fact it’s a play and not a novel. Meaning it doesn’t seem to be written entirely by her. For this book you feel she sort of glanced over the summary and gave her nod of approval, then left the premises. There are too many inconsistencies – it’s called the Ministry OF Magic, not FOR Magic in her other books, and certain charms like “Flipendo” have never appeared in her other works, just the computer games. I found that sloppy – like an unwelcome intrusion. As if people who’d only ever seen the movie but not read the books were suddenly in charge.

Spoiler alert: The time turner makes another appearance. As does gillyweed and polyjuice potion. Lots and lots of polyjuice potion. I never found it all that convincing to begin with, thinking that of all the magic available, going that way is the most cumbersome avenue, and it stays that way here. Personally, I would have loved another walk through Diagon Alley but there was no room for that. Actually, the entire first few years of Hogwarts are compressed into just a few pages, which is hard to swallow given the typically slow start and diving right into the moment for all the other books.

The story is basically all about Harry’s youngest son Albus who struggles as a teenager, as teenagers are prone to do, feeling oppressed by the fame of his father and not fitting into the family mold. His best friend is Scorpius Malfoy, Draco’s son, around whom suspicions swirl that he is Voldermort’s son. A fantastic plot of time travel and messing up the past ensues - It’s plausible I guess, but I found the plot too forced –bringing back certain elements of the previous series that had been particularly popular. There were parts that I enjoyed – the glimpses of Ron and Hermione as a married couple, for instance, another appearance of Prof. Umbridge, or hearing a little bit more of Dumbledore’s wisdom – but the main shortcoming for me was Harry. He just didn’t seem to be using his head like he used to.

If you love these characters and have been dying to hold this not-really-a-sequel in your hands, you’re going to buy it and read it, regardless what anyone here says. But if you really want to treat yourself to some good fresh writing, read JK Rowling’s (aka Robert Galbraith) Cormoran Strike detective series. THAT is a story you won’t be able to put down.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Fanfiction in book form. Not great, but good enough.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: To be clear, I am not passionate about Harry Potter; I am obsessed. That being said, this script is less like a Harry Potter novel and more like a poorly written fan fiction filled with innuendos that suggest Scorpius and Albus are gay for each other. This is as amusing as you would imagine, as everyone seems to ship it except for Harry Potter himself.  Overall, though it was amusing and overwhelmingly nostalgic, it didn't quite hit the mark. The only thing of importance about this book is that it does give us some answers to the questions we've been asking ourselves since the last book.  6/10 would recommend to people who know what they're getting themselves into.

author: Teresa3607
title: Cedric Diggory and Ludo Bagman seemed like characters we had never been introduced to before
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2016
content:
It is difficult to believe that Ms Rowling had a hand in this play.  My biggest complaint is the 'character assassination'  that takes place, since Ms. Rowling is a master at character development.  In particular, the Trolley Witch, Cedric Diggory and Ludo Bagman seemed like characters we had never been introduced to before.

I realize that in a play script you do not have the time to thresh out the characters or develop the plot as you do in a novel or movie.  However, this script reads more like an outline for a novel.  This script fell short of my expectation.

title: Harry tries parenting teenagers.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
content: The storyline was good. I thought it was a bit slow to get into the story and then when it was over I wanted more. More stories about the Potters jnr. It was a typical revitting Harry Potter story. A must read for all Harry Potter fans.

author: TH1028
title: Sad, I wanted so badly to love it. (Possible Spoiler warning)
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Look, I ADORE Harry Potter. I wanted to love this new story. It isn't awful, but it does NOT feel like JKR's work. It doesn't feel like a genuine HP story. This feels like fanfic. The original characters (Hermione, Ron, Harry, Ginny, Draco, McGonagall, and even Amos Diggory) don't feel genuine. They don't feel anything like the "real" characters. This feels, sadly, just like any series where someone different takes over and starts writing. Everyone is there, everyone we love, but they're different - like they've had a lobotomy or something. I don't think it was necessary to turn Ron into a bumbling idiot. I find it highly unlikely that Hermione and Ron would ever raise a child like Rose. Then again, Rose plays nearly NO PART in all this. Albus is a jerk, Scorpius is an incredibly kind person, and I wanted more of him than just humorous one liners.

There's little in the way of character development. They tried to cram 5 years worth of content into a short stage production. If this was always the premise of the story, it was a poor idea to force it into a stage production. Nothing about this translates well. I'm sure the staging is beautifully done in person, but the story itself all feels rushed, and half baked. It truly, and deeply pains me to say this - but I just didn't like it. It really feels like Thorne's fanfic, not JKR's work. I've read much BETTER Fanfic than this. After all these years, I really thought I would love anything JKR wrote in the HP universe. I was very, very wrong. I will still place it in my collection, it is still a part of the HP world, and as a whole, I treasure that world. This just isn't my cup of tea.

***Update - I re-read this. I still don't love it. But I don't hate it either. I am considering that possibly the nuances of character development and dialogue require the actors (who I hear are amazing) to really bring them to life. I still dislike the plot. It still reeks of fanfic.

author: lpd32
title: I wanted to love it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: I wanted to love this book. I've remained a loyal HP fan since my childhood and was estactic about the new book. However, the screenplay format is a tough read. It loses the charm and story telling which made Rowling famous. I'm sure seeing the actual play would be wonderful, though. But overall, I am glad for the look into Harry's adult life.

author: stu mitchell
title: I'm a bit dissapointed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I love Harry Potter. It is my life. I reference it constantly, draw deathly hallows and lightning bolts everywhere. I have hogwarts robes and shirts and jewellery. I'm a big reader and HP is top of the list. So I was litterally shaking with exitement. I found the build up to the release and the exitement better than the actual book. I was dissapointed. To give you some comparison, when I finnished the deathly hallows I was crying and laughing and so sad that it was over. My parents made me wait a year or two before reading each book so I grew up and matured at the same time the characters did. My reaction to the cursed child was, "oh. I guess it was ok. I mean... it was fine." you just can't go into it expecting Harry Potter. It moved to fast, and the characters where not like themselves. Plus the whole writing style was lost. And thats a big part of what makes HP so good. Still buy it though. Just don't get your hopes up. Go into it expecting fan fiction. When thinking about HP, think about the original 7.
Harry Potter is still the best book ever written.
Always.

content: Having been a dedicated fan since the age of five, I was very excited to receive this book in the mail today. Unfortunately I must say it was a bit of a letdown. The story read like a fanfic piece and the original characters did not really seem to speak to me in the way they did in the original books. The new characters also seemed sort of flat, and I didn't really feel attached to them in the same way as the original characters. This could be attributed to the fact that this is a screenplay and not a book, but I've read other screenplays that simply felt more involved. I really hate to give this story three stars, but the whole thing felt like a forced and unnecessary addition to the canon universe.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It's okay. You should still buy it.

content:
I'm glad she released this because I will never get to London to see the actual production. But, there were character inconsistencies throughout the book, and several disappointing behaviors of characters we've come to know and love. Also, the main character switched about three times through the book, so it was difficult to really invest in the story.

All in all, I would buy it again because I adore the original 8. And, I commend Ms. Rowling's courage in releasing this. And, I'm so glad she made this a play, thereby leaving the original 8 alone, but still revisiting the magical world of Harry Potter.

author: L. Wallis
title: Totally disappointed

content: I'm a Harry Potter super-fan.  I have ALL the books, movies, books-on CD's, all the additional books (Beetle the Bard, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, and 10-12 more). I've seen all the movies and have the music CD's, Harry's wand and other collector items. I have a robe, a Gryffindor throw and sweater, etc., etc.  I can't get into this script.  I got the thing when it came out, and haven't been able to read past Act One, Scene 10.  It has totally disappointed me.  I'd like a J.K. Rowling novel written by her as the others have been.

author: Shelsi Harper

author: Vicki M. Gonzalez

date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I liked the story but would prefer a novel to the play, as the novels all had such wonderful detail about the characters and the wizarding world.  The play was okay because we already know the characters and can imagine them from the detail that had gone before.  However, new characters seemed one-dimensional because there was not that same type of character development.

author: Tricia Klebacha
title: I did not like the way it was written
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I did not like the way it was written.  All with stage writing.  It was an ok book, but not the type I am used to reading.

author: Amanda
title: Not on the level of the harry potter series, but you have to read it
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content:
It's an easy read, which is what you would expect from a book that's target audience is children. It's a must-read simply because it is the last official book in the series. I don't even mind the script format. You get the background from the stage cues.

I was extremely disappointed in the characters' roles. I could understand to an extent Harry Potter having trouble communicating with his teenage son Albus Dumbledore. I cannot understand how Harry Potter is grappling to find common ground with his son after 15 years. Harry was an outcast at Hogwarts at times, so I find it hard to believe Harry could not relate to how Albus is feeling. I think Harry in this book is almost unlikeable. He always got in shenanigans when he was at Hogwarts and valued his friendship with Ron and Hermione, so how could he possibly think an appropriate punishment is to separate Albus from his one friend!?! Also, Ginny has a very depressingly passive role as his wife. Ron is still an enjoyable character, and he lightens the book with his antics.

The time traveling aspect seems like a crutch. In a way, the writers do not have to come up with a new storyline. The book ends with nothing new really happening. It's repetitious and an easy way to use that world without changing it. It's also reminiscent of Prisoner of Azkaban where they use a time traveler to travel back in time and have to make sure not to run into themselves. However, time traveling is a main plotline in this book.

I really love the character Scorpius Malfoy. His humor and relationship with Albus makes the book worth reading. Albus being a Slytherin was really exciting, but the writers never really used it to their advantage. You never see the Slytherin house from a different angle or gain a new appreciation for that house. Also, I wish there was more of a conclusion to whether Albus and Scorpius end up enjoying Hogwarts more or if anything changed for them there.

All in all, read it but don't expect it to be on the same level as the other 7 books.

date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: First off, I'm a huge Harry Potter fan. I'm constantly going back every couple of months and reading the books. That said, that whole magical and insanely creative world Rowling has created with Harry Potter is not in this book. Being as it is a screenplay, there are none of the small, yet magically delightful details that she put into her other potter novels. There is no character depth, or thoughts that make you partial to any new characters. Although the there is enough of the world we love to make this screenplay enjoyable for us desperate potter fans who love anything about hogwarts and the magic world, it doesn't satisfy the craving of anyone waiting to dive back into hogwarts and relive some magic with the old gang. Good story, could have been great with added, typical Rowling, details. But doesn't meet expectations for true Potter fans.

title: It was ok
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2019
content:
I liked how this was a continuation of the series I love but it is written completely as a screen play, which isn't really my thing. But even with that aside, I felt most of characters fell fairly flat (partly because of that and other parts due to their actions) and some things that happened in the plot just came out of nowhere, but not like a twist or surprise but more like "well, that was random." The alternate time dimensions were cool to see how things could've been, and at least those made sense, as to how it could have happened. Certain characters from the original series I felt did not stay true to their originals but 19+ years have passed and also parenthood, but there were some things that they did that, even with that, I still don't think they would've done or at least done differently. I did finish this book though, it was interesting enough to see how it would end.

I'm trying really hard not to give any spoilers, but I think the story was just ok, but that is just my opinion. I'm sure there will be others that disagree, and of course, I am not an author.

Although there were many twists and turns in the plot line, all of them were able to be predicted chapters ahead of time. I think this will make an excellent stage play, I want to go see it, but as for the book, it was lackluster.

author: Samantha Romero
title: Harry Potter- The SCRIPT
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content:
When I first heard that J.K.Rowling had written a new Harry Potter novel, I was as excited and confused as every other fan. Soon I realized that it was not actually written by her nor was it a novel but a play. This helped me to set up my expectations to start reading. From the beginning, the play requires a lot of background knowledge in the history of Harry Potter. I found myself pausing to reflect on pieces from previous books or the movies to help me place myself in the story and create the imagery. If you have not previous read any of the books, I think it might be hard to follow and invest in the same way as any of the other books.  It was a wonderful play but as a book it was not up to the “Rowling Harry Potter” name.
The book was enjoyable and a quick read. I met some new characters, revisited Hogwarts and got to image the life of Ginny and Harry as parents.  With any play, they develop a lot of the personality of characters through the act which was hard to develop in this book. I was able to piece together a sense of Albus and Scorpius but the character of Rose was very limited. In previous Harry Potter books, I felt like I deeply understood the characters and could relate to them in various situations. Because of the limited writing in this story, it was hard to know them deeper than a surface level.  The adventure was also not as detailed as true Rowling fashion. While the authors wrote about each time travel back and the ripple effect they had created, I never felt the same buildup of the adventure. I was also left confused about this daughter and am planning to go back and re-read the Harry Potter books to see where this could have actually been placed!
This book only took a few hours to read and while it wasn’t all I expected it to be, it was a great trip back to Hogwarts and with some familiar characters and settings.  I have read mixed reviews on this book and I personally believe that if you are a Harry Potter fan, it’s a fun adventure to remind you of the magic as long as you go in expecting it as a play and not as one of Rowling’s detailed novels.

I would recommend giving this a read if you are a Harry Potter fan in need of more to read about Harry and his world. I enjoyed the story and couldn't put it down for the 4 hours it took me to read.

author: Cdubs
title: Hardcore Harry Fans: Lower Your Expectations
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2016
content:
I'm going to say the same thing here I said on Goodreads.

 ** spoiler alert ** While it was nice to continue the Harry Potter story... I think I need to see it on stage instead of read it.

It was capturing, it was a cool idea. Obviously JK Rowling didn't write it, she came up with the idea of the story but not the script. The voices of the stronger female characters were not as prevalent. McGonagall was still strong as the Headmistress and her usual stoic yet caring self... but it was missing something. Hermione... wtf happened. Sometimes she was her strong, know it all self. Other times it was like she just took a back seat. Hermione never takes a back seat. Ron was forgettable. It all just happened too fast. I feel ironic saying that since it's two plays that span about 2.5 hours each.

As I said, I just need to see it on stage. If Jo wrote it herself, turned it into a novel, I'd probably like it better.

title: This hurts

I was so excited to see my old friends again. But they aren't real in the play.  They aren't real to Rowland's true canon. That's not Harry. The playwrights ruined our Harry. They ruined all of them. It was not good enough they all deserve better. However, I liked how Draco was able to bring himself from the darkness. He was my favorite part of this play. Read if you have to. If things play out I will see if someday on Broadway. This hurt to write. The play is three because I love the characters even when they are poorly written and bastardized.

author: Rowan Moonstone
title: Would love to see the play.  The book, not so much
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Finished "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" last night. Keep in mind, this is a script and thus only contains dialogue and stage directions. As a theater major, my mind can fill in the blanks. A lot of folks won't be able to and the intricate world drawing that Rowling did in the novels is missing. That said, I'd LOVE to see the production. I can't imagine how some of those effects work. I LOVED the new characters of Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy. They were totally believable and fun. The old friends of Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny, and Draco were not nearly as well done. I thought they strayed from the characters that Rowling drew. Of course, a lot would depend on an actor's interpretation of that character and their chemistry with the other characters. The premise of the story was fun and believable within that world. However, the dialogue kind of had a "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" vibe to it. My take on it? I'm fussed that I spent $30 on the book. Wait for the paperback, borrow it from a friend or the library or buy it in a used book store. But if the play comes anywhere near here, I'm GOING.

author: Lena Carino
title: I've come to really like it and appreciate it for what it was
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child... Where to begin...
Just know, I always have been and always will be an avid Harry Potter lover, supporter, fan. I grew up with the books, went to all the midnight premieres, watched all the movies a million times over, did it all.
At first, I was really reluctant to read it; I was more so nervous than anything because the standard that the original series had set was really high in my mind. But reading it with an open mind, I've come to really like it and appreciate it for what it was. it's own separate thing.

I will admit, there are many flaws; it's not perfect. The plot line near the end was a little predictable, and the twists were surprising in a very corny kind of way. I knew the dynamic was going to be different because they're older, their lives are different, everything is different.

But a big thing that I loved about the original Harry Potter series was there: the development of friendships and relationships, sometimes even between unlikely people. For here, especially between unlikely people. It also gave me the opportunity of getting a glimpse (however small) into their lives after. Bringing all that in, with all of these characters I've loved for all these years, I liked it. Didn't super "LOVE" it, or thought it was incredibly amazing. Just...liked it. Still would recommend it.

author: CPTROG
title: Not book 8
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
Although I was initially thrilled about the book, after reading it I'm only happy to have experienced the old rush of getting the next HP book. We have raised our kids on the books and have made it a family love.
I knew going in that a play is not a novel, that being said, my wife and I just didn't like the characters that we once loved. Ron was a shell with none of his personality from 1-7, Harry was kind of bipolar, Hermione was unpleasant, Draco was all over the place...it just felt like someone messed up the personalities of our characters. It did feel like JK Rowling wrote this story, and she's who made us fall in love with all the characters.
All in all it's not bad, but it's not book 8.

author: Dikgang Kekana
title: The magic flickers in 'Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content:
In the documentary 'J K Rowling: A Year in the Life', the author of the wildly popular 'Harry Potter' series says something becomes true for her only once she writes it down. Upon reflection, I’ve found that this was also true for me: I always avoided fan-fiction stories based on the second generation of characters because there was no canon that recorded their dimensions from which my imagination could proceed; it felt fraudulent from the first, a misgiving that entirely missed the irony that I write stories based in a universe created by another writer.

Luckily a Clean Sweep has swept away all such concerns from my head and burnished the mantle previously occupied by what we, and Rowling presumably, thought was the last instalment of the franchise. In its place stands the brand-new eighth book, a script adaptation of a play of the same name, 'Harry Potter and the Cursed Child'. When Rowling hinted in a 2010 interview with Oprah that an eighth book was possible, I dared not believe her. But here it is.

'Cursed Child' picks up the story 19 years later from King’s Cross, where Harry and his wife Ginny drop off their wizards- and witch-in-training, Albus Severus Potter, James Potter and Lily Potter. Aboard the Hogwarts Express Albus meets the spawn of his father’s childhood enemy, Scorpius Malfoy, who feels just as trapped by his family legacy as Albus does, and they become fast friends. Together they travel far and wide in both time and space to right the wrongs of the past and liberate themselves from it.

Without spoiling it (at least not too much), here are my owl droppings about the story.

Ginny is a broomstick wife—or rather a Shooting Star

Any first-year would tell you that the Shooting Star is the lowliest of brooms (but wouldn’t go as far as to scoff at one, for many of them would have never been on a broom before, so any would do). It’s standard issue and clocks a measly speed. Ginny’s performance as a character is not much better: she disappears into the wall even as she shares the scene with Harry and vaguely resurfaces to mutter empty platitudes of encouragement to him. She’s a husk of the fiery redhead we saw in 'Half-Blood Prince'—even in 'Chamber of Secrets' when she was distracted and possessed for most of the book. It’s a faded rendering that does not do the character justice. But as this is the first script I have ever read, perhaps I’m missing the point that this format might necessitate such sacrifices.

Her brother, Ron, is equally diminished in character, getting very little  productive stage time. James and Lily appear in three scenes each at most in the entire story. But beyond that the colour returns. If you thought Harry was irascible and too quick to act, Albus is in a Quidditch league of his own; Scorpius barely has enough time to pull away from a hug (yes, Scorpius is strangely hug-happy in this story, which stirred my suspicion that something little more than a friendship was afoot here) before Albus grabs him by the arm and plunges them into another rabbit hole.

Harry has a rich character arch. As he contorts himself with guilt and fatherly concern before his son, who keeps testing him, we are reminded of the evolving mental state of a young boy who had to grow up very fast in a foreign world and in the cross hairs of a tenacious terrorist. We enjoy a refreshing insight into what goes through Harry’s head as he tries to build a firm foundation of trust and affection with his youngest. The same tension takes place between Draco and Scorpius, though, of course, to a diminished extent (who has time for all these finicky emotions when there is an empire to build?)

At last we get the measure of our favourite wizards and witches, and, as judges do with the strata of precedents in common law, we can interpret their actions through all manner of scenarios in our fanfiction stories. Finally the ink from my pen can flow.

Time-Turner as predictable as sands in an hourglass

As you may have surmised from the blaring hint above, the Time-Turner features heavily in the story, which was rather predictable. But if I could give myself a pass on this cliché as a fanfic writer, surely I could deign to extend the same courtesy to the mother of the 'Harry Potter' universe. So I move that by the order of the Wizengamot, the charges against her are dismissed. Although, naturally stories that involve time travel tend to have some pretty convenient bends, so be prepared to roll your eyes here and there.

The deferred dreams of fathers

Just as the death of Rowling’s mother leaps from every page in the previous seven books, so does her complicated relationship with her father in every page of 'Cursed Child'. Albus and Harry size each other up, and Draco at first has just enough time to give his only child a once-over, which is much more than Voldemort would ever care to give… I myself have spent a mere 14 minutes in the presence of my biological father, which I suspect is why I cherish the bond between Harry and Dumbledore so deeply that it, too, bleeds on every page of my fanfiction efforts. Gees—how many of us have daddy issues?

An unexceptionable to good story

The story has a few twists and turns, most of which you see coming a mile away. But I think we should keep in mind that it is meant to be shown, not read, so the obvious must scream and the subtle at least harrumph. I lapped up everything that told us something about the second-generation characters, who include Ron and Hermione’s children, Rose and Hugo Granger-Weasley (What, you thought Hermione would offer to drop her family name? Have you read her?) Its most compelling feature and through line is the relationship between Albus and Harry.

'Harry Potter and the Cursed Child' is a worthy if lukewarm addition to the magical universe. Now that we’ve broken the drought of entertainment that began after the release of the eighth and final movie, we can finally hope for a 'Harry Potter' television show that would Reducto! all traces of 'Wizards of Waverly Place' from the face of the Earth, retired as it is. If Merlin has any mercy.

([...])

content: This book was a total disappointment. I was hoping for the splendor that was Harry Potter but it really felt like it was revisiting the past adventures of Harry, Ron and Hermoine. There was no new adventure and the plot was dishearteningly simple. Maybe the actual play is better.

author: AmazonCustomer01

content: This is an interesting book to say the least. It is great to finally have an addition to the story we all know and love, but it is clearly not an award-winning book. Again, though I am extremely happy to have an addition to the series, I just can't get over the trolley lady on the Hogwarts Express using pumpkin pasties as explosives and practicaly being immortal.

author: Michael
title: Worth the read but not something you'll fall in love with
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: Overall, I enjoyed the read.  It was quick and kept my interest.  However, this does not compare to any of the novels in the series and you should definitely lower your expectations if you expect it to.  If you're a die hard Harry Potter fan, you should definitely read it.

author: Anonymitea
title: Not really Harry Potter, but an ok read...

content: This felt more like fan fiction than a real Harry Potter book. The characters were all pretty poorly developed and the dialogue felt forced at several points. Main characters from the older books (Harry, Ron, Hermione, etc.) also felt completely different and way more flawed/wimpy than their old selves. It is an easy read though and does trigger a bit of nostalgia, so I will allow it 3 stars.

My #1 problem is that hermione is gone. Not from the movies but the books. She is a smart "funny when wants to be girl" and she has a slight bit of a joker twinkle in her eyes.

ALLL OOF THAAT ISS GOONE!!!!!!

One more thing.... Time travel has been done to death. Seriously. The whole "if you do something in the past it will efect the future" thing. content: I would of liked it better as a book (instead of a script) with more description and details so it was richer and lasted longer (and written by Rowling), but I really enjoyed the story.  It felt like it belonged in the same world and with the same characters.

author: Cynthia Lynne Mobley
title: It was okay.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2016
content: I am a big Harry Potter fan but this was so far out there plot wise that I didn't finish it. The writing was so-so.

author: Russell Fellows
title: I WILL TRY MY BEST TO NOT INCLUDE SPOILERS
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2018
content:
WARNING: THE FOLLOWING MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS. I WILL TRY MY BEST TO NOT INCLUDE SPOILERS, BUT THAT MAY NOT BE POSSIBLE. IF THAT DOES NOT BOTHER YOU, PLEASE READ ON. IF IT DOES, BY ALL MEANS GO READ THE BOOK, THEN COME BACK HERE.

Synopsis:

The story, play, begins where Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows ended (in its epilogue). 19 years have passed, and a new generation of Hogwarts students make their way to the Hogwarts Express. This time, it is Harry and Ginny's middle child, Albus Severus, that begins his first year.

When Albus arrives at Hogwarts, he finds everyone is excited about his arrival. Another Potter, another child of the famous Harry Potter. He soon finds that living under the shadow of his famous dad is more pressure than he can handle. He grows to resent his dad, prove that he wasn't the hero everyone thinks, and maybe right a wrong that Harry committed so many years ago. Will doing so prove that he is worthy to be the child of the famous Harry Potter?

Along the way, Albus makes a couple of friends. The unlikely pairing of Scorpius Malfoy, son of Harry's old nemesis Draco, is frowned upon by all. And, the mysterious Delphi. Who is she? Is she the answer to all of Albus's questions?

Follow Albus and Scorpius as they try to navigate the sons of fathers with heavy pasts and make names for themselves. Join Harry and the old gang as they try to grapple with ominous happenings while figuring out what the children are up to. The whole world hangs in the balance.

(I understand that isn't the greatest of synopses, but I'm trying to keep out spoilers while not copying the synopsis from amazon or others. :) )

What I liked:

I am a huge Harry Potter fan. I loved the books, enjoyed the movies (they could have done better, but they were still enjoyable). To get the chance to join my favorite characters in another adventure was irresistible.

I love the plot - original and engaging. It is a slow start, but once we start in on the action, it keeps you turning pages to find out what happens next.

I would love to see this performed on the state - it's an element that cannot be ignored for this story. Obviously the book is the script and so it does not have the brilliant prose of Rowling's originals, but it is engrossing.

It is a story that will have you smiling at the end for the sheer pleasure of one more adventure.

What I didn't like:

The character development was the weakest point, I believe, of the whole story. I suppose they sacrificed a lot for the time constraints of a play, but I think they could have spent more effort on each character. Many were two dimensional. The whole of the story focuses on Albus, Scorpius, Harry, and Draco. Even the four of them lacked in development, though they fared far better than anyone else in the story. Sometimes, you're left to wonder where others are - surely they are around, though there is nary a mention save in passing.

And I absolutely hate how Ron is portrayed. Sorry, he's not always had the best of it in the original books, either, but here he is just pathetic.

The plot is predictable. Of course, so were many of the books. That isn't its weakest point, but one I think could have done with a boost of a good twist.

The climax wasn't entirely satisfying. It felt rushed and too clean/abrupt when there was so much build for something far more spectacular. It gave me a "well, yeah, but..." feeling when it was all said and done.

Conclusion

To see the actual production would probably make up for many of the short falls I find in here - the wows would probably make me forget the lack of characters.

I loved going on a new adventure, and learning about new characters - and even delving into thoughts and motivations of old ones.

I just wish it wasn't so rushed. Maybe that is the main problem with the whole of it - it was rushed. It reads much like a fan fiction piece that someone decided to put on the stage. It's good, but not great.

My biggest disappointment: That this will be the last that JK Rowling will delve into Harry's life. Not the last into the wizarding world, but into Harry's life.

Farewell, Harry. It has been a pleasure.

author: Mo
title: Disappointed actually! I expected more character build for Harry's ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2016
content:
Disappointed actually!

I expected more character build for Harry's children, as well as Ron & Hermione's children...I found the story to be predictable without any new twist or adventures, that long awaited fans were expecting.

I am aware it was written for the stage, but it doesn't mean more development could not have been provided!

I am a fan of J.K Rowling, and will continue to purchase other writings, but I just wanted to be honest, about this project

author: S. Taylor
title: Good plot, distracting formatting
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
It was wonderful to see the Harry Potter characters come to life. They were as charming as ever and the plot they were placed in was quite good. It feels churlish to say this because I knew that it was a script format going in, but format nonetheless made the story feel two-dimensional.  It was simply flat, without the richness of detail which made the original Harry Potter stories so extraordinary.

Still, it's Harry Potter, so well worth the read. I hope to see the play one day--the visuals should help to give the story depth.

author: Busy Bee
title: Hard to read in play format and left me feeling a little flat
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2016
content:
Hmm, I really hate to give JK and company just three stars, but that's how this book/play left me feeling - just kinda "meh." True, the Harry Potter series is an extremely tough act to follow. But rabid fans were clamoring for another taste of Potterdom and most will never have the opportunity to see the stage production in person. So, for that purpose, this was a nice offering - and a fabulously smart move. Because this little sip of our favorite wizarding world has no doubt increased anticipation for the upcoming film "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" exponentially. I know I can't wait to see it!

But reading "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" just didn't make me feel like I was getting a taste of the stage experience; instead, I felt like I was reading the working outline of Rowling's next big series. (And perhaps it actually is...wouldn't that be cheeky? :D ) In any case, I really wanted more...more character development, more backstory, more action, more dialogue. Seven books' worth more. C'mon, Jo, it will only take five (okay, maybe more) years of your life to write a new series. Is that really too much to ask? ;)

author: Amazoncustomer
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2016
content: Disappointed

author: Hal C. Elrod
title: A rousing "meh"
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is interesting if you are a die-hard HP Completest. The trio of authors kill suspense and damage the literary universe with a dopey time travel plot. Whoops - gave away the book [reminder: put "spoiler" at top of essay]. It's probably adequate as a play, as one can almost picture the special effects. But don't expect a real Harry Potter book.

author: Jean Farmer
title: I enjoyed it but it was a little weird too
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
*** Little Spoilery But Not Too Spoilery ***

The Pottercast podcast once started a verbal story series that focused on the kids and what they did at school 19 years later, including Scorpius. I hate to admit it but that one captured the characters better I think.  I am a huge Potter fan. I’m a huge Rowling fan.  I enjoyed the screen play for what it was, but I found some of the characterizations a little odd. Specifically, Harry and Ginny were odd to me.  Ginny is pissed because Albus is struggling to relate to people and Harry isn’t connecting with him properly to help Albus because Harry’s always at work. Well for one, why can’t GINNY connect with Albus? She’s his mother after all, she can reach out to him too. Secondly, the kids are at school for most of the year and only home for a few months in the summer. Harry, who only ever wanted to have a family, wouldn’t make sure to spend quality time with his kids when they were home for the holidays? That doesn’t sound like the Harry we’ve known.  Part of that I actually found interesting though, Harry struggling to connect with Albus was interesting in some ways because Harry isn’t perfect and you see how human he is in the story. However, there are parts where it’s just over the top. Him spending a specific day with a blanket each year is just freaking weird. The Trolley Lady on the Hogwarts Train was super weird. Who really shines in this book is Scorpius and Draco. Draco is more adult than Harry in a lot of ways and Scorpius is just a really great kid who would never have been put in Slytherin because he’s a sweet kid all around. He’s the real star of the show for me in this book. Scorpius is who saves the day really in so many ways. In fact, I’m not entirely sure he’s not the cursed child in some ways.  Oh, and I’m glad I’m not the only one who totally thought Albus and Scorpius had a thing for each other. I’m glad a few other reviewers mentioned it too. I was sad they didn’t end up being together, it would have made more sense and would have been pretty cute.

So as a fan, yes I think you should give it a try. It is different. It’s not what you expect. It is interesting to see them all as adults and to be excited about who turns out to be Minister of Magic. I enjoyed it but I did find some of the aspects of it odd.

author: Uyen Anh Nguyen
title: ... not what I expected although story and plot were good.

content: Play dialogue format was not what I expected although story and plot were good.

author: Mateo Urquizo
title: An average but entertaining adventure
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2017
content:
Fun and entertaining. Also a very detailed and imaginative screenplay. But I miss the more detailed description of the novels.
Furthermore, I find that in the effort of making Harry Potter more of an adult, he's became a less interesting character and instead transformed himself into one of those gray and shallow adults of the wizarding world.
Finally, the book's name is misleading since Harry Potter plays a secondary role in this adventure.

author: Taikun
title: Not Great, Not that Good, But (Somewhat) Salvable
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
This script has brought me a lot of mixed feelings. As many of you, I've been a HP fan for as long as I can remember, reading the books multiple times a year throughout elementary until high school. In fact, if memory serves me well, I was a fifth grader when I first became a fan and now I'm in grad school. Harry Potter is not just another series I've enjoyed, it's an inherent part of my childhood and teenage years that I cherish to this day.

Nevertheless, I've always been a critical fan of Rowling and I've criticized her whenever I think it was fit, instead of glorifying every decision she makes, regardless of how awesome of a writer she is. Now, I tried to judge this book—script—for what it is, a play, not a novel, and that's fine.

SPOILER LAND!

::::What I wish was different::::

1)  I was not expecting much character development or vivid descriptions because of the format and I can live with that. However, what makes me feel uneasy is that, the more I kept reading, the more it felt like a fan fiction rather than a genuine HP story. I don't know how much involved Rowling was in this work (from what I hear, she wasn't very much involved in the writing aspect), but it is difficult not to see this work as a glorified fan fiction at times. Harry is sort of a jerk at times, Ron is more laid back than ever, Hermione seems rather clumsy at times—it is just odd. Like it doesn’t fit quite well entirely with the foundation set by the books. I understand the concept of change. I'm not the same person I used to be when I was 17 years old, so I don't expect the famous trio, for instance, to be just as they were now that they are 40. But at the same time, as we change there is continuation and, at times, I think that continuation is lost in the play. I can see how Harry could be a jerk with Albus—not having a true parental figure himself and just being frustrated with his kid, but the fact that he even threatened McGonagall (someone who stood up for him at critical times in the past) seems way out of character. Ron, likewise, was sooo laid back and almost completely irrelevant with his commentaries; it just doesn’t truly resembles him, given that although he was kind of laid back in the books, he took seriously what was serious. The same goes with Hermione, if anything, I’d expected her to be even more cautious and clever than ever. This is the girl who devised a system of secrecy around the D.A. and even a contingency plan in case of having a snitch. But somehow, she didn’t put much thought on hiding an overpowered magical object capable of changing the whole world.

2) The sole fact that Voldemort had a daughter seems odd and counter intuitive. As many have pointed out, Voldemort was a very unilateral character, basically obsessed with power and power alone and the idea of him reproducing himself—between the 6th and the 7th book, while his mind was completely occupied in waging a war—just seems odd for that kind of character. What was the point of  such idea when you think you’re going to live forever and specially when you’re so self-centered you want the whole world for yourself? And of course, is not like Bellatrix ever had a belly—but then again you can make everything look less “Deux Ex Machina”  with magic.

3) The fact that Scorpius and Albus are best friends, is cool, I even like the idea, but they don't act like typical best friends. I mean, take a look at Harry and Ron. Throughout 7 novels they did not express their affection to each other as Albus and Scorpius did in just one book (a script, nonetheless). That is just odd. C.S. Lewis, reflecting on the idea of friendship noted in “The Four Loves” that “Lovers are always talking to one another about their love; Friends hardly ever about their Friendship. Lovers are normally face to face, absorbed in each other; Friends, side by side, absorbed in some common interest.” It is for that reason their friendship looks unrealistic. What I loved about the friendship of Harry, Ron and Hermione was not the expression of affection and loyalty, but its demonstration. They didn’t spend much time expressing their feelings about their friendship, they showed it day in and day out. That’s what made me think as a boy: “Wow! I want friends like that! I want to be that kind of friend!” But the friendship of Albus and Scorpius is cheesy, overly-expressed and quite unrealistic.

4) The whole plot revolving around this glorified Time Turner was odd as well. In most readers' minds this aspect is probably the very thing that makes everyone think this is poorly written fan fiction. It's like the whole plot was a magical Back To The Future—and that's not a good thing. I mean, after all, Rowling did spent quite a bit of time trying to tight the potential plot hole the very existence of a Time Turner could create—and now there are in existence more powerful Time Turners capable of changing the past and the future in matters of seconds. Even if all of such glorified Time Turners are destroyed, who’s going to stop a skillful wizard from figuring out how to make another?  In my opinion, the very possibility of creating one of these Time Turners breaks the balance Rowling sought to create between what is possible and what is not possible to do with magic. In addition, I think that the events that they revisited in the past are going to be stained by this joke, Now Scorpius and Albus are going to be in the back of our heads when we revisit the TWT and, quite frankly, it just ruined it.

5 )The ABSOLUTE WORST of all, in my opinion, was the Trolley Witch. Oh, my goodness! This—above everything else—is what makes the script look like (bad) fan fiction. To start with, it looks that somehow this witch has been working at the Hogwarts Express since 1830, making her over 200—maybe 300—years old. This witch is even older than Dumbledore ever was. It just defies explanation. On top of that, she is able to turn Pumpkin Pasties into grenades and transfigure her hands into claws. Oh, and she also doesn’t even remember her name, yet is able to do presumably complex spells. While in the HP universe such things sound certainly plausible, it doesn’t stop from sounding ridiculous.  Again, it just sounds like bad fan fiction.

::::What I loved:::

1) Snape. In my own judgement, Snape looked true to his character for the most part, even adjusting for some changes in personalities due to time and life experiences. His battle against the dementors was memorable and, not only that, I loved the idea that somewhere—somehow, Snape was able to know what happened in the future, how Harry forgave him and started to admire him and how he honored him by naming one of his children after him. That was moving.

2) Scorpius. Albus who? Albus, is a walking cliché of a character. He is the typical son living under the shadow of his father that has something to prove to the world. Nothing out of the ordinary. But Scorpius, in a sense, is not only the real hero of the story, he is his own persona, he is funny, witty and quite different from his father. Without him, I don’t think I would have enjoyed this script almost at all.

All in all, I still gave it 3 stars because the script was fun to read (for the most part)  and kept me wanting to know what was going to happen next. Nevertheless, I am disappointed about the overall plot line, how the characters were portrayed and how unnecessary and childish some aspects of it were. Sadly, I cannot help but to conclude that this script did not meet the expectations I had.

author: Beau Yarbrough
title: A story better told in a novel or on a movie screen, not as a theater script
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2016
content:
It's a strange choice for the publishers to label this as "Harry Potter #8," including on the actual dust jacket. That sets up unfair and unreasonable expectations.

This is, of course, a stage play, which Rowling only had a hand in creating. As a result, it's missing a lot of the world building and internal dialogue she includes in her novels, making the whole thing seem thin when compared to the previous seven stories.

Taken, not as a novel, but as a script it's OK. There's definite heart there and Albus and Scorpius in particular are charming characters. But Harry Potter stories rely a great deal on things that don't translate great to the stage and not at all to the script book. The recent news that Warner Brothers was looking at turning this into up to three movies is, for once, actually pretty good news, as the spectacle that doesn't translate well as a script will work perfectly on the screen and the additional time will hopefully flesh out some of the parts that feel rather thin as-is.

This is worth reading for Harry Potter fans, but they should go in expecting something much less than previous Potter works.

author: ashcat1014
title: Bollocks, That Was Bad...
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Like many in the Harry Potter community I was super excited to read The Cursed Child. I don't know about anyone else but I had flashbacks to original Potter day. I was pumped! I had my wand and robes at the ready as I paged through a fresh copy.

I was left so disappointed...and confused.

I knew going in that this was going to read like a screen play so I wasn't distracted by the formatting. What left me scratching my head was the continual mischaracterization of Harry. Who was this character? Also, I got so distracted by the contrasts of the characters during the parts of the story which were dictated by the time turner.

Yes, I thought that plot line was cliche but it truly didn't bother me. I just with it had been built upon more substanciously.

I thought Scorpio's character was fantastic...he was probably my favorite part of this entire book.

I would consider this a must-read for Harry Potter fans but go in knowing it's not nearly as magical and books 1-7. I also caught at least three editing mistakes/grammatical errors which still stands out to me.

I have a lot of love for this franchise and communkty, but...what did we just read?

author: Shellbell
title: Hard to get into
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I was happy that I read this book but the play form was difficult to get into. I think that many people would find it much easier to understand in book form.

author: Jarrod
title: Good, but not great
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: Harry Potter was my childhood. Every summer since 5th grade, I would read the series in anticipation for the next film or book release. Ultimately, I believe that I read the series roughly 8 times. When I learned that a new book would be coming out, I was ecstatic. I had no idea what to expect, but I was, unfortunately, let down. While J.K. Rowling's wonderful writing ability is evident in the story, there is not enough story to the book. Personally, I finished it in roughly two hours, and I left filled with disappointment. I wanted to know more and be immersed in the Wizarding World in England, and all I got was a teaser of what I once knew.

author: Amazon Customer
title: there were some really nice things in the script like starting off where the ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: I grew up reading Harry Potter and the series is still one of my favorites to this day. Needless to say, I was very excited to read about Harry Potter and the Cursed Child after so many years with out anything new about Harry. While, there were some really nice things in the script like starting off where the 7th book left off, it is still just a script. This is not the 8th book that Scholastic heavily advertised but it is only a script. It lacks the character and story development that J.K. Rowling exhibited in the original books. While, I believe that the play will be excellent reading the script was disappointing. It was just a shell of what the Harry Potter novels achieved.
