author: JacquelineESmith
title: * Even though I do love it because
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
I have finally decided how to describe my feelings toward this play.

* BE CAREFUL! POSSIBLE SPOILERS! AND ID ON'T KNOW HOW TO MARK IT AS SUCH! *

* I'll admit I'm a little mad that the writers and publisher let us all believe that JK Rowling was the one who wrote the script when, in fact, it was the other two guys. That's deceptive and not very fair to fans, especially when they know fans will pay literally anything to get more of Harry Potter even if they can't necessarily afford it.

* Even though I do love it because, well, Harry Potter, I cannot bring myself to accept this script as canon. I've been having a bit of a hard time coming up with a way to make it okay with my brain that yes, I've read it… No, I won't forget it… How can I live knowing that this play exists and that these books exist, supposedly in the same universe, without actually accepting that this IS the continuation of Harry Potter's story. THIS IS what was going on throughout the fourth book. And then it finally hit me.

* I'm a big fan of The Princess Diaries, both the books and the movies. However, they are drastically different. I accept the books as canon. The movies, as delightful as they are, are nowhere near as good as the books. And Mia doesn't end up with Michael in the second movie. No. That's just wrong.

* Then I remembered that in the books, Mia actually mentions the movies! She calls them "the movies based on my life." She's also disappointed that she doesn't end up with Michael in the second one, even though she claims that the new guy is a total babe. Which he is. That got me thinking. I can trick my brain into believing that this play is kind of a play "based on the story of Harry Potter's kid's life." Very loosely, that is. In fact, a fictionalized version of it altogether.

* I know this sounds a bit crazy, but this is important to me. I can imagine that, in my canon world, Harry and Ginny and the rest of the gang are fully aware of this play's existence. It's a play that they enjoy. I'm certain that it's absolutely stunning on stage. But, much like the Princess Diaries movies, it is hardly based on reality. There are no Time Turners. There is no secret Dark Lord love child. Harry did not go back in time to watch the events of October 31, 1981. Come on. That's just straight out of some kind of fan fiction. But it is an emotional idea.

* So, that's how I am reconciling the existence of both the books and the play. The books are canon. The play is not, but it is loosely based on the story of Harry Potter and Albus Potter's lives.

* I do accept that Albus and Scorpius are best friends, however, and that Scorpius is an adorable little nerd. I can totally see that.

author: LDH
title: it wasn't what I hoped for
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Unfortunately, this didn't come close to my Harry Potter expectations. I suppose I was hoping it would be an entirely new story, not one that used previous books and experiences over and over again to keep a story alive. Not to mention, I extremely disliked that it quickly skimmed over Albus' first several school years. If I were to have read this without the expectations of a Harry Potter quality story, I probably would have liked this more. Again it is a screen play, so it reads much different than a novel and surprisingly that part very minimally bothered me. But due to this, it wasn't nearly as descriptive as I would have wished. I honestly only gave it 3 stars because I was happy to read more stories about Harry Potter and his gang. But I didn't much care for the story at all.

author: Stephanie Messenger
title: Good, but not Amazing
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2016
content: I am a huge Harry Potter fan, so I pre-ordered this the day it became available to do so. I stayed up to read on my Kindle as soon as it was released. I was so excited for the next chapter! However, I was rather disappointed. I knew it was written in "play format" and would not be in a regular format, so that played no part in my feelings on it. The story itself was interesting, however I will echo others who have said that it seemed more to be a FanFiction. The story itself was interesting but it seemed to jump around almost too quickly. I know that this is meant as a play but it still was disappointing to not get to delve deeper into the new characters. Overall, it was a good read, but perhaps it would be better to see in it's intended format.

author: S. ALD
title: Disappointing...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I was sadly disappointed by this book. Like everyone else I grew up reading this series and was excited. it is a quick read the the script format didn't distract in any way. Unfortunately, the storyline seems oversimplified and forced. The complexity of characters and story that we have come to love is missing.

Is it the worst thing I've ever read? Not by a long shot, but if you can resist, I would avoid adding it to your current "untainted" view of the potter world and JK Rowling's work. It doesn't do either justice.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2017
content: not what I expected

author: agabrielle
title: Nothing special, but entertaining all the same.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Look, if you're a true HP fan you're going to like it and bear through the difficult parts no matter what (with Jim Dale's voice going through your mind at the same time). This is our last piece into the Wizarding World. Truthfully, it's just OK. Nothing completely special, you can see where the story is heading early in the second act, but you will muster through because you are a fan. It is a bit confusing to read, I don't know it may just be because I am reading it on my kindle, but having the lines listed out by name and the constant jumping around makes your head spin. I had an open mind coming into this and of course there are many things I would have liked to change, but with a shrug of the shoulders I will add it to my HP collection and probably read it again and again just to get a better grasp of what is going on. Maybe by the third time I read it I will understand and enjoy it more. Overall I'm indifferent. Good pool read.

author: James F. Lawson
title: Tinme Travel
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2016
content:
When a new Harry Potter book appeared I jumped on it.  Set somewhat in the future as Albus is leaving for his first year at Hogwarts.  On the train he meets Scorpius Malfoy. author: Steven K. Piper
title: Realistic Expectations
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
If you're expecting an authentic continuation of the beloved Harry Potter series, then turn back now. If you're properly prepared to read a script of a play that includes some of our childhood heroes, then by all means: read on. All along JK Rowling and the makers of The Cursed Child have been upfront and honest about what this story is, but unfortunately some of us cannot help but hope for an eighth installment of our favorite story. I do believe that this story contains less character development and magic than the Harry Potter series - but how can it not when we are not reading a narrative, but only learning about these characters through the words and minimal stage direction? The first part of the story read similar to a bad fanfiction project - forced plot lines, cheesy recollections and inside jokes, and a painful attempt to bring us back into the wizarding world. The character relationships were awkward and inauthentic and the overall mood of the story was very immature and not well thought out. Around halfway through the book however, we begin to understand the characters and their motives. We begin to understand the complex plot points that felt so forced, and we are forced to relive some of the trauma from the series.

These alternate realities give us insight into the significance of each character in the series, and how the slightest change in history could forever change the wizarding world. The plot, very focused on two small specific aspects of the intricate Harry Potter series (time turners and Cedric Diggory - of all things to zero in on...) suddenly becomes relatable and more familiar to those of us who followed Harry, Ron, and Hermione into unfathomable situations throughout their Hogwarts years.

All in all, I believe the script leaves out so much character development, the complex emotions, and the feeling of familiarity - but is well worth the read for those of us too poor to see the play. Yes, it may be disappointing to some of us, but we can never expect to truly relive those midnight releases of the next HP book, or that feeling of knowing the fate of Dumbledore before the rest of our peers because we stayed up reading the night the book came out. If you approach The Cursed Child with realistic expectations, I believe you will enjoy yourself. Any glimpse into the wizarding world is well worth a couple hours of my life, no matter what.

author: LJ
title: Great live production, but disappointing read!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content:
Yikes. I'm honestly not quite sure how to digest this one. Let me preface by saying that I was fortunate enough to see the Cursed Child play on London's West End last week and it was magnificent! Sam Clemmett, Alex Price, and particularly Anthony Boyle did a fantastic job portraying Albus, Draco, and Scorpius respectively. If you get the chance to see the play, you will not regret it. The actors wonderfully bring what is an otherwise bland script to life and make it one of the more enjoyable and engaging live productions that I've seen.

With that said- make no mistake about it, this play was quite clearly not written by JK Rowling or even in the tone that she set throughout the seven books. Harry, Hermione, and Ron (especially Ron!) almost seemed foreign to me. Ron's character is written in such a pathetic manner that it almost makes it unbelievable that someone like Hermione would be married to him. The play leaves you thinking that he has become a man of little to no substance as his character is inserted minimally and primarily as a source of comic relief.

[MAJOR SPOILER ALERT] Aside from the integrity of the characters being compromised, the play also leaves some glaring plot holes; the most prominent one being Bellatrix Lestrange's pregnancy. The playwrights expect us to accept that Bellatrix Lestrange gave birth to Voldemort's child at Malfoy Manor prior to the Battle of Hogwarts. Wouldn't Rowling have left some hint of Lestrange's pregnancy in Book 7? If the child was born before the Battle of Hogwarts, wouldn't Voldemort have found some way to use the child to his advantage; especially because at this point he knew Harry was on a quest to destroy his horcruxes? Wouldn't Voldemort have done something desperate with the child knowing almost certainly there was no way that Harry Potter could ever destroy a baby, and thus never destroy him? I don't know-- it just seems too far out from the original story line for me. Voldemort's character in the books was desperate for immortality and power. Based on what we know of him, all signs point to the idea that he would have used that child in an act of desperation or selfishness to quench his thirst for these two things. Marring what was a marvelously crafted fiction series with baby drama seemed rather unnecessary to me. There are so many different directions they could have gone with for a sequel and this "who's your daddy" option was a little too soap opera-y for me.

Although the premise of the play was Albus' struggles with living in his father's shadow and how that affected their relationship, there were too many inconsistencies throughout the play that distracted from this theme. However, Scorpius both on stage and in text was a delight! I would say that his character was probably one of the highlights of the play. Overall, I thought it was a weak follow-up to an epic series. If you read and accept it as something that was intended for the stage and somewhat disconnect yourself from the 7 books, then it's OK. As someone that has been enamored with the HP series since it was first released, I found the play to be underdeveloped and somewhat disappointing. It is definitely worth seeing on stage, but reading it as a standalone makes me wish Rowling would release an eighth book to clear up some of the inconsistencies and reestablish the magical world that we all grew up with and loved. Of course I would recommend reading it, but do so with an open mind.

author: Kristen Burns
title: Great Ideas, Didn't Reach Its Potential
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2018
content:
I was originally not interested in this story, but then I reread the Harry Potter series again and couldn't resist giving it a try. I feel like I don't have as extreme an opinion about this as many people do though.

I love the idea of Harry's son and Draco's son being best friends (or maybe even something more, if you ship them, as I do). I even like the idea of Harry and Draco getting over some of their animosity toward each other, of Harry's son not being what everyone expected, and of the father-son issues between Harry and Albus and between Draco and Scorpius.

However, As much as I liked the ideas of all the things above, I don't think they were executed well. Everything was so dramatic and mushy. It was basically just, "Look at how wonderful and caring and misunderstood Snape and Draco actually are!" and heart-to-heart moments between Harry and Draco, and a bunch of unrealistic, forced conversations about friendship and father-son issues. No 11-year-old immediately tells another 11-year-old they've just met that they have father-son issues. Is this just how plays are? Since there isn't information about emotions, the characters just speak all their innermost thoughts and feeling and struggles, even when it's not believable to do so? Also, everything Scorpius said sounded like a Tumblr post (e.g. "Oh my, that’s her. Wow. Squeak. My geekness is a-quivering." <-- that's an actual quote), which was funny but, again, not believable. So yeah, the dialogue was unrealistic, and the characters from the original series seemed out-of-character sometimes.

Also, the time travel aspect didn't work for me. It seemed like it had a lot of plot holes and logic flaws, as time travel usually does in stories. The story itself had some issues too. Like, how did Albus and Scorpius manage to get to the blanket that was wrapped around baby Harry, in order to put the potion stuff on it to send the message to older Harry, without Lily or James noticing them?

Then there was the whole, well, twist, let's call it. Honestly, I don't really feel much either way about it. [Hidden spoiler can be found in my review on my blog or Goodreads.]

I can tell you what I do have strong feelings about though: Scorpius and Rose. Why is that even a thing? She was such a jerk to him.

Anyway, I'm not really sure what to think about this overall. It was good to see some nice Slytherins for once, the friendship was sweet, and it was fun being back in the Harry Potter world, but this play did not reach its potential for me. Maybe actually seeing it how it's meant to be seen would've made it more enjoyable? I don't know, but if Rowling were ever to rewrite this as an actual book (which I don't imagine she will, but a girl can dream), I'd give it a try.

Rating: 3 Stars

Original Review @ Metaphors and Moonlight (link in profile)

author: Neurasthenic
title: Not at the level of the original seven books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content:
The first play, in which the characters of Albus and Scorpius are established, worked well for me. However, the second play amounts to so much fan fiction. There's no suspense (there's only one new character, so we know who the "mysterious" secret antagonist must be, and we know the stars must all survive). And this lack of new character points to a larger problem — by restricting this universe-threatening challenge to characters we already know, using magic and artifacts we already know, this play serves to make the Harry Potter universe seem smaller. The resolution of the plot relies on plot devices rather than arising from the characters, which I suppose is fine for children but will children really want to read a two-part script?

My kids have seen the stage play and liked the magic, so perhaps avoid reading the script and just see the show when it inevitably arrives in a theater near you.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I guess it could be worse....
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Mildly entertaining as it brings us back into the Potter world.  That said, be prepared for more disappointment than joy.

Spoilers!!!!!!

A Malfoy and Potter becoming best friends and being outcasts....loved it.
Harrys persona.....not in keeping with the boy who lived over 7 books.
Ron...same old Ron.
Hermione....bland character.
Malfoy....inconsistent personality throughout.
Ginny....same as Hermione but at least a little better.  Provides a solid counter to Harrys sometimes cold and brooding personality.

I was truly excited to read this but any time we have to rely on time travel I become somewhat concerned.  There were portions that I enjoyed and many you others I was left disappointed in.  I say read it as there's very little time commitment and it does add a little to the Potter mythos.  That said, be prepared to be left with a somewhat empty feeling at the end.

title: Good, not the best.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
First of all, when this book was delivered, the cardboard box it came in was not reinforced with tape and was too easy for anyone to get into. Also, the book itself did not come in a plastic cover. It came bare, which is unexpected and unacceptable when delivering a book.

As for the book itself, it's nice and entertaining to a potterhead. However, it is nothing compared to the actual books. Which I expected because Jk Rowling did not write the book, 2 other authors wrote the script based on her ideas. The book is not detailed at all and skips over many years within a mere 10 pages. That being said, it's still a nice book to read for a potter fan.

author: Tim Moreau
title: I enjoyed the latest Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
On a surface level, I enjoyed the latest Harry Potter. It had just enough forward momentum to keep me moving along and the child characters were actually fun to read. Really, it was just a nice excuse to jump into the Harry Potter world again.

But were things that just didn't work. The basic plot was, well, basic. To add to that, the characterization of Ron, Harry, Hermione, and Draco could best be described as spotty. Overall, they feel wrong.

I wish there were stage directions here. It would help with things like building tension or understanding relationships a little better. Body language goes a long way.

All said the book just needed to be an actual novel with drawn out concepts and emotions to match the more serious tone of the later Harry Potter books. They tried, but it just doesn't translate on the page.

*********Spoiler Town Complaints**********

Sure, bring in a descendant of Voldemort. There's potential for an interesting story there where SHE perceives herself as a victim. Maybe we could get some dramatic tension by actually reducing her age (s***, there's so many hints dropped about a kid conceived through time travel there's no reason it couldn't happen) and allowing her to have conflicting emotions and a budding affection for Albus.

So Hermione never noticed that someone broke into her office huh? She didn't see the books strewn everywhere? She didn't have a conversation with her husband about seeing him during the day when he was kissing her and telling her he wanted a baby (which was someone else with polyjuice potion)? Okay.

As much as it hurts, there's too much fan service here. Don't even get me started about Voldemort Day.

Why is Ron suddenly the creepy drunk uncle? And drunk on his wedding day? Come on.

Scorpio being super interested in Rose doesn't come off as genuine.

author: Elizabeth A. Denton
title: Harry Potter & the City on the Edge of Forever
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
First of all, let me say that I did not have a problem with the fact that I was reading a script. I have read lots of scripts.

The problem is with the plot itself, and it's reliance on a device that makes Star Trek fans everywhere groan with dismay. I liked looking at the familiar characters grown into and struggling with (as we all do) the responsibilities of adulthood. I liked the children, particularly Scorpius. I just couldn't get over the repeated use of that plot device. Without it the material had the ability to be fresh.

author: Michael G Flores
title: Did George Lucas write this?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content:
Like other fans of Harry Potter I was excited about this play.  I was also excited that they released the script in book form.  Now I knew going in this was going to be a play script, and not a book.  And after reading it, I think the play would be slightly better as it would have acting and special effects.  But then great acting and special effects can't make up for the writing.

-- SPOILERS --

This clearly wasn't written by J.K. Rowling, and you can tell based on the characters.  But before I begin, I would like to focus on some of the good things from this story.  I really enjoyed the father / son moments between Albus and Harry.  This was in my opinion, one of the few redeeming things from the story.  But the best character by far goes to Scorpius Malfoy.  This character made the story palatable.

So lets talk about some of the things that didn't sit well.  The first was the plot, which was pretty much a weak time traveling plot.  One that would make even the Doctor cringe.  Using a time turner, Albus and Scorpius pretty much mess up time and have to go back and fix it.  This gives us a great opportunity to visit all the old Harry Potter characters, in alternate time lines, but who wants to?  While the nostalgia was nice, I wanted to hear a story about new characters, not just name drop some of the familiar ones.

But even then, I could look away at some of the cheesey parts, and enjoy the few scraps of good story telling, up until Delphi.  Delphi, it turns out, has been manipulating the boys the whole time in order to get them to change time and bring back Lord Voldemort.  Which in itself, is fine, until it is revealed that Delphi is the daughter of Bellatrix and Voldemort and was born just before the Battle of Hogwarts.  This is where it got all George Lucasy for me, and the cheese factor exceeded even levels that I could tolerate.  Ignoring how wrong this idea is, and unlikely, as well as the timing of it (Bellatrix fought pretty well in the Battle of Hogwarts for someone who just had a baby).  I just cannot accept this as cannon.  Delphi could have been a death eater, maybe even the descendant of a famous follower, etc.  But to make her the daughter of Bellatrix and Voldemort was too much for me.  They might as well have had her build C3PO while she was at it.

So for me I am going to take the Scorpius character as being awesome, and the fact Harry is not a perfect father, and flush the rest.  Time to put the book down, and count the days (100) until Fantastic Beasts hits the movie theaters, and hope that J.K. Rowling helped write the movie, will make up for this cursed book.

author: Brian Driver
title: An Enjoyable Play, Though this Version Is Pretty Dry
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
I have two kinds of comments to make here: one set has to do with the VERSION of this play, and one has to do with the play itself. I'll review the version first:

One thing you must understand when it comes to HARRY POTTER AND THE CURSED CHILD: not only is this a play with minimal stage directions, but author J.K. Rowling is NOT the playwright. In fact, Rowling’s writing TEAM only provides the “original story” – the actual play is co-written by John Tiffany and Jack Thorne.

So, is it worth reading?

Ultimately, I’d say yes, though I don't feel this format is wise for those who are either first-time readers or even casual Potter fans. In fact – though I’ve read every book several times and was as captivated on each reading as I was on the first – there were times reading the play I questioned whether I was enjoying myself...that is, to the level of the previous Potter entries.

Now that I’m finished, however, I can truly say I’m glad I read it. And here’s the best news: if the play lives up to the potential displayed here in this text, it is going to be an AMAZING and yes, MAGICAL experience to see it live. (And, from what I’ve read about its opening night in the N.Y. Times, it is.)

I am not really getting into the story here: other reviews and the blurbs above are doing that already. I WILL make the point that pretty much ALL the main players get some stage time, though some are very brief. Even though the play is essentially about the children of Harry and Ginny Potter, and Draco and Astoria Malfoy, its clever plot allows for the presence of the likes of Dumbledore, Snape, and even He Who Must Not Be Named – and all in a very organic, faithful and well-handled manner, without any pandering or falseness.

But here is my recommendation: if you are someone who truly MUST read this play because you can’t stand waiting, then do so. However, if you’re someone who can wait for the version that is rumored to be coming out -- one WITH full stage directions, then do so. Though neither version will be written by Rowling, the stage directions should get across to the reader more of the charm and sophistication of what is taking place on stage. Sure, the dialogue is important, but seeing a story about Potter and Hogwarts WITHOUT getting a sense of the magic that is happening alongside it is sacrilege, and in this version that is what you get. For example, while you find out that a certain incantation is taking place, there is no DEPICTION of it… and without that, you don’t have the spectacle of a Rowling play.

As to the positives and negatives of the play itself, regardless of format, I thought that the play must be extremely strong to see...though the real tension for me took a while to develop. It seemed strange for me to see Harry be such an inadequate father when it came to rearing and reassuring Albus. I was surprised that Harry found it so difficult to say the simple words thaat would have helped so much, and it was equally odd to to see Ginny be so reluctant to guide him in the right direction. But no one is perfect, and the Potter series is predicated upon the concept that a hero isn't someone who does everything right ALL the time. One learns, often by his (or her) mistakes.

What really bothered me was how certain key players were held to a minimum. Ron has a really small part here -- MUCH smaller than I expected, and he was more of a buffoon than a real player of consequence. In his stead, Draco Malfoy really earned a

But I was really surprised by what a poor showing Dumbledore had, and particularly how harsh Harry was when it came to his old mentor. I don't want to give up too much here, but I felt this figure was really treated poorly by this particular outing.

Yet I will say that I thought this was one of the few Time Travel plots that was reasonably easy to digest without being simplistic. Time travel plots can be EXTREMELY thorny and complex, and in fact can really stretch credibility, but not here. As stated earlier, the events of this plot made sense and the conundrums time travel engender seemed logical. In doing so, the resulting conclusion of that part of the plot was extremely powerful and moving.

While this play is being regarded as a VERY powerful stage presentation, I am grading it on its readability, and that’s why I’m giving this version a 3. If the rumored "upgrade" comes out I will give it a higher grade if it delivers … like I am guessing it will.

author: cmfinkler23

author: Coreena McBurnie
title: OK
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2017
content:
I was so excited to get this book when it came out and I wanted to love it so much, but I have to say I didn’t. I didn’t exactly hate it either because it was missing that Harry Potter magic that we’ve all come to expect from this series.

It was fun to delve into a play, something I hadn’t done in quite awhile, which also made it a quick read. I enjoyed visualizing what the scenes would look like on the stage — and according to the stage directions, the play must be spectacular.

But I did find the story lacking. I don’t want to spoil anything, but the whole story was missing a major villain, someone the reader could really hate, someone along the lines of Voldemort. There was an antagonist, but they just didn’t seem evil enough for the Harry Potter universe.
The other strange thing was the lack of magic.

Also, I wasn’t thrilled with the relationship between Harry and his son. It just felt wrong. Harry knew what it was like not to fit in and be bullied and yet he seemed to have very little sympathy for his own son.

My favourite characters in the story, by far, is Draco Malfoy, followed closely by Ron Weasley.

Overall, I did enjoy The Cursed Child, but found it lacking at the same time.

author: Twylark
title: Fan Fiction Quality Writing
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: The quality of the ebook product was good for the kindle app on my iPhone. The content itself, read as a fan fiction rather than a professional play script.  Completed reading in 3-4 hours, not worth $15 for the digital copy in my opinion, but there are no plans for an audiobook.

author: Michael DeFellipo
title: Not the trip I wanted to go on again
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: [spoilers] I was so excited to get another Harry Potter story, but this doesn't have any of the traces from previous installments. The very limited descriptions I could deal with, because J.K. did such a great job creating this world that I could SEE everything in my mind without it being described to me. The big problem being all of the characters are unlike themselves. I understand people change in 20 years, but not to the point that they're completely different people. Also, I don't think Cedric was a big enough character to base a whole book around. If you want to reverse time to save someone, why not go for Dumbledore or Harry's godfather? Ya know, someone important. The pace and content is way off, too. It starts off great, dives into bad territory, gets better, gets into worse territory, gets better and ends on a very average not. It wasn't the journey to Hogwarts that I was looking forward too. Not bad, but far from great.

I'm sure as a play, the scenery, the props, the animation of the characters would help to bring this story alive.  But in it's written form as a play, it left the reader wanting.  As with most time travel storylines, it had some major flaws which can not be resolved.

author: Emma Budiansky
title: Glad to see HP's return, but not entirely fulfilling
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: It was nice to finally have new HP material again, and there were some charming and interesting moments, but unfortunately these were interspersed with fan-fiction level writing and a lack of consistent character depth. Some aspects of the plot were quite clever, while other aspects lacked originality and didn't entirely make sense with the other books. The text and narrative fell short of what I've come to expect (as a serious, long-term fan) from JKR. Certain points were so awkward and poorly concieved that I doubted the level of involvement that she had in writing this script. I won't mention more specific criticisms to avoid spoilers. It might be a much more fulfilling experience seeing this as a play though.

author: Paul
title: Significant Plot Holes Which Impact the Original Novels
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
The script of the new 2-part play does what many a script where visuals are going to be extremely important do: Disappoint.

One can tell the J.K. Rowling did not write this: Much of her crafting is absent, although the playwright tries his best. We have a story of a conflict between Harry and his 14-year old son, Albus, who finds that the weight of his father's fame isn't easy to live with, and their estrangement leads to desperate measures resulting in an adventure for Albus with an unexpected friend, and dire consequences.

This is a bit tough to rate, as I find the current collective rating of 3.4 stars to be pretty accurate. I'd round it up to 3.5, and since Amazon doesn't do half stars...well, here we are. I was originally going to give this 4 stars, but there's a major problem with this play, one that undermines certain scenes and character establishment from the novels. While doing my best to not spoil, we have a character whose stated mother was portrayed as childless in the novels, and it was a very important part of her character that she had never been a mother.

That's just one of the major plot holes that exist in this script. Another is never being shown the turn of the character Albus and friend were trying to save. The other problem with it, of course, is that it is a script, not a novel. As a result, it is barren of the characterization and details that a novel fills in, that in a play or a film is filled by the visual and auditory aspects. I can see that the play itself is likely better.

It's still interesting to go back into this world. But as scripts go, this one is lacking as a dry read, depending too much on the visual spectacle of the actual play to make a fully satisfying read as a script.

author: minikawa
title: Read it then let us take a moment of silence and let Harry Potter and the gang rest
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I just finished reading the whole play and I think that I should write what I think about it before going to sleep. It is a short read at only 320 pages.

We start of at the Epilogue in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows wherein Harry, Ginny, Ron and Hermione are sending off their daughter and sons to Hogwarts at Platform Nine and Three Quarters. Albus Severus Potter, Harry and Ginny’s second child is scared that he will be sorted out to Slytherin. James Potter, the eldest, keeps on teasing him. Harry assures him that he is named after two headmasters of Hogwarts and being sorted to Slytherin is not a bad thing.

Albus and Rose, Hermione and Ron’s daughter, boarded the Hogwarts Express and entered a cabin occupied by one boy - Scorpius Malfoy. Rose didn’t like being in a cabin with Scorpius given that he is a Malfoy and there are rumors going around about him being the son of Voldemort but Albus felt comfortable with Scorpius so he stayed with him in the cabin and that started their friendship.

When they arrived at Hogwarts, Rose was the first one sorted and she got sorted to Gryffindor - no surprises about that. Albus, however, got sorted to Slytherin and everyone, even the Sorting Hat, got confused and silent about it.

Over the course of the year, Albus was bullied at school for not being like his father. He wasn’t able to get into the broom the first time he tried, he is not a Gryffindor and he is not excelling in any of his classes. He became timid and had just one friend - Scorpius.

The play fast forwarded to their second year in Hogwarts then to their third year and to their fourth year. Harry is Head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement, Hermione is the Minister for Magic while Ron manages the Weasleys’ Wizard Wheezes. There is no appearance from the other Weasleys. Harry and Albus’ relationship turned for the worst and the last night before Albus’ fourth year, Harry and Albus fought. On that same night, Albus also overheard Harry talking to Amos Diggory who is begging for Harry to use the illegal time turner he got from a wizard he caught to bring back Cedric Diggory. Harry didn’t agree to Amos’ pleading and Amos’ went back to the hospital with his niece, Delphi Diggory.

Albus went to the Hogwarts Express and was determined to do something about bringing back Cedric to life and he asked Scorpius to go with him. Albus and Scorpius managed to get to the hospital where Amos is staying and they ended up in the “Bring back Cedric to Life" Quest with Delphi in tow.

That is pretty much the plot point of the play. Traveling back in time trying to save Cedric, learning that when you try to change the past, the future may or WILL end up differently and then trying to repair what you have done by asking for help from other people. There is a part where it is more of a Scorpius show than an Albus show but I kind of enjoyed that part because finally, there is a likable and cute Malfoy in the Harry Potter universe.

I didn’t understand much why Albus and Harry had that conflict. Their conflict is a bit similar to Snape and Harry’s relationship. Maybe it has something to do with Albus being named after Snape. And surprise, surprise, I also can’t fathom who the Cursed Child is. Seriously.

The book is just a transcript of the play with a short description of how the stage looks like and what happens around it and then the conversations between the characters so there are no explanations about why things are happening since you will just be able to read what is being said out loud and none of the thoughts swirling in the characters’ minds. So there’s not a lot of backstory to work on and I felt that some parts needed a backstory like why is there a rumor of Voldemort having a child (unless there was some of that in the previous books that I don’t recall), etc.

Do you know when anime TV series caught up with the manga and they need to put in filler episodes? That is how I felt this book/play is. It doesn’t really change anything in the Harry Potter universe unlike when X-Men Days of Future Past changed the future. I still enjoyed reading it though and I still recommend every Potter fan to read it. However, I can’t believe I am saying this, but maybe it is really time to give Harry Potter’s story a rest and move on to other wizard’s story such as the upcoming movie, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them. Harry Potter will forever be in my heart but unless there is a new and logical enemy out there not from Voldemort’s blood line, let’s leave Harry and the gang in peace and just re-read the original books.

author: Cara
title: An okay sequel, but lacking in the kind of emotional conflict that Rowling excels at
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
I enjoyed . . . The Cursed Child, but not quite as much as I hoped to.  I don't want to spoil it for others, so I'll just say that some points convey a strong sense of fanfiction wish-fulfillment.  I enjoyed Scorpius' character, though I don't understand how someone with his personality would come out of Draco Malfoy's home.  I'm torn about the depiction of Rose Granger-Weasley; it's hard to imagine Hermione and Ron producing such a snobby kid, but she is the daughter of two of the major heroes of the last Wizarding War, so perhaps it's not particularly surprising that she feels entitled to be the among the most popular kids at Hogwarts.  I found Albus' character to be a bit troubling.  I don't understand how he gets sorted into his House, unless we are supposed to believe that he was attempting to rebel, even from the first.  Also, the crux of the story is the complicated Albus-Harry relationship, and I think that the script quickly passes over the source(s) of tension, and, as a result, the conflict is under-developed.  I am also disappointed in the lack of any real family connection between the Potters/Weasley-Grangers.  Apparently, James doesn't ever really think about, or look out for, his younger brother, and their relationships with their cousins seems largely non-existent.  I also think Ron is written too much as mere comic relief.  And, like many, I really don't like the Cedric development.
The new characters may come alive on stage; on paper, they seem a bit thin.  Not surprisingly, this is especially problematic for Delphi.
But there are things that I think the play does very well.  Amos Diggory's grief and anger feel very realistic, and I can see how Harry and Draco can find some common ground through their concern for their children.  I also like Ginny's portrayal.  And there is a moment when Albus and Scorpius have a break-though about how they can succeed at their task that is funny but also sad, as it so strongly conveys how isolated and lonely they are (though Scorpius' depiction as a loser is a bit confusing because the play gives the impression that he's a nerd and more like Hermione than Ron or Harry in his study habits).

author: T.C.
title: Okay, but not great
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: J.K. Rowling's name is on the book but the quality of the writing differs from her previous works which makes me question -- why?  Granted, this is the script for the play which would naturally differ.  I've read the Harry Potter series and liked the earliest ones best.  To compare those to this is like comparing apples to raisins.  Both good but very different.  However, this will be the last one I buy.  My husband, who was a local actor in his youth, was a huge Potter fan.  He enjoyed it more than I did and he thought it was okay.  Quick read.  Pretty artwork on cover.

Anyway, I'm sure if I witnessed it on stage I would have given it a higher rating, but for now it gets 3 stars. If I could give it 2.5 I would. I don't recommend reading this.

On the other hand shipping and delivery went smoothly. My package arrived on time (maybe a bit early if I remember correctly). So, no problems there.

author: wolfboy001
title: Not a bad read, but set your expectations accordinly
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2017
content:
Not sure what I was expecting, but it was an entertaining story, even if it was strange.  The characters have changed so much from the books that it is hard to think of it as truly "canon".  Worth a read if you're a Harry Potter fan, but I wouldn't go out of my way to read it otherwise unless you've got a good vision and imagination for stagework.

To be fair, it is a script for a play, so much of the "magic" that makes a play come alive is dependent on real people putting on a production.  I'd definitely see this on stage.

author: Melissa D
title: It wasn't bad and it wasn't great. I wouldn't read it again, but I also wouldn't say, " This is a must read."

content: This book was just okay.

author: Olyvia M.
title: I was pretty entertained throughout the whole thing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
This review was originally published on the blog[...]

Okay, this was wild. From start to finish. And I am so conflicted about it. On the one hand, I was pretty entertained throughout the whole thing. On the other, I was pretty disappointed/underwhelmed overall.

Let’s start with what I loved about it. Albus and Scorpius’ seriously unsubtle love and devotion to each other. Finally, a Potter/Malfoy love story the fans have been waiting for. Seriously though, I’m ignoring that bit at the end. The premise of the story is so outrageous that it was just so entertaining and I loved a lot of it. I was able to easily feel a connection to Albus, and Scorpius. Even in play form, you can see that they’re struggling trying to find a place for themselves in a school that holds the legacies of both of their fathers. Ron Weasley is still the best in every universe and I have nothing more to add to that.

However, for the most part I found the story predictable and the original characters to be completely out of character from their development in the canon Harry Potter books (because I for sure am not considering this part of canon). First, in no universe would Harry James Potter ever say such terrible things to his own son, or try to control him the way the Dursley’s controlled him. Second, there’s no way that Severus Snape would ever be okay with sharing a name with a Potter. Even if he did, he would never outwardly admit to anyone, let alone his namesake.

I was really disappointed with the story overall in that everything that happened was predictable, which is not ever something I would expect from a Harry Potter story. In general though, I found myself having to remind myself just to read and not think too much about it. Time travel stories sometimes really mess with my head and I start thinking about the complexities and consequences, and things overall that could just not happen even in the magical world if you’re following your own rules.

If nothing else, I got to feel the anticipation and excitement of reading a new Harry Potter story and I’ll always be grateful that I got to feel a little piece of my childhood all over again.

Overall, I’d give it 3 bards.

author: Dh
title: Another time, another place
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: It's hard to condense 4 years into a 4 hour play. It's even harder to accept the premise of this work of fiction, but I have to remember it is fiction. Perhaps the next version of this play will remember that there were two boys born at the end of July and let Neville be the hero, of course we will still have that unbelievable narrative of Voldy breeding. Just keep repeating this is a work of fiction, it's not real.

author: M1
title: Not by J.K. Rowling, stage script, difficult reading format.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2017
content:
It's not written by J.K. Rowling.
It is a Stage Play script format. Some people will not enjoy reading a script.

content: Why Jk Rowling...? Okay first things first I absolutely love Jk Rowling and the Harry Potter series. I also like fan fiction...when it is clever and written well. author: Alex
title: An interesting look at Harry and the gang many years later.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content:
Interests: Play/Scripts, Fantasy, Magic

Quick Summary
Set 19 years after Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, this play looks at the life of a now 40 year old Harry and how he is handling working for the Ministry and being a father to a son he can't seem to understand.

What I Liked
I will preface this by saying that I don't read plays and I only read this one because I grew up on Harry Potter so I was pretty much obligated to read this, right? Having spent so much time with Harry, Hermione, and Ron it was interesting to see how they were as adults and how they had changed and in many cases hadn't changed. I also liked the idea of certain things being destined, like Ron and Hermione. I loved Scorpius Malfoy! He was funny and goofy and sort of embraced his "loser" status. He was lonely but also didn't really care, as long as he had his best friend, Albus Potter. I also strangely liked Draco in this one; he's really grown up since the original books and he's got his life sorted out pretty well. He tragically loses his wife but his love for her is so beautiful and his devotion to his son, Scorpius, is also wonderful. There's a lot of coming to understand Draco's past in this one and learning to forgive the angry, confused boy he was.

What Needed Work
I just couldn't really connect with the story and I'm sure it's being this was just a script. I would love to see the actual play because I'm sure I would like it a lot more. There's just so much that gets left out when all you're reading are character lines and some stage direction. You really lose all the emotion of the story so that made this one hard to relate to. The story also had a lot going on because there was multiple trips through time to change and then try to fix things. Just a lot going on. Again I'm sure I would have liked it more in his actual play form rather than just the script.

What I Didn't Like
I didn't really like Harry (don't hurt me) because he's pretty much a jerk about a lot of things. He's pretty obsessed with work and doesn't really relate to his younger son, Albus's mediocre status at Hogwarts. He's not the best father because he's hardly around and he can't understand why Albus doesn't love Hogwarts and everything associated with it. Harry's pretty self-centered in this one and he says some pretty awful things -- granted he realizes his mistake right away and I'm sure we've all said things we didn't really mean in the heat of the moment. To be perfectly honest, reading this now as an adult I can see how selfish Harry was in the original books. A lot of it comes from having the pressure of saving the world on his shoulders as well as being an act first, think later personality. But this was a little eye opening.

author: Book Club Fan
title: Quick read - and that's my main objection
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
My 13-year-old & I both flew through the pages of this story, and walked away from it thinking it was okay.
That's a shocking thing for me to say about anything Harry Potter by JK Rowling. Because both she and her series are historically exquisite and worthy of all the gushing praise we willingly gush.
Her writing (sorry for the cliche) transports me every time; the nuances of her storylines, the flaws and frustrations of her characters, the ultimate triumph of good over evil - all of that typically registers deeply with me.
Not this time. The notion written here (no spoilers) raises thoughtful "what if" questions, and the cast presents interesting relationships and conflicts - but it just doesn't ever successfully tap into my own imagination, failing to stick with me during my daily routine, as I've come to expect from Rowling.  To be fair, I haven't read many screenplays, but I don't believe the format detracted from the tale's appeal; I just needed about 300 more pages of tale to be told with the exceptional richness Rowling does so well.
Plays do expect the audience to garner a lot from what is often very sparsely written dialog, I get that.
And I get that Rowling set the bar unusually high with one of the most compelling book series I've ever read.  There's a reason there are 500 million copies in print...
But I also get that this is not that, so I'm left hoping Rowling's got another series growing within her.

title: OK for nostalgia, little else to add
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content:
This was ok. The biggest disappointment for me was that I loved the world JK Rowling created and how thoughtful and fleshed out her descriptions were. Since this is a play, I didn't have that world creation, just little action. I can imagine it being good on stage, but she should have adapted this into more of a novel for the book release.

As for the plot, it just felt lazy and uncomplicated. Yes, there is a big twist, but it isn't anything grand or shocking. The old characters turned into the parents we hated as a teenager, and the new characters tried to be like Harry's meddling self, but for no reason other than to comfort an old man.

I will say, however, that it is an easy read and it was nice to see how she sees the magic world after the fall of Voldemort, but the nostalgia was not enough to make me want more. I'd rather re-read the seven books than this one play.

author: Mike
title: Disappointing...Read it, I Guess...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
It's hard to put into words how I feel about this book...I mean script...other than to say that it was "disappointing". I'm not saying don't read it. You'll probably enjoy it a little bit like I did, but it'll leave you feeling disappointed.

The 7 Harry Potter novels by J.K. Rowling are my 7 favorite novels ever written. I remember beginning to read them back when I was in elementary school. I continued reading them throughout grade school, anticipating the release of each book and finally finishing the 7th book some time in early high school. At the end of the 7th book, I was completely content with how the story ended. Then, the movies provided some closure. Life was good.

I was excited to hear of the release of a so called "8th book". Despite negative reviews, I ordered it and gave it a go.
I was prepared for the fact that this "book" was actually just a script. However, once I began reading it I immediately hated that it was a script. It took a bit to get used to that. What I hated the most was that there was such a lack of detail provided. I had to rely on previous books and movie scenes to help paint a picture of what was going on, as well as understanding the personalities of each character. This book is just straight dialogue, with some minor narrating here and there (which is put in parenthesis and italicized).
The plot was there, but it felt rushed. There is lots of skipping around and less story development. It almost feels like you're reading the sparknotes of the story. So many things were just left out.
Note that this book is about 300 short pages, while some of the other books are 700+ full pages of text.

Overall, I'd say read it but don't expect a whole lot. I am so disappointed in J.K. Rowling for this work. I feel that she did not even write most of it. This really could have been so much more...so much better. But instead its a script. From a play. That none of us will ever go and see. It could have been the 8th Harry Potter book we've all wished would have existed, but it's just a script. Some talking back and forth with somewhat of a plot.

Happy reading.

I wish that they would expand more on the world of Harry Potter rather than Harry's descendents.  To see the future generation was good, though.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Unoriginal, but I'd still recommend reading.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: Let me start out by saying that I'm a HUGE fan of everything Harry Potter and I was terribly excited when I found out J.K. Rowling herself was working on a HP play.  However, after getting the script for it and reading it in under two days I was a bit disappointed.  J.K. Rowling thoroughly contradicts herself with the way she has written the majority of her characters, especially Draco Malfoy who she originally said would never get along with Harry and the gang, but in the play she even goes as far as mentioning that Harry and Draco see each other as friends for the first time.  I love Draco, and I'm glad that he finally gets redemption, but it's weak, rushed, and he's out of character for most of the play.  Other than a lot of the characters being very different from their original selves, the play is completely unoriginal and all over the place.  It seems as if J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany, and Jack Thorne took popular elements from Harry Potter fanfictions and stuffed them all into the play.  In fact, even minor elements seemed to be based off of fan's headcannons rather than original ideas from J.K. herself (I'd give examples, but I don't want to spoil the story for anyone who still wants to read it).  If you're a die-hard Harry Potter fan, like myself, I'd still recommend reading it as it is considered cannon, but I know many other fans, including myself, who are refusing to recognize certain aspects as true cannon.

author: Brandon Winslow
title: It's fun, but it's not Rowling and it doesn't feel like canon to me...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content:
I think that seeing the play would be a fun experience, and I was super excited to read the script book when I got it for my Kindle. I definitely had a fun experience reading it, but a month or so on it doesn't sit with me as being a true "Eighth HP Story." First off, it re-uses a lot of story and scenes from previous HP novels as time-travel is a central theme of this story. The characters from the original series seem a bit off in some places - especially Harry himself. Oddly enough, my favorite character was a new one - Scorpius Malfoy - he's hilarious and all-around entertaining!

If you're an HP fanatic like me who's read the books many times, you'll have to read this - but just understand that it's not a novel - and they even take minor liberties with certain dialogue that was in the existing series. 3.5 stars would be my rating if they'd let me do half-stars.

author: Joe Kessler
title: Don't expect another Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2017
content: On both a plot and a writing level, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child falls far below the previous Potter books -- perhaps reflecting the fact that J.K. Rowling was not involved in the actual writing process. (She's merely one of three credited authors for the original story idea.) Still, this stageplay sequel just about squeaks by on the charm of its characters, especially the sweet bond between Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy, and on a reader's undeniable joy at any revisiting of Rowling's Wizarding World. I imagine the weaknesses of the script could also be mitigated somewhat by a talented cast performing the lines, and I'd certainly love to see the production brought to life on stage someday. But as written, it's a pretty flimsy work with an absolutely absurd premise, and it utterly fails to add anything meaningful to our understanding of the Harry Potter story. In the script's own parlance, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a "spare" -- an inconsequential add-on that's not awful, but is still nowhere near as exceptional as its fellows.

author: Nico Restal
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content:
Apparently this was great on stage, but Rowling (or whoever wrote it) doesn't know how to write plays (directions like "their minds are in hell" don't belong in scripts), nor can she punctuate. This can't have been edited; I didn't notice any such errors in her books, which I loved.

The plot was disjointed - how did Harry know Delphi's name? - and the characters apart from Albus and Scorpius were badly drawn. I couldn't see Ron or Hermione in their adult versions. I did rather love Scorpius though; his dialogue was witty and funny, but the scenes without the boys were awfully flat.

And seriously, how did they stage this with all the emotional directions and special effects?

author: Jack B.
title: so-so
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I got this last night at midnight and finished it around 4 pm on July 31st! All in all, it was definitely entertaining BUT as it is a script and as it is NOT written by JK Rowling, it is not the Harry Potter we know and love.

I won't get into the details of the plot, but I will say that the storyline was entertaining and it was interesting to see a glimpse into how things may have gone if Voldemort had triumphed. Unfortunately you can't really savor any part of the story for long because it was written without any of the frills and beautiful description from JK Rowling.

Now before you criticize me, I GET that it was a play and that you can really only write what can be seen on stage, but with the previous 7 novels setting the bar so high, this was fairly disappointing in comparison. Some of the other reviews are pretty accurate in saying it reads like a polished fan fiction.

All criticism aside, the story was fun and because it was a script, it was a very quick read. Overall, it was exciting to go to a midnight release party for an HP book again!! Nostalgia!

author: Kellie's Kindle Reviews
title: Hate The Format

content: Realize it's a play but it's a rough read in this format.  The story itself was good enough but wonder if it had been more of a regular book if it wouldn't have been stronger.

author: Melissa
title: Published Fan Fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2016
content: If you are going to read this book you have to detach yourself from Harry Potter books 1-7 which is very hard to do. Take it as published fan fiction that J.K. Rowling liked so much she put her name along with it. Certain things do not flow with the way the series was previously written and it's hard to get past. Character behavior and personality are also things that become lost with this story making the whole plot highly unbelievable. They shouldn't have referred to this as the 8th book and should have called it what it is, Harry Potter fan fiction. If you want a book that gives you an alternate look at Harry Potter and the rest of the characters this is a good book to read. If you are looking for something to continue the Harry Potter story line, this isn't it.

author: VaultDweller
title: Three Stars

author: Kay
title: A Difficult Read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: Regardless of anyone's opinion, Potter fans will want to read this latest chapter in the series. It is a quick, but difficult read. The play format makes the flow of the story impossible. The story itself is short. It would've been far greater if the format was not written in a play. I also do not see much of Rowling's hand in this story. I would love to see how the play turned out. I wish, for the money spent, I would've got a bit more. But love it, like it, or hate it, fans will want/have to read it.

title: A play is not a seven novel  extravaganza

content: An enjoyable reverie bringing back all of the major characters, but not as good as I was hoping

author: Amazon Customer
title: Disappointing ending to the magic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I am a HUGE fan of the Harry Potter books and am very sad to say that this story was a disappointment. Without giving out spoilers, the entire plot is centered upon a rather minuscule detail from one of the books. That made me question whether this play was written in a true effort to continue the story, or rather to further profit from the Harry Potter name.

Rating 3 stars because, sure, I love Harry Potter and I did get more character insight and a further sense of closure from this.

This script dreadfully lacked the magic, emotional impact, and overall depth of the famed book series. Quite a disappointment.

All true fans are going to read it anyway... But don't expect much.

author: CamaroZ28c
title: Decent but fast read for Potter fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2016
content: This was an enjoyable read, although it was not able to match the quality of Rowling's books.  It was fun to see Harry and company again but there was hardly any character development and I had a hard time getting to know the new characters.  The screenplay format was annoying and made the book feel even shorter than it was; I finished it after only a couple hours.  There are some rather large plot holes but don't want to get into them here for fear of spoiling.  I would recommend this to Harry Potter fans eager for more, but would not recommend to those that haven't read the real books first.  I would probably give it 3-3.5 stars.

author: NY Book Blog
title: Check expectations at the door.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: It was like standing on the sidewalk and watching a car crash in slow motion, I couldn't resist looking. Or reading. I had to remind myself over and over to check expectations at the door. This isn't anything like the original HP series.  Shadows of the past  characters, the world less developed. It's like reading a graphic novel executed on a fully functioning fantasy world. Disappointed. J.K. Rowling please learn from Seinfeld. Exit while on top.

author: Cindy

content: An avid Harry Potter fan, I tried to read this and got almost halfway in before starting another book and forgetting about this one.  I don't mind that it is in the format of a play, but because of this, it's mostly dialogue (contrived dialogue, at that). What so many of us loved about HP was the vivid imagery Rowling gave us.  It's not in this book.  Giving it three stars because I didn't get very far...maybe the other half is better...

author: Justin Ivan
title: Wish the charcters were more like the original.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2018
content:
Harry is weak, Hermione is a teenage girl with her first bf, Ron is a dumb misfit, and their childeren have none of the values that were developed by the three friends. Rose Granger-Weasly is a prejudice bully. Albus is worried about every little thing. Scorpious is a copy of a ship character (Ron-stumblyness Harry- famous)
The plot was OK I like how the co-authors TRIED to relate it back to the real JKR works. Honestly I refuse to believe JKR layed a finger on this book. I believe she and the other two authors went into a meeting and slapped together a plot line and made a poorly executed FanFic.

I still enjoyed going into the Harry Potter world as an adult, that I have loved (as have many before me) for years and years.

title: I don't feel like this story really embodied the characters as it should ...

content: I don't feel like this story really embodied the characters as it should have. I definitely agree that it read more like a fanfiction

author: Hellboy Lover
title: Rent - don't buy.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
It was definitely a disappointment, given the previous books. It was apparent, that JK was not involved in this story aside from giving her blessing on the play itself.
Zero character development - difficult to do with a play script with time constraints.
The characters we've grown to love and associate with, came across as flat and very one dimensional - almost plebian in their portrayal. There was a distinct lack of vibrancy and camaraderie in their interactions.
I agree with a previous reviewer, it was very much a fan fic read - it's too bad, there was a whole host of storyline left undiscovered, and one hopes that had JK actually written it, the hype and the expectation would have been warranted.
For me, I find that I wish I had simply borrowed it from the library, rather than invested in it. I still prefer books over electronic reading devices, and honestly don't feel that this book is up to the previous bar that JK set with the rest of the series.

author: S. Anderson
title: Interesting Story Line
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
content:
But it felt rather juvenile.  I think it might be more interesting in person, on a stage.  Obviously it is mainly dialog with stage directions.  Fleshed out as a novel, it could be a better story.  But I still think maybe more juvenile than even the first HP book.  I realize they started out as children's or young adult books but by book four in the HP series definitely more dark and adult.

Love anything Harry Potter though and can't wait for Beasts movie this fall.

author: #TeamCap
title: This isn't Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2016
content: The characters are well written, the dialogue is charming, and the scenes are well described. But the plot? It goes against some of J.K. Rowling's writings on Pottermore, and seems childish. I literally read a fanfiction a few years ago with the same 'twist' at the end. And if you think about it, the twist doesn't make any logical sense. Good attempt, but you can tell that Rowling did not write the majority of this. It falls flat of what I've come to expect from the magical world of Harry Potter. I've enjoyed the Pottermore writings more than this. I greatly look forward to Fantastic Beasts in November.

author: Fiddlethumbs
title: Eh, not a keeper.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I had ordered this from somewhere else, then tried to cancel it when I read the reviews here.  (I always go check 1 star reviews first).  It was too late to cancel it, so  I decided, with urging from a friend, to read it when it came in.  I read it in about 4 hours or less over a day.  It's a short read.

So, to address a critique I saw in the 1 star reviews:
"Harry, Ron, Hermione, Draco characters are completely different." -
well, I found their characters were essentially muted.  The play and book were too short to flesh out their adult selves, and what little character development there was was devoted to the kids.  There were vague recognizable undertones to the adult's personalities, but, there wasn't enough space or time to treat them.  Draco seemed a bit different, but it was more like they humanized him, making him into a concerned parent "with a history".

I did bring the book back, as I didn't think it was something I would reread, again and again, as I did the Harry Potter series.  Some of the 5 star ratings I saw seemed to focus on "AT LAST, something else to read about Harry Potter".  If it were fleshed out into a one or two book full treatment, then I would say hurray.  Several people felt it was just a money grab.  Well, hard to say if it was JUST that.  It was for a play, which is limited in scope.

I will say this about the book.  There was a LOT of parent/child estrangement, worry and bonding going on, and some of it was heart string tugging, but, still, dealt with on a superficial level.

author: Dennis
title: Dull final Harry Potter play/novel will guarantee there will be no more.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2016
content: While I was excited to see where Harry Potter might do as an adult. I was disappointed that he apparently didn't learn much from high school days to middle age as a more effective wizard. Frankly, his son's adaption to his father's fame might be reflective of some children's behaviors, I found his character pathetic including his final actions. Oh well, time has passed and Harry Potter's time to hold our interest should fade too. Bye, Harry Potter and crew.

author: elisainnyc
title: Eh. Potter world as a play simply isn't as delightful
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I wish I could read the original story that this play is based upon.  J.K. Rowling is an incredibly gifted writer, and her novels are truly crafted in a beautiful and thoughtful way.  Though this story has the creative plot twists and turns as well the witty verbal reparte that we've come to expect from Harry Potter fiction,  it's missing all of the rich details-- the sparkle and meat of the thing.  Theater is a different creative medium, perhaps not the best format for imagination rich worlds that shine best in a novel format.  In short,  this story sadly falls a little flat.  I believe JK Rowling could fix it be having another go at it, and I hope she does.  It'd be a shame to end the Potter dynasty on this note.

------
One more thought- it has come to my attention that JK Rowling may not have written a lot of this.  That makes complete sense, and I'm relieved.  Now.  Please.  Go write us the sequel we all (and your characters and you), deserve, you brilliant goddess writer you.

author: pooled ink Reviews
title: Cursed Child | a brave continuation
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content:
pooled ink Reviews:

Read my FULL review here: [...]

Hmm…I’m honestly not sure how to review this…I will say that a script is only the foundation of a play. The words are important indeed but there is something so drastically changed when one sees a play performed compared to simply reading the words in the script.

Okay so why didn’t I give this book 5 stars and a raving review in all capital letters? Well…because it was just okay. While the writing is spotless as usual the story just couldn’t hold my interest (I think I read three or four books between starting and finishing this script).

Scorpius Malfoy is the best character in the whole play. I am forever a Scorpius fan. Albus Severus Potter, kid with the worst name ever, is an annoying angsty little git for 90% of the play and I just couldn't do it.

I’m not saying every story has to be profound or groundbreaking…but as clever as this story makes itself out to be, it sort of wasn’t. Perhaps it was all over-hyped. Perhaps if I had waited until all the excitement had died down I would have enjoyed it more. I’m not sure. Perhaps if I read it again in a year or two I will absolutely love it. Anything is possible.

Rowling is a very gifted writer and I bet this show would be seriously incredible to see performed live (like seriously, based off some of the loose stage directions in it I bet they have quite a few nifty tricks up their sleeves and the characterization that an actor brings to their role is really the magic that sells it).

OVERALL: I didn’t hate it but I didn’t love it. Glad I read it but I could totally have lived without it.

HARRY POTTER AND THE CURSED CHILD is stage play and a brave continuation of the Harry Potter novel series. An interesting look into the Wizarding World’s future that is best performed, witnessed, and experienced rather than simply read and scrutinized. Entertaining but not heart-pounding.
