author: Skylar Whitaker
title: A imbalance of everything we wanted and a lot of everything we didn't
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
This book (script) took me on an emotional roller coaster for the 4 hours it took me to read. I'm going to break it down into pros and cons without trying to reveal too much.
Pros:
- We get a good dose of nostalgia. In particular, I love that Harry shares the first piece of Wizarding wisdom ever bestowed upon him with his children in Kings Cross station. That's one of many moments I loved.
- We get to see our favorite characters all grown up. Harry grappling with being a parent when he doesn't have parents of his own to model after was very realistic, in my opinion.
- Hermione's job title is nothing less than what I'd expect.
- James Potter is every bit his namesake, and I like it.
- Overall, it was a decent read. I enjoyed it, despite the flaws.

Cons:
- What is this timeline? Trying to imagine it as a story, it's hard to follow. What year are we in? Are we jumping back or forward right now? Attempging to imagine it on stage? Impossible.
- Plot holes everywhere.
- The plot twist? Most unbelievable of it all. Literally, you can't believe it because you know it's bogus.
- SPOILERS HERE. Character interaction is awful. Do we even know these people anymore? Hermione sucks at her job, Harry is disrespectful and inconsiderate to everyone, Ginny's a health freak, and Ron's a... drunk? Not to mention, Ron and Hermione's child doesn't like Harry's? What is that? Rose would stand by Albus, I'm sure of it.
- It does not feel like JK did this. It feels like fan fiction.

author: Healthy FitMom
title: The Phantom Menace of Harry Potter (Character analysis included- No plot spoilers)
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
***(Contains short analysis of main and supporting characters - No plot spoilers!)***

I will preface this by saying that I will love Harry Potter, "Always."
I wish I could say that I was under the Imperius Curse giving this 3 stars.

If you read the script objectively, not expecting it to be a continuation of the novels, it is more enjoyable. Seeing the play in person would give MUCH more personality to the characters and greatly enhance the magic of each scene.  I suppose I would rather have been able to read the story this way, then not at all.
I have a family member that saw the West End Production and said it was an INCREDIBLE experience - every detail was thought out and it was like real magic. I believe that.

Reading "Cursed Child" as a script doesn't have the same feel as reading the novels.
I missed Harry's internal thoughts that gave him depth in the first 7 books. This was forgivable since the characters' personalities still showed through their dialogue and stage directions.  Breaking the fourth wall may have been cheesy or awkward on stage, while on the other hand, some of the corny humor would be more comical watching the play with the right delivery. It's nearly impossible to envision the intricacies of the scenery, music, and effects on stage by reading this. I'm rating the script with that knowledge and not at face value. If I were to compare it to the last 7 books, zero stars would be appropriate.

The scene designations help set the stage for the characters both in the wizarding world and in the play, which made this a unique addition to the series. The pace moves VERY fast in the play compared to the past books.  This left little time for character and relationship development, but that is understandable given the format.

I was looking forward to reading this as a play, that is not the issue. The story itself has a lot of plot holes, inconsistencies (especially in "rules" of magical objects), and things left unexplained. Some favorite characters were thrown into the story, just for the sake of making an appearance. I wish I liked the story better than I did, but it was so cliche and predictable. Promoting this as the "Eighth Story" gave me false hope. It was more like a quick glance into one messy event in their future. I wish I could see the play because the superb acting, music, and exciting effects may have made the plot bearable. I LOVE Harry Potter and I wanted to love this script.

As for the "secrets," grab a chair, some butterbeer and start reading.

****Character Analysis - Read ahead if you do not mind learning about some characters' personalities and backgrounds - Does not ruin the plot******

The beloved wizards we grew up with are still relevant and relatable as they have, like us, grown older and are experiencing life in a whole new light. Harry, Ron, Hermione, and Ginny's personalities are somewhat consistent with the previous stories, but have evolved as they are now tackling marriage, careers, and the joys/worries of parenthood. There are moments when they are familiar, and others when you wonder what the authors were thinking. Did the creative, imaginative J.K. actually write this?

Although the story does focus a lot on their children, the baton has not completely been passed.  There were some positives. Ron's sardonic comments made me chuckle. Ginny's dry humor and quips are more profound. Hermione's intelligence, helpfulness, and compassion are endearing. Harry's fierce passion for his loved ones and what he believes, along with other traits that make these characters who they are, gave me a sense of nostalgia. I feel like Harry had time to become his true self, without the weight of Voldemort and being the "chosen one" on his shoulders. Although, as one can imagine, his past still haunts his life in unexpected ways.

We are even treated to the delightful, lip curling, Draco. I must say though, adulthood looks decent on him, even if it makes him a very inconsistent character.

The new generation of characters all have personalities that make sense. Rose Granger-Weasley (how fitting is that surname?) is brilliant, and a bit bossy like her mother, but is more confident in her abilities since she comes from a wizarding family.  She is quick to judge like her father, and this flaw can get the best of her, despite her good intentions and other enormous talents.

Albus Severus has not only the Potter name to live up to, but the great wizards he was named after who sacrificed their lives for the greater good. Plus, spending the last 11 years with his boisterous older brother James Sirius has molded him as the more reserved of the two. James could be the reincarnation of a stag we once knew; are we sure Harry decided not to use the resurrection stone?  This isn't to say Albus doesn't have his own voice. The House he is selected for is fitting, and with the help of his supportive parents and loyal friend, he is more than just an introverted, misunderstood teenager.

If an anthem was written about Scorpius Malfoy it would be entitled, "don't judge a book by its cover." He is eccentric and desperate for a real connection, being raised under an isolated, overprotective, household.  Scorpius is sharp, friendly, and intuitive. His childhood could be compared to the boy who lived in a cupboard under the stairs. Only, his cupboard extends through a Manor with an extensive library from the magical world; he at least knows who he is and where he is going.

author: Z Hayes
title: Engaging and readable, but I miss the HP novels as penned by JKR
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I only got around to reading HARRY POTTER AND THE CURSED CHILD yesterday and finished it in about 2 hours. It is a quick read, mainly because it is written as a script. I don't understand all the complaints about this since from the beginning it was advertised as such. That being said here are some of my impressions of this latest offering in the series (although strictly speaking it really isn't part of the novels, since it is just a script) - Warning SPOILERS AHEAD!:
- I enjoyed reading about Harry and Ginny's and Ron and Hermione's lives post The Battle of Hogwarts, albeit 22 years later. They are about 40 here and have matured into the responsibilities of adulthood with their respective careers and family commitments. Ron is the exception, however, retaining his goofiness and his career, if it can be called that, is running a joke shop which somehow isn't a stretch at all given his off-beat character.
-The focus of this script is on the story of Albus Potter, Harry's second son, who can't seem to measure up to his older brother James, or even his younger sister, Lily, both of whom get into Gryffindor, while Albus gets sorted into Slytherin. Albus also becomes fast friends with Skorpius Malfoy, the son of Draco Malfoy, although Skorpius here is presented as a geeky, Hermione-sort character with his fondness for books and learning. To cut to the chase, the plot focuses on Albus and Skorpius going on a quest of sorts to set things right and to bring Cedric Diggory back alive, all using a contraband Time Turner. Things off course go horribly awry, and it is left to the famous trio and even Draco to rescue their offspring.
- The story starts off in jumps and starts and the plot is a little confusing as we are taken back and forth in time, but after a brief period, things slow down enough and I was able to appreciate the narrative and where the story was taking me.
- The dissatisfying part of all this is that the story is too brief (it is after all meant to be staged as a play) and I felt a full-length novel would have done the story justice. There's not enough character development and a lot of it has to be sort of imagined.

Final Verdict - engaging and readable (a really quick read), but could have been better as a full-length novel. Although J.K. Rowling contributed ideas for the story as it says on the cover, I believe the writer of this play is Jack Thorne. Personally, I don't think it would have taken too much effort on J.K. Rowling's part to flesh this out into a novel, and fans would have been so much more grateful for the effort, but I guess we have no choice but to just enjoy this for now. You know, unlike the 7 canon books in the HP series, I don't feel the compulsion to re-read this, and that says it all, I guess.

author: Ezra711
title: Interesting continuation
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: Ok story but didn't like play format. Kept true to the characters. A bit predictable but then all the books were to some extent

author: Jennifer R. Hill
title: Cursed Child was ok....
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
As a fan of Harry Potter and JK Rowling's superb books, I found this one disappointing. It missed the mark since it was written as a play. Rowling is one of the best children's authors of all time but we did not see this in the play. In some ways it felt disconnected - you could actually see it was written by different people in parts of it.
i think that the characters were portrayed well. Harry would have changed a lot from the time of the last book. He's an adult now struggling with work and raising his kids. Albus is a whiny teen who has never known the real struggles people went through to create a safe world. He's like so many teenagers I know today. They create problems for themselves out of nothing because life has been a bit too easy for them.
Scorpius is truly my favorite character. I don't want to give anything away by saying much more though!
I have read it twice and the second time was better than the first. It is not my favorite Potter book by any means.

author: Miss Mellie
title: Adequate
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: It lacks the palpable emotion of the books.  Obviously, given that it is written in theater format, it is difficult to get a feel for the characters.  It is has interesting possibilities but I think JK Rowling would greatly help things along if she were to write the STORY now that the play version has been released.

author: haileyfierce
title: Not what I was expecting
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2016
content:
When you see the name Harry Potter, especially on a book, you have high expectations. You spent 7 books getting to know and love these characters, half the time during this book I couldn't even recognize these characters. They were so different and nothing like you'd imagine they'd grow up to be.
I was so excited to read this but I'm left incredibly disappointed. It's a really quick read which is probably the only reason as to why I decided to finish.
There were parts in the book that made me laugh out loud and parts that broke my heart and made me cry, those parts are because Harry, Ron, and Hermione were so out of character, some of the things that were said are things I never thought would come from their mouths.
This book has a lot to do with the past, the Triwizard Tournament and Halloween of 1981. The authors of this book created all new lines, Ludo Bagman is introducing the victors of the tournament and his lines don't match up to what was said in the 4th Harry Potter book. They changed the what happened in the past for no apparent reason. I kept waiting for Harry to say "that's not what happened", "he wasn't the first one there".
The writing was cheesy, the storyline was cheesy. I complete agree with the people who said this book feels like fan fiction. That's exactly what this is. Everything has changed and not in a good way.
If you can forget the Harry Potter series and everything that we know happened, I can see how people find this book to be amazing and love it so much. I personally cannot forget my experiences and the journey I shared with Harry Potter to fully appreciate this new story about Albus.

author: artist
title: predictable
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: It is an ok read, play form is not always my favorite reading.  She takes the characters forward but is almost predictable and I did not feel it was worth the excitement or the price. I was disappointed.

author: Linda
title: WTF

content: I don't understand publishing this in play format. Makes it difficult to read.

author: Kari Newman
title: Not much storyline
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: Although the story was a genuine Rowling story, this adaptation for the stage lacked the magic that is present in the books. Sure, there were plenty of speeds cast, but there was so little detail that the story seemed distant and just a shell of what the story should be. Worth reading for hard core fans, but unlike the books, this offers no intrigue or hints of what might come in the future.

author: Barry Busch
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2016
content: It was the script to a play. I thought it was a novel

author: john hemmer
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2016
content: disappointed

author: R. Chang
title: Be prepared for a very different kind of Harry Potter story
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016
content:
Much has been said and criticized about the script format in comparison to the original novels. True, it gives the story a very different flow. Different, not better or worse. The story is actually quite enjoyable in merging the generation of characters that we know (Hermione, Ginny, Ron, Draco, and of course Harry) with their children. Surprisingly, it very much humanizes Draco and much of the Malfoy family. I did find it rather disappointing, however, that Ron is mostly regarded as a leftover and is not really given a significant role. My other criticism is that the dialogue sounds rather forced, and a few scenes, while obviously trying to pull for emotional content, are not quite effective at continuing the flow and are rather mediocre bridge scenes.

If you are a major Harry Potter fan, as many of us are, I do encourage you to read this book, as it does offer a good (but not spectacular) continuation of the story. I do not recommend this book for someone new to the Harry Potter saga, as it greatly draws from knowledge gained from previous entries. Make sure you read ALL of J.K. Rowling's novels before starting this one.

It's definitely one for the shelf and the collection, but a disappointing read for someone who loves the books.

author: bookworm28
title: Who's the Cursed Child?
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
This was a great read, but at times confusing(perhaps because Rowling didn't write this herself) so if a newcomer to this series decides to read, they will have trouble keeping up if they don't know the Characters of several of the Harry Potter books. This is not a novel, and by far the shortest Harry Potter book of them all. I completed this in four hours and thirty minutes, with few breaks.
There are twists and great plots that HP fans will love, but after this, I still find myself asking the question the title raises. Who is the cursed child? To answer this, read and form your opinion of who it could be since I have several guesses as to who it is :)

author: N
title: good for reminiscing original series
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2016
content: It was an entertaining and fast read, good for reminiscing original series. That's it.

author: RandomGeek
title: Not what we waited for...SPOILER FREE REVIEW
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Harry Potter fans have waited years to get the new installment to this beloved series. It wasn't until a few months ago that it was confirmed that an eight story was in the works. Everybody rejoiced jubilantly, including myself. But even I had a lingering doubt that this wasn't going to be what we wanted. I was right.
THE BAD:Harry Potter and  The Cursed Child,while not a terrible read, feels too much like a fanfiction. I'm certainly not the first one to say that, but it's true. The writing isn't the same, the characters are not like they were in the books, and the plot was very vague. It feels as if we have waited a long time for nothing.
THE GOOD: What I liked about this novel was the pacing. I will acknowledge that it is really just a script, but even then, the pacing is great! It never lets you go, it just pulls you into the book. Most people complained that it was in script format, but I didn't find it to be that bad. Another good thing that I liked were the new characters, Scorpio and Albus. At first I was very skeptical about Albus, being your stereotypical "teen angst" in a story who hates his dad. But that didn't matter because it was a perfectly understandable character. You know why he is like he is, it's explainable. Now, I personally think that Scorpio stole the show. He had a very Ron vibe, always cracking jokes, but at the same time he was a geek, a good friend, and overall a very enjoyable character. I think his relationship with Rose at the end is very funny, and I would have hoped to see more of these characters in the future. OH WAIT! J.K. Rowling said she was "done" with Harry Potter. That fact makes me a bit mad.
VEREDICT: While not the eight story that I wanted, it is still a must read for Harry Potter fans. It doesn't ruin the first 7 books, and it has interesting new characters. I suggest you read this book with no high hopes for a good plot. It is still enjoyable, but a bit disappointing to be honest.

P.S. Where was Teddy?

author: Suzanne Wiseman
title: ... just took me that long to acclimate to my favorite HP characters being 20+ years older than I'm used ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content: It took me nearly half the book to really get into the story - I'm not sure if it was just me getting used to reading Harry Potter as a play script with the minimal descriptions and reliance on dialogue or if it just took me that long to acclimate to my favorite HP characters being 20+ years older than I'm used to reading them, but it was slow going for a while there and I considered stopping. Once I reached the midway point though, the story got a lot more interesting (and I would say more familiar/comfortable as it began to draw more and more on plot elements from the book series) and I flew through the second half.  I would imagine this is a fantastic play though. I wish I could see it.

title: Quick read
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2017
content: Perhaps because it is a play and not a novel, this book was a quick read in spite of its length. I enjoyed the story but found it lacking in depth, unlike its predecessors.

author: Christina Powers
title: As other reviewers wrote this book was very disappointing. ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
content: As other reviewers wrote this book was very disappointing.  The original series was fresh and inventive.  This play took an idea that's been done over and over in other movies and books, which is the idea of what happens if there is a different outcome. I could deal with that if the characters weren't so far off base, for example Ron comes off as a doofus and Harry is cold towards his son and except for the beginning we forget he has 2 other children.  Also, even knowing this was a play format you can't help but miss Rowlings prose.  It left a lot of fill in the blanks and there were too many things that didn't hold true to the original series.

title: Another H.P....Kelly in Clifton Park,NY

content:
I guess I could sum it all, by saying this is the whacked out version of Harry Potter....some if not all made
No sense.  Especially with all the Time traveling that went on...confusing to me.  The overall story didn't
seem right..some of the facts weren't true....Ron wasn't  the same...and even Harry was wacky...But in the
end truth prevails.....EVIL.  Just the same...it was nice for another chance to read a Harry Potter book.  I like
millions of others is a FAN.  I loved all the characters..and the story...they will always be in our minds
and hearts...it's still worth a read...and as usual..I could Not put it down.  Personally..I didn't like the Play
format...it was weird reading...but I trugged on...I was glad in the end that Harry & his son Albus had a
more closer understanding.  An important message to all parents...talk to our kids...they may do wrong,
(even we make mistakes) but it's important not to judge them...just be more open to them.  We could all
learn something....even Harry learned to be a better father...

author: T. Sue
title: I liked a scene at the end that actually pulled at ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: Beware. It's not the script in book form, it's the script in script form.  You don't get Jo's voice, you don't get some important details, you can't see the performance.  Jo was just one person credited for the writing as well.  I liked a scene at the end that actually pulled at my heart, but the weird nicknames that Ludo Bagman called the triwizard participants that weren't in the books (and other liberties with canon) might work for the stage, but as a novel... not so much.  But this wasn't a novel, so this might not be a fair crit.  Confusing, to be sure.  But script Potter is better than no Potter I suppose.

author: Vania
title: Let's pretend this book doesn't exist.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
content:
This is between a 2.5 and 3 star rating for me. Truth be told, reading this book gave me such an ambivalent feeling that I'm not exactly sure of what I thought about it, nevertheless I do have some very clear opinions.

1. The fact that the format is a script and not a novel had a huge impact on me and my enjoyment of the book. It made everything feel a bit chopped and extremely fast, not at all what I was used to from all the original books in the series but since it will be difficult for me to go to London and experience the play this publication will have to do for me.

2. Scorpius is a great surprise, quite a lovable character. All the other kids presented in this story are just a bit, very, irritating and just annoying and somewhat self entitled.

3. Ron lacks shine, the character comes off bland and just not what one remembers of him.

At the end I understand, or at least I think I understand, the fact that no matter how magical this world is the people in it are human even though they're witches and wizards, they are first and foremost, human. They are flawed no matter how much we love them and I do love them, even with this book. I'll always love them and I'm grateful for the original series and to Rowling for writing it.

I read this to see how Harry and his family turned out.
I didnt realize the book was in play form. To me it was very hard to stay focused. But it was a good read . Book form would be great so that each scene could be followed in more depth. Some scenes lacked information and there was a lot of jumping around. But all in all it was a good read.

author: Amazon Customer
title: but it's still fun to get another Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2017
content: The characters are not as relatable and likable as the original three, but it's still fun to get another Harry Potter book

author: B. L. Schneider
title: Two lies are written on the back of this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
The first, that this is the 8th story. It's not. This is a guy writing fan fiction and slapping JK's name on the cover so it will sell. The second is that it's 19 years later. No. The events in this book happen 22 years later.

It's a shame because there's a lot of possibility here. There are interesting storylines taking place here, they just aren't executed on the level we've come to expect from a Rowling product. I'm a sucker for a good time travel story, as well as revisiting beloved characters much later in life. But this isn't how these characters act. Albus should never have been this whiny. I liked him in the 7th book. I liked Harry in the original 7. But, here, the characters have become annoying or flat. With Ron he was actually just describing either Fred or George!

I also just wasn't a fan of how entwined in the story Harry was. Like, I've already seen him and everything he's capable of in the original 7 books. Now, he's a blubbering fool. You can't sit there and tell me that Harry Potter, the boy who lived, is going to run to Ginny every time he has a minor problem. That and I don't want to read about his life working a 9 to 5. I work a 9 to 5. That's not interesting to me because I live it everyday. Give me more Albus and Scorpius!

The only intriguing part of this for me was when we focus solely on the kids. No, they don't act like normal kids, but honestly, I just wanted to see how they would interact with each other. I know the adult's story and I just want to focus on someone else, now.

Another very problematic thing for me was the fact that we spend a good chunk of the book fast forwarding to get where we need to be. Why waste all that time? Why not start us where we need to be? Why not go further in depth for the moments you do skip over? Entire books could be written for the amount of time we skipped in the beginning of this book. I wanted much more from this story. Answer some how's and why's while you're skimming through the years.

No one can write these characters or this universe like Rowling and no one should. I'm going to have to exclude the "8th" story from my yearly reading of these books, unfortunately. Fantastic Beasts looks great, though, and that is a truly Jo Rowling production.

author: Sylvie
title: Not as good as the 1st seven books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content: My grandson enjoyed it, but it wasn't as good as the first 7 books.

content: I liked it as a fan would it had all the elements of JKR's writing, but it lacked something. Sometimes the dialogue didn't seem to match up.  Also it lacked a continuity with the American version of the books especially The Minister for Magic was in The Minister of Magic in the U.S.  Some british slang needed to to be retranslated to American English or a glossary would have been nice. Also some next characters seem to disappear entirely after the first act. Maybe show illustrations or pictures of the cast. It was hard for me too picture the characters in my mind and its usually the first thing I do to build up the Head Canon of what the characters look like.

author: michal shwarzman
title: I am a passionate fan of the HP series. ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: I am a passionate fan of the HP series. This book, while well written, pales in comparison. As a screenplay it lacks the richness of the world inhabited by the original HP series. The characters - particularly the original trio - are flimsily written, one dimensional. The female characters especially.

author: Tom Reeves
title: Meh—ok.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020
content: Storyline is only okay—it felt forced and rushed, with little character development and very little nuance.  I get that it’s a play, but it falls far short of the delight that the Harry Potter books provided.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Like many others I grew up with the frachise
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I am a life long Potterhead. Like many others I grew up with the frachise, the characters were my friends. Still, this newest stage production sent me for a loop.

First thing I want to say, after reading the stage directions is that a lot of action and movement is happening, so I don't think the script does the play justice. I've only heard positive reviews of the cast.

However, the story seems over burdened by plot holes and a lack of characterization. And I do mean that. Yes it is a script, but there are so many plus out there that have so much depth to them, and this seemed more like a fan service. For example, copying old lines or bringing back dead heroes for a short while.

It had characters who seemed OOC, and plot lines that didn't seem realistic in the magical world. It also directly contradicts several things in the books. For spoiler reasons I won't get into them. But really. Some things don't make the least bit of sense...

Now the positives,  this play was a Malfoy redemption arch and did some great things for them (and some mean things too sadly). It also handled PTSD and parental relationships well. So in that way, the play certainly has depth. Just out of character depth.

I would still recommend reading it, but I fall in the category of people who treat this as an entertaining fanfiction over canon.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: The story is good, but it's in play version

date: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2017
content: I'm not sure that this needed to be written. It was an ok story and I think it was more that Rowling just wanted to give the people what they wanted.

author: eakmkae
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Disappointing

author: Maria Hopkins
title: I'm not mad, just disappointed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
As with many people who have written reviews, I have always been a huge Harry Potter fan and I always thought that J.K. Rowling could do no wrong in my eyes.... until now.

It is with great sadness that I say that J.K. Rowling is a sell out. The book is okay, but not Harry Potter worthy. If you're planning on writing an eighth plot to the greatest series ever written, it cannot be anything short of extraordinary. And Harry Potter and the Cursed Child fell incredibly short. If you want to read a story about teenage angst and awkward conversations, this is the book for you. This book has huge plot holes, is not consistent with the other novels, and adds unrealistic twists to carry the plot. I'm not mad, just disappointed.

Read the book, because it is worth the read. Just don't expect much because it is nothing compared to the originals.

author: A. Walker
title: Sadly dissatisfying
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: While I enjoyed being back in the world of Harry Potter, I did not really care for this storyline. It had its moments, but I did not like seeing Harry being anything other than an exemplary father. And, some of the boys’ antics and troubles and immaturity were painful to read about. The best parts were the alternate universes, in my opinion. But, I just was not excited at any point during this play. I thought it was a great idea to have a play instead of a novel as a follow-up. But, it did not really meet my expectations and ended up leaving me unsatisfied.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It was just OK.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I went in to this knowing it was not written by Ms. Rowling. The story line was predictable.  The plot I feel was written for the ages of about 8 to 13. The dialogue between the characters, even the now grown up Harry and company, seemed to be geared to the younger set. Yes the original books were also geared for the pre-teen to teens but the dialogue was different.  Corny when it had to be, but not as much as this play seems to have.

It was fun to have one's memory of the books refreshed as you could tell where J. K. Rowling's influence was in the story line. If you go in and not expect the magic of the original books, one can plow through it. Good book to get the pre-teens introduced to reading scripts.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Almost ruined the original stories for me.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I we so excited to read this book. I always like to follow Characters as they age and being able to see Harry and the gang all grown up seemed especially exciting. How disappointing. I feel like JK Rowling was only a part of this book in terms of character names, new spell encantations, and history from the original series.  I feel like the writers were hoping to recapture the magic- no pun intended- and fell short. I wanted Harry to be a better father than he was. I wanted his children to all be dull of life and vibrance. I wanted them to be normal happy children with a life that Harry didn't get to have. Instead they have a dad who seems like a past-his-prime professional athlete, not the Harry Potter we all love. I gave 3 stars because the story was well written although a Bit odd in some places, for instance the two best friends seem like they might one day be more than friends except one is in love with Rose. It jumps back and forth. I wanted the original characters to be grown up versions of themselves and not tired old people. They worked so hard as children only to grow up to be those tired, unexciting ministry workers from the first books.

All in all, this was an unnecessary ploy to get books sold.

author: Gypsy Red
title: Disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2016

author: SMD
title: Potentially Promising Story About Friendship/ Fathers and Sons, But Plot Problems Bogged It Down
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I don't really have a problem with this being a play / script.  However, the format is very different from what we are used to.  When the plot is parred down to dialogue only, it's easier to see the flaws.  I am giving this three stars because I found some of the story to be around 4 stars (the new characters, especially Scorpious and Rose) and others to be around 2 (the plot and dialogue,) so I took the average.  Honestly, I wish that Rowling had developed more books focused on the new generation of wizards with cameos by Harry, Hermoine, and Ron, especially if she was going to change them so much.  Suddenly, Harry is claiming that he is a horrible father because he had no role models growing up.  How about Mr. Weasley?  Or Hagrid?  This Hermoine is bossy, but not in a good way.  This Ron is a one dimensional jokester like his brothers (and he's seemingly only there for comic relief.) He actually shows regression instead of growth.  It's a little disrespectful to him.  The character of Scorpious stole the show.  Rose has a lot of potential, but was completely underutilized here.  Frankly, Albus is the focus and much of the time, he just is not likable.  I liked the theme of friendship as well as fathers and sons. There was real promise with these themes.  But these things aren't developed enough because of the crazy, frenzied time travel element, which sort of takes away from the rest of the story.  It drives most of the plot and the story relies on it too much.  I wanted to love this.  I found it just okay.  I suspect it's much better on the stage and in person.  But I wish it were a book so I could get to know the characters' thoughts and motivations better.  I'd love to get to know Scorpious, James, Lily and Rose, but I guess that isn't happening now.  Considering that Rowling is now done, I kind of wish she had left it alone.  This was a mere taste of the new characters, and the time travel took away from us getting to know them.  As an aside, Draco comes off well, as does Ginny.

author: Britt Peters
title: Muddled Review from a Muggle
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content:
I grew up loving the tales of Harry Potter.  My dad used to travel to England and would buy my mom the Harry Potter books before they were popular in the States.  She would read them first and then I would get my chance to read them.  They were a fun treat.

When I heard there was a new Harry Potter book coming out I was immediately on alert.  What more could author J.K. Rowling and friends have to add to Potter’s story?  I began to research and learned that this latest installation wasn’t written in novel format like the previous seven books, but as a script.  This threw me for a loop.  A Harry Potter play?  Set in his adult years?  I was more than skeptical.

When release day finally came I balked at purchasing the book.  I just couldn’t do it.  I was too afraid I would be disappointed.  However, about a month later, I found a stack of forlorn looking Harry Potter and the Cursed Child books sitting on the shelf at my local library.  I felt compelled to take one home and read the latest Potter tale.

I wish I could write that it was everything I had imagined and more, but alas, it was not.  I’m just not a fan of reading plays.  I prefer the author to magically weave stories through colorful, imaginative narration. I feel that plays are a bit too cut and dry for my taste and during my reading I found myself missing the flesh and fluff of the previous novels.  Perhaps I just lack imagination myself and need the guiding hand of the author to take me to another place and time.

The first half of the play took me a while to get into.  It was like trudging through water.  I felt like I just needed to get through this book.  I wanted to love it, but sadly I didn’t.  I wasn’t invested in or convinced by the new characters.  The returning characters lacked their original charm.  I found Harry whiny and sad, Ginny was tired and dull, I felt Ron was a doormat, and Hermione lacked her take charge, know-it-all attitude.  In essence, they had simply grown up and lost their magic…and I was not prepared for that.  This caused me to wonder, had I done the same thing?  (Glass shattering moment)

The second half of the book picked up the interest and the pace.  I was intrigued by the friendships in the second generation.  I found it interesting to think about the alternate realities of Harry Potter’s world.  Exploring these alternate realities conjured up memories of those childhood classic Choose Your Own Adventure stories.

After finishing the book, I began to realize that this could be the last installation.  The seventh book had us all craving more Potter, but perhaps we really should let him go.  It is time.  I found this script cathartic in that way.  I’m no longer longing for more of Harry Potter and his crew.  I’m satisfied with reading where they all ended up and don’t need a follow up.  For this therapeutic reason, I am giving the latest Harry Potter a 3 stars.  It hurts me to do this because I wanted so much to give it a 5.  But the script and the aging of the characters threw me.  As I stated before, I wasn’t prepared.  It’s not realistic, but I expected the characters to be ageless and not share my own problems.  Which is silly, because of course that’s what drew us all to the characters in the first place – they were relatable because of their issues, but in a magical way.

author: NEPAbiker
title: Enjoyable, but not outstanding (spoiler free review)
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: This review is free of plot spoilers. If thinking about purchasing this, you must first understand that it is a script, not a novel. Therefore it does not go into the depth and detail of the original novels, nor is it written as a narrative; it's a script. And while it had input from Rowling, the input of two additional writers is quite apparent. That being said, the actual plot line is enjoyable, but weak. At several times, it felt as though I were reading a piece of fan-fiction, rather than canon Harry Potter. I won't spoil the plot for anyone, but let's just say that it is a plot that has already been covered by many an amateur fan-fiction writer. After becoming used to Rowling's ability to create plots that offer twists, turns and totally unforeseen events in the original novels, this falls short. It stands apart from the other canon in that there is nothing tying it's plot in with the originals, no breadcrumbs left in the novels that make the reader suddenly go "ah ha, I see where this plot line was seeded." In fact, I found the opposite to be true, where certain events seem like they couldn't possibly have gone unnoticed in the Deathly Hallows. Unlike the original novels, it is not something I would re-read again and again. I finished it slightly unsatisfied, still unsure of exactly which character was supposed to be the cursed child (or perhaps it was intentional for more than one character to fit that role). Overall, it was enjoyable to spend a few more hours in Harry's world, and I can see the appeal of viewing this story as a play. The special effects described in the script would be truly magical to witness on stage, and I would take the opportunity to see it if it ever comes to a stage near me. But in the end, it is a weaker story than those in the original novels.

author: Keith L.
title: Disappointing. Only consolation is that JKR didn't write this ...

content: Disappointing.  Only consolation is that JKR didn't write this.

author: Mr. and Mrs. Blackman
title: A lengthy review from a life-long Harry Potter fan
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Since I was 12 years old, I have lived and breathed the world of Harry Potter. As I have grown, my love of JK Rowling's world and works has only grown. I have anxiously awaited a story following the adventures and misadventures of the children of the characters I grew up relating to so profoundly. Given those facts, I had such high expectations that I knew, deep down, that in some small way I would be left disappointed with anything other than a full length novel. I knew going in that this was not going to be that.

There were so many things about this play/story/book that were right... and yet I also feel like lots of things were 'wrong'.

Spoilers coming!!!

Rights:
Albus' struggle with his own identity and not measuring up to his father and older brother
Every single thing about Scorpius Malfoy
The continued love and relationship of Ron and Hermione
Intricacies within the wizarding world
The temporary resurrection of Snape

Wrongs:
Every single thing about Harry. I feel like he was pictured to be a shell of his former self. Nothing about his dialog and behaviors seemed to be true to the character we all know.
Ron was painted to be a bumbling simpleton.
I feel like the ending was, well, lame. The whole pigeon thing was just bizarre.
A weeping, sniveling Dumbledore
All in all, it was a nice story. I feel like I needed to read this to be able to form my own opinions.

Will I read this time and time again, like I have with all of my nearly-worn-out Harry Potter books? Nah. Probably not. I will give it another go in a few weeks to see if it has grown on me, but it likely wont get a third read.

Would I recommend that others read it? Probably. Yes. I think that everyone needs to be able to decide for themselves if this is the closure they needed. For me, it wasn't. But for others? Possible.

In all honesty, I have MUCH preferred the full length novel fan fics by G Norman Lippert following James Potter and the gang to this. Which, I suppose, is all the review this truly needs.

author: fredamans
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2019
content:
Better than I thought it would be.
In my mind I definitely wasn't giving this one a fair chance. I don't like reading in playwright format, but I flew through this one. It's not even J.K. Rowling... but that didn't matter either. These two guys that wrote this one did her stories justice.
Was I blown away to give it a perfect rating? No.
Did I like it? Overall, yes.
I liked how it picked up where the films and the last book leave off. You are left wondering what happens with Harry's family, since you get that glimpse. This story gives you everything you want and more.
What I didn't care for was the bopping around to different scenes. I get it's a play so it's different, but some were to cut and dry for me. Especially coming from such huge books from Rowling. This was like a tidbit.
Still good though, and fans of the series should read it.

content: Good story but way too slow until the third act. If you're a fan of the Harry Potter series you take for granted how fast the stories move, not so much in the play.

author: Trevor Gant
title: Flawed but good, would love to see the play!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The problem is that it seems to come from someone else's words, Because it is. I enjoyed this a lot but it is a story that isn't as grand. More along the lines of a really good made for tv production, not something as great as the original but still has some of the same flares. I enjoyed it but it has its flaws

author: Hillary Weeks
title: Who is the cursed child?
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2017
content:
I have been a fan of the Harry Potter series for almost two decades.
It reads a bit like an angsty fan fiction. It seems to revel in the misery of the characters, but obviously loves the series and its mythos.

Parts of it are quite touching and good- I especially like the characterizations of the adults- though they did a bit of a character nerf to Ron a few times, similar to how they did it in the films where they took away his smarts and strategy and instead had him act as the only levity to be found.
Ginny was characterized well (unlike the films, yeesh), as were Harry Draco and Hermione.

As for the news cast...
I love Scorpius, and how he is just a genuinely sweet fellow who is a total nerd.
Albus is just about the worst character I've ever read. He has no redeeming features, except that he cares about Scorpius- and even that comes across as a form of rebellion against his dad rather than genuine friendship.
Rose is a snot, and I was sad to see her barely in this at all.

The plot.... It isn't true to Harry Potter and actually breaks many of the laws of magic we know, and does not have a plot structured similarly to the mysteries of the HP books.

PLOT SPOILERS AND MORE AHEAD
Time travel doesn't work how it did in Prisoner of Azkaban.
This is not really a mystery- it's 'The Butterfly Effect' set in the harry potter universe.

I'm genuinely not sure who the cursed child is, felt the rumors of 'he's the child of Voldemort' were shoehorned in, and hated Delphi for being boring and with a motivation that seemed tenuous- as did Albus's for trying to save Cedric Diggory. The whole main plot felt arbitrarily chosen. A Voldie/Bellatrix love child? Saving Cedric? Why did she even bother dealing with these teens- she could have just stolen the time turner!

The sequences with the adults were good- the time travel ones read rather poorly and seem to have 'off' choices. The script seemed to almost Queer-bait a Scorpius/Albus relationship- and very poorly. Then they'd hamfistedly establish 'but don't worry, they are straight! See!!!'

They over-redeemed Snape, over bamfed Hermione in certain scenes, under bamfed Ron,

The heart of the play- the relationship between Harry and his son- felt completely one-sided. Albus is truly a horrible kid, and Harry can't connect with him- but I don't see how anyone could. He's awful. He's not compassionate, kind, funny, smart, interesting or compelling. All he does is complain. I tried to like him, but I couldn't find one scene where he drew me in.

The one scene that truly touched me deeply was Harry having to witness his parent's deaths, and do nothing to stop them. It made tears appear in my eyes.

The 'clever' scenes in this, weren't. :( Delphi wasn't all that smart, Hermione's safeguards in her office and the riddles were sadly oversimplistic, and the even Al's 'use the blanket!' didn't seem to make sense, as what were the chances that his father would come across it in time? The 'prophecies' in this were quite weak. At one point they time travel and Rose no longer lives- but really, shouldn't Al and Scorpius not either? It makes no sense. Their 'rules' for time travel are non-existent. (And Cedric turning evil seemed untrue to the books.)

Scorpius's mother's passing was glossed over, and added nothing in particular to the plot except give Draco some more angst- and show more evidence of how thoughtless and horrible Albus is.

So, to sum up-
It's ok. The adults part are fun to read. The children's individual scenes are only good when Scorpius is talking, and the overarching plot is just a few Butterfly Effect time travel sequences for no real reason. Who is the cursed child? Who knows. I say it's Albus, because he's the worst.

author: Reviewer 4
title: Same stuff. Wish there were new characters and more ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Same stuff.  Wish there were new characters and more of the Harry Potter World lore.

author: J. Manzolli
title: An enjoyable read, but different from the original novels
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2017
content: I enjoyed this quite a bit -- it's a quick, fun read.  Due to the limitations of time for a live stage production, though, the climax might feel rushed compared to the original novels for some readers.  Having worked in children's theater for a number of years, I understand why it needs to be that way, but if you're not used to reading scripts or to the pacing of live theater, it may seem a bit less satisfying.

author: Rachel Z.
title: but to me it reads like a bad fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2017
content: As a lifelong HP fan, I was excited about The Cursed Child.  I don't regret reading it, but to me it reads like a bad fan fiction, and I don't "buy" most of the characters.  Without leaving spoilers, I will just say that I found many things highly unbelievable of the characters and world that JKR created.

author: william daniel hatcher
title: Teased with anticipation, joyful for the memory, but saddened by the rushed story line and painful dictation
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I will start by saying that I have been a devoted fan of the Harry Potter book series since the first edition of Sorcerers Stone hit the shores in the US.  I have compared every piece of literature and fantasy to the journey the Harry Potter series took me through.

I am shocked when reading some of the reviews, If you did not know it was a script, you should just re-read the title.  However, I feel it was to much a tease to turn this into a book.  The story line barely brought me back to that same feeling i got reading through the pages of Goblet of Fire or Hablf Blood Prince.  You can tell this was written by more then just J.K. Rowling, the story just seemed too post modern tween.

Ill add it to the shelf, but i doubt ill read it again, and again and again like I did with the other books in the series.

author: Jamie Elaine Gordon
title: Not your normal book.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2016
content: It was a very different read. The play format, instead of the usual book format, was definitely a change. I'm sure that visually this play would be spectacular, but as a normal read, it leaves a lot to be desired.

author: Jpar1127
title: Ugh
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I understand that this is a play and the plot is interesting. That being said the characters don't act/speak or behave as the characters in the book. The intricacies of JK Rowling's writing and character development are totally lost--the magic that is Harry Potter is lost. Parts just seem thrown together, adding spells,characters,and trivia from the books as novelties. A great idea that was lost in translation.

author: Cadye
title: but the only thing I truly liked about this book were that Harry and Draco became ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2018
content: I'm a huge Harry Potter fan, but the only thing I truly liked about this book were that Harry and Draco became friends.

author: Natasha G
title: Not as magical, but still worth reading
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
Reading through the reviews, I can see that there are a lot of people that didn't like this book. I can see that. The play format can throw people and it definitely doesn't bring to mind the same Harry Potter magic as any of the previous books. I've heard the play is fantastic, but that spirit definitely is not captured in the book.

However, if this book wasn't part of the Harry Potter universe and I didn't have such high expectations, I think I would have enjoyed it more. I actually did enjoy a lot of it and even loved some of it (trolley witch, HELLO!). If you like Harry Potter and haven't read it already because of the reviews, I do feel like you are missing out. It is worth the read through and it is a pretty quick read.

author: Malorie Rich
title: I Really Wanted to Put Five Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I loved the concept of this book. I feel like the emotion portrayed by the characters were true to what I imagined the older generation. Harry is still plagued by a past he never wanted; Ron is goofy, which I think he is more so since Fred is no longer around; Hermione is still head strong and being the best at everything she does (I loved how she used the bookcase as a weapon); and Draco is exactly what I imagined, still tore up about his past with new present problems. My heart broke when he was confiding in Harry about the death of his wife. The children were also exactly how I imagined.

I read a lot of fan fiction and I know a lot about the family trees and the actual history of the Harry Potter world, but there were a couple characters I was hoping to finally see or see again. (1) Teddy Remus Lupin - we were all upset when the relationship of Remus and Tonks wasn't portrayed in the movies; it was such a beautiful thing in the middle of war and death. AND THEY HAD A CHILD! And, guess who is the god father of said child? Harry Potter. I kept hoping Teddy would swoop in as the big brother and try to talk to Albus on Harry's behalf, but it didn't happen. (2) Older Mrs. Weasley - she was mentioned but she never popped up. I adore that woman; she's a mother on all fronts and a total bad a** of a woman. Molly Weasley is mom goals. I found myself wishing she was in the middle of the action because she doesn't play around when it comes to her family. She would have got things done quickly. A lot of my favorite characters are dead so the list is short. I did enjoy having Snape back for a moment; it was nice to see that he never changed sides, despite Harry's death.

Voldemort having a daughter definitely threw me off. We all knew that he can't love anyone because of the love potion he was conceived under, but I guess we never thought that he could still have sex and reproduce. I'm guessing Bellatrix was fixing to push out a baby when she was gang was locked up in Malfoy Manor in the last book?

I do think this would have been better as a book, especially since I haven't seen the play yet. It needed more description. I found myself needing to see what the characters looked like (yes, I did look up the cast). I needed to see the wrinkles from years of worry and watching over their shoulders. I needed to see the grey in Hermione's hair from running the Ministry and thinking about the time she is missing with her children. I needed to see the laugh lines around Ron's eyes from running the joke shop with George because we all know that Fred would want the both of them laughing and smiling with their customers.

This script was a good fix for my Harry Potter addiction, but now I'm left wanting more about the next generation. I also need a prequel about the Marauders generation, but I shall not hold my breath.

author: kriti
title: Closure to Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I loved the premise and pace of the book. And of course, the chance to visit Harry and Hogwarts once more. What I did miss is JKRowling's attention to detail which all her narratives have; this being a play. Wish she would start writing a new series for Gen Next of the Potters and the wizarding world. After all, the world is not divided just into Death eaters and Good guys!
Definitely recommend it to all Potterheads. New readers need to read earlier books first if they are to truly enjoy this one.

author: Tere Naylor
title: Turn it into a novel and give it more depth
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Interesting plot. Prefer reading novel not a play

author: T. Hunt-solomon
title: It's a play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content: I'm a big HP fan. Really enjoyed the story just hated reading it in play format. Can't say I was engrossed because I didn't finish in a day but I did complete.

author: Tdog
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016

author: Elizabeth M. Enderby
title: It felt like a forced book
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2016
content: It was ok but didn't grab me the way the originals did. It felt like a forced book.

author: Duffman751
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content: Mediocre story at best. I am sure the production is better. Overall a somewhat disappointing read.

author: AmazonCustomer
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2016
content: Not that good

author: richard e whitelock
title: NOT EVERYTHING IN LIFE ENDS WELL- INCLUDING BOOK 8
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018
content:
Read for yourself and determine the ranking of this book. Harry is older, married and the father of 3 school age children. He has met the true reality of life which is "the time will come when the flame grows dimmer and the magic is lost on the mundane responsibilities of work, family and what you must do just to keep things on an even keel. His son Albus must now deal with the Potter legacy.

Book 8 is like the last rose of summer. Its memory lingers but it has lost much of its luster as portrayed in the first7 book of a magnificent series and outstanding author.

author: Erth
title: disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2016
content: I was so excited when i purchased this book. I tried soo hard to read it but ended up exhausted with the format. no pleased. i just love harry potter

author: Ryan O
title: Girlfriend was disappointed with this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: Girlfriend said the book was not that great and she was disappointed.  Unfortunately, this is not the copy she read.  We found it at Barnes & Noble the day before and she was finished with that copy before this copy even arrived.

author: KB
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2019
content: Compared to the other 7 books, it's a key down. The writing is not as good. More childish. And sometimes you just feel like a character just would not say something written here. If you know well. But, being a die hard fan, I had to read it. Go on with low expectations, and you might enjoy it.

author: LARO
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2016
content: I think the HP saga is running out of fuel

author: Green Geni
title: What a let down
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2017
content: I bought this a while ago and still haven't finished it. It just didn't pull me in like the other books and was kind of boring. A shame because I love harry potter books

author: Mattie
title: Not your typical Harry Potter Book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016

author: dn
title: Didn't live upto expectations
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2017
content: It feels like this book was just written to have some kind of extension. It didn't leave upto expectation. Also because it was written in play format it couldn't involve the reader very well

author: Ellen H.
title: I'm not sure I would have liked it any better written as a book though
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2016
content: I read the other books in record time, always on the edge of my seat.  This one is just ok, done as a play instead of a book, I'm not sure I would have liked it any better written as a book though.

author: Sam1957
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2016
content:
I was very disappointed with the book.  I didn't feel like you got to know the characters.

Maybe it will be better as a movie.

author: titanium
title: I really wasn't all that thrilled. I realize that ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content: I really wasn't all that thrilled. I realize that this wasn't meant to be a book so is therefore not written as such but still this story just seems thrown together.

author: bookworm
title: Just Not Possile
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content: The book was great and well written... It's just not possible. If you read the 5th Harry Potter You know what I mean, It is written like a play which isn't half bad, In all I think it would have been a great story if they had just changed a few things to make it more likely to take place in the wizarding World

author: celticgoddess
title: I really enjoyed the Harry Potter series and movies
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2017
content: I really enjoyed the Harry Potter series and movies.  I was excited to see that a new book was coming out, but I was disappointed with the screenplay lay out and how much story was reviewed.  I was really hoping for a more detailed and updated story line.

author: Curtis Bagnall

author: Melissa
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: It was good.

author: Lexsar
title: Meh
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: I didn't case for the screenplay style of this Harry Potter novel.  I felt that the writing was not at all up to the same standards as the original book series.  The predictable story line and attempted plot twists can be seen coming a mile away.  It reads more like a fan fiction than a JK Rowling piece.

author: Cheese Monger
title: So-so
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2017
content: Interesting, but a but shallow in terms of character development and plot as one woukd expect from a stage play.  I felt like it was also a bit too much of a walk down memory lane to relive the original stories.

author: Ashley Butler
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2017
content: Not what I was expecting 😔 the sale was great and in great condition, the story itself wasn’t what I was expecting

author: Kindle Customer
title: Meh
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2017
content:
Only read this to keep up with my students who are just discovering the series for the first time and who will undoubtedly have questions about it when they get to this book.
This one felt too "Americanized" and "modernized" in the dialogue. Characters felt out of character and while it was nice to have some old characters back, I think I've read better fan fiction.
While reading, I was too much reminded of the infamous "My Immortal" fanfic and serious parts were laughably bad. This just didn't have the charm that the old books had, even as a play, and moved too fast because of the script format.

author: lang23
title: Gets Better as it Goes Along
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content: Like many Harry Potter fans, I was unhappy with this play at first. The plot and dialogue sometimes sound like fan fiction, and the actions and speech of the participants are not always true to character. In the second portion of the play, however, the plot picks up and the characters begin to sound like the people we knew from the Harry Potter books. I enjoyed the time spent in the HP universe, I just wish that Rowling had had a bigger part in its preparation, or ar least edited the product before it was released to the public.

author: Tiniferous
title: A great children's play, but definitely not the "8th Harry Potter book".
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016
content:
Whether you enjoy this book all depends on your expectations going into it. If you try to think of this as an 8th book to the Harry Potter series, you will be sorely disappointed. It is not at all like the books. I did, however, still enjoy it as a Harry Potter fan.

Harry's son Albus and Draco's son Scorpius both start Hogwarts the same year, and become fast friends. This play is really about them, with plenty of fan service to old characters thrown in. You will hear plenty from Harry and Ginny, Ron and Hermione, and Draco too.

Important to note is that this "book" is really a play script, intended to be performed as a play. You are not going to find rich description like you would in a book, or scenes that would be impossible or very difficult to enact on stage in front of an audience.

Is this a greatly written story? No, but it is fun to relive some new experiences with some old characters. This story is also written as more of an older children's book. It has more of a feel similar to the 1st and 2nd Harry Potter books than, say, the 5th and 6th ones. While the original books grew in maturity with their audience, this is more of a "go back to your roots" story than a continuation into new adult or adult fiction.

Because this is a play, the character development is very different. Characters were not very well developed, and I only found myself caring about characters because I knew so much about them from the previous series. This really felt like a fan service story rather than a fully developed one. I don't think that someone unfamiliar with Harry Potter would enjoy reading or seeing this play. I don't think they could get invested in the characters.

While in many places the script tries to make you feel a sense of dread or worry, it fails horribly at it. Other times it tries to feed off of corny humor, and that works some of the time. The ending was satisfying enough. It didn't leave feeling unfinished, but there wasn't a lot of suspense or unrest on the way there.

Rating

I give this book a 2.5 out of 5. If you're a Harry Potter fan and would like to read a little fan service, it's worth the one time read. I look forward to seeing the play someday too. If you're not, I'd steer clear. You likely won't enjoy it.

author: Stacy
title: An ok story
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2016
content: The book was ok. It started out annoying, as is Harry's son in the book. Once he wasn't the main character anymore and we got to follow Malfoy's son instead, it actually was an ok story.

author: Shaneye Ferrell
title: Quite Disappointing :(
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2017
content:
As an avid Potterhead I found it my duty to read the new "8th" Harry Potter book. I knew that it was a script and I also knew that it would probably not be up to the awesome level of the other books becouse J.K. Rowling was not the only writer of the book. When I opened up the book/script I felt tolerably optimistic. I mean if J.K. Rowling was a part of it, it couldn't be that bad. As page after underwhelming page went by my spirits dropped down and down and down, untill finaly some 300 pages layer the book came to an end. Honestly I felt pretty let down, the book was even more disappointing than I expected. The charactors were not funny and witty like Ron, Hermione and Harry were. The humor was more bland and average than that of the previous books. The story line itself was enough to get a four star rating from me- it made barely any sense! The theory of time travel within the series (not beeing able to change the future, only doing doing what was ment to happen in the first place) was completely changed. I don't what to spoil any more of the discombobulating plot, in case you deside to read it but lets just say that I have not told the worst of it ( those of you who have read it will know what I am talking about!). That said, I realize that it is a script and it must be pretty awesome to see live on stage. And who knows you may love it! As Dumbedore said, "Happiness can be found in the darkest of places if only you remember to turn on the light"

P.S. I am not saying that I could whrite some thing nearly this good!

author: Finu Lukose
title: Return to the wizarding world...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: This book /script was successful at bringing back characters that I missed and loved growing up. It did seem to rush through character development for new characters and changed the dynamic slightly of returning characters. I actually probably would have enjoyed a bit more of the suggested stage directions. Whatever little detail there was seems kind of corny and forced. Also very vague.

author: Annabelle
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I wished that it was a novel and not a play.It could have been a little more exciting.

author: Redshirt guy
title: Fun read: not a masterpiece
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
Truly enjoyable read. Skilled use of pre established exposition. New characters are believable, but very familiar. Yet, it is apparent from the start this is not JK Rowling. JK's masterful turns of phrase, her use of language and imagery are my favorite parts of reading her work. These aspects of fiction are difficult to weave into the fabric of a script.

Despite that, I do want to see the play, and really had fun reading this play.

author: Holbs
title: Cursed Screenplay
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content:
This is average at best. I love the original series. It is easily one of the most magical stories ever told. It is written at an amazing pace and the characters are brilliantly multi-layered. Every character stays true to themselves from the Sorcerer's Stone through the Deathly Hallows. This is not the case in The Cursed Child.

The general story is not the problem. I enjoyed the overall idea of this tale. My main complaint is that the pacing is WAY too fast. It removes the character development aspect of the story which was so crucial to the main series. It makes it nearly impossible to care for any of the new characters. This particular story would be much better as a novel rather than a screenplay.

The other big issue is that beloved characters act in ways that seem inconsistent with the characters fans have come to love. The only character that I loved just as much in this story as in the original series is Professor McGonagall. Multiple characters act in ways they never would have in the original series. It is frustrating!

It is clear the Rowling did not write this from the start which is too bad because she may have made this as beautiful as her other masterpieces. It is not terrible, but it could have been so much more.

author: Lisa
title: This definitely did not feel like a Harry Potter script
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2016
content: The book/script was very well written. However, there was little magic, little action and just didn't feel Harry Potterish. The plot  was boring and some of the lines felt very predictable. The story was  somewhat predictable. I am glad I did not buy the book. The younger age group might enjoy it.

author: Sadie
title: over all I was a bit disappointed. To much on father son relationship
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
content: Play format was confusing,  over all I was a bit disappointed.  To much on father son relationship.

author: Eric Brown
title: A good time - no matter what others say
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
content: This was not a horrible story, and I'm unsure why it's getting so much hate. It was not predictable (well parts of it weren't) and it was not boring.

author: March2December
title: Wasn't expecting a novel. Was expecting better writing! You Should still get it and read it for yourself.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I cannot say there was any part of this book that sent me back to the HP world that I know and love. I knew this was a script and not going to be in book form. That wasn't it. I was okay with that part. My imagination is good enough to fill in those blanks. I knew it wasn't written by JK herself. That someone else wrote it and she approved it. My thoughts where that SHE KNOWS HER CHARACTERS and if she approved it that it would be spot on.

I am not here  to say that I know the Harry Potter characters better than JK. That is ridiculous in my opinion. They are her creation after all. Some say that this book/play isn't in "canon". That anything outside the 7 books don't fit in this world. That is also far-fetched to me. This world and this canon are JK's. If she wants Harry to grow up, dress in drag, and date Peeves (non of that happened btw), she can! It is in canon and part of that world. This world is JK's after all. W are only lucky to be part of it.

I am here to say that I have my own thoughts on what characters would and would not say. That there were some things that the main people said and did that just blew me away. Not in a good way. There is one main thing that Harry Potter says that, in my opinion and I feel most everyone else's, he would never ever ever ever say. Never! By the time I got to that part of the story, I was already put off.

The characters apparently grow up and become completely different people. Say and do things they would never do in my opinion. They all but forget Harry and Ginny's other two kids. There are two stand out points in the book. They are interesting but lacking. The idea of this story line is great. Which I feel like is JK's part to this story. The writing itself and the character development is awful.

The story itself bounces around all over the place. They drag one beloved character from the past through the mud. Harry smacks close to the Harry we loved to hate in Order of the Phoenix. The moody and annoyingly "why me" Harry. Ginny reminds me a lot of Molly in the book. There is no mention of George. Ron is the closest to the Ron that I imagined. Hermione grows up and reverts back to the pre-troll version of herself. Albus Potter needs a good smack and I actually like Draco's boy, Scorpious. I cannot say that it was this way for everyone else. I kept expecting something to happen between Albus and Scorpious.

Don't go in expecting this to be a wonderful addition, THE 8th book in the Harry Potter world. They could have given us this information in a post on Pottermore and I wouldn't have been as disappointed. You will be able to tell pretty early in that this was NOT WRITTEN BY JK. It feels more like a fan-fiction. With that in mind, I've actually read fan-fiction that was so much better than The Curse Child is. The main characters in this book apparently grow up to become other people. There is weird things added in like dragging people through the mud, time turners that don't make sense, and hand grenade pumpkin pasties...yeah. You read that right. Think "Anything off the trolley" and then the sweet old lady growing spike and throwing exploding pumpkin sweets....weird. Just plain weird.

I wanted to much for this to be amazing. I think that is why I went to bed this morning wholly disappointed. I feel that the only positive thing this story had was taking me back to my childhood. Reminding me of midnight releases and the wonderful anticipation of a new story. It failed miserably in everything else.

Should you buy it and read it? Yes. I think if you love the Harry Potter stories or have read them then you should read this as well. It does add to the stories. It was fun to see them all grown up. There is no other reason to read it. It isn't fantastic or a great piece of literature.

author: C. Bish
title: Doesn't Hit the Mark
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I don't know where to even start with this review. Was the book entertaining? Yes (hence the 3 starts). Did it bring back the excitement of Wizarding World? Of course. Were the characters well developed and the plot well written? Solid nope. Like many of the other reviews stated, the book reads like fan fiction and I don't understand how Rowling could approve of it. The characters personalities are off and their actions are absurd. I found this to be a quick read but it can't hold a candle to the original series. For the sake of Hogwarts and all that is holy, please do not ever have anyone but Rowling write in the voice of her characters. If you can look past the fact that the characters don't hold true to themselves you may find some enjoyment is this book.
