author: Michael A.
title: Reads like a piece of fan fiction.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
I'll start by saying I've been a huge fan of Harry Potter since I was about 9 years old. I grew up with the books, and I was completely satisfied with how the story ended 9 years ago. I wasn't left wanting a sequel in any form, but to my surprise here it is. First of all this is a script for a play and not a proper novel, so I'm aware that it is probably different watching it performed rather than read. However the story is just flat out odd to say the least. It focuses mainly on Harry's son Albus and how he's trying to live up to his father's name but is seemingly failing at it. I was at first intrigued by this exploration in the relationship between these two characters, but was quickly disappointed by the fact that the story then revolves around Albus trying to fix something that happened around Harry during the events of the fourth book through means that I won't spoil.

This is a disappointing way to tell the story. I would have rather have seen a brand new story that didn't rely so heavily on the materials from the previous installments. Basically during the play Albus and Scorpious (a fun duo) make huge mistakes during the course of the story, and fix them within minutes. Scenes are far to short, the gravity of these mistakes is never properly felt because they're fixed so quickly. Dialogue is also poorly written and most of the returning characters don't really act like themselves.

In short, even though there are flashes of what could have been, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a disappointment due to a short but crammed story and obvious fan fiction influences.

author: Sarah B.
title: No spoilers just an honest review! 📝
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I am about halfway through the book. If you're looking for something exactly like the HP series books 1-7 you're not going to get it with 'Harry Potter, and the Cursed Child'. Book 8(HP and the Cursed Child) brings back most of the main characters who we fell in love with in the original series. I thought I always wanted to know what happened to all my beloved characters, but I'm not so sure now. I have a few issues with this book. One being that this book is written in a play format so reading it is kind of hard if you're not used to that, which I'm not. I haven't read a play since I was in high school(16 years).
It reads as follows(no spoilers)
*** -Ginny and Harry are angry
Harry What do you want Draco
Draco gives Harry a dirty look
Draco You know what I want Harry. I want you to write a retraction.
Harry is very angry, his face is fire red
Harry I don't have any control over the paper Draco.(ect, ect, ect)-***
My sister got her copy before I did, and warned me about the way the book was written so I wasn't surprised, but it still took me about 20(ish) pages to get used to the play format. Another thing is that I don't think J K Rowling had ANYTHING to do with this book other then putting her name on the cover as one of the authors(maybe she wrote a sentence or two?). It feels like the two men who did write this book only read the CLIFF Notes of the Harry Potter series because this book lacks almost everything I hold so dear from the original series. I think I would have been happier if the last I heard of Harry, Ginny, Ron, Hermione, and Draco was when they said "Good bye" to their own children on platforms 9&3/4 at the end of book 7. On the positive side it's an easy read so finishing it shouldn't take too long. I just need to find the time.
Also if you haven't read or watched 'Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows' in the past 6-12 months I suggest you go watch it so you are fresh on where Harry, and the gang left us. It might make reading 'Harry Potter and the Cursed Child' a little easier for you. Plus watching any of the Harry Potter series is never a waist of time. Lol. HAPPY READING📚

author: James R. Gilligan
title: Odd addendum to the beloved series
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2018
content:
This coda to the wildly successful and tremendously entertaining seven-volume Harry Potter series of novels that transformed Young Adult literature is rather peculiar. First, it deviates from the narrative form of the seven novels—it’s a play. And although it retains much of the charm and wonder of the Harry Potter universe, its true focus is somewhat more profound—the complicated dynamics of parent-child relationships.

In this story, our favorite Hogwarts trio—Harry, Hermione, and Ron—are all adults with children who attend (of course) Hogwarts. Draco Malfoy’s son Scorpius plays a major role in the story as well. As for the “cursed child” of the ambiguous title, there are three candidates: Scorpius, Harry’s son Albus Severus Potter, and Delphi, a mysterious young lady who turns out to have quite an ominous heritage.

The story deftly balances plot and character development, using time travel to display the complex relationships among generations, and although Harry himself is not the protagonist of this tale, his hybrid position as both orphaned child and husband/father sharply foregrounds the challenges of parenting faced by those who grew up without strong parental role models.

This might seem rather “heavy,” but Tiffany and Thorne manage to infuse the story with the requisite dose of Potter magic. Recommended for all muggles.

author: Kristin Young
title: We were all excited to go back to Hogwarts with Harry, but we actually went back with Albus, and he doesn't much like Hogwarts.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
My very favorite thing about the Cursed Child was Scorpius Malfoy. He was setup as a sort of combo Ron/Hermione to Albus's Harry, so he's studious and clever and awkward and jokey and full of heart. As Scorpius himself points out during the play, he has a lot more reason to be angsty than Albus, but he's just happy to have a friend, and I absolutely loved him. I also really enjoyed that Harry and Draco's sons became best friends and seeing the interactions between the two fathers as they navigated that.

I'm mixed on the fact that the plot was setup in such a way that we got to revisit characters or relationships that we thought were done with. Going back to these was lovely, but I'll admit that structuring the plot this way was also the biggest weakness of the play; it felt like a cop-out to deal so heavily with time travel just for the nostalgia. I also agree with other reviewers that the characters were not consistent with who we know them to be, and the dialogue, particularly for the younger characters, was a bit hard to believe.

There's not much in the way of character development here, and the emotional issues are somewhat over-dramatized, perhaps to fill in for the lacking plot. I think I would have preferred if the "adventure" part of the plot were a bit lighter and the emotional story were more subtly explored instead.

I'm sure that this script is hugely better with the great acting, effects, costuming, staging, etc. that I've heard is given to the London production, but I must say that the stage instructions were a lot of fun to read. That's one of my favorite things about reading plays because you get a glimpse at descriptions, sometimes with very specific or interesting wording, that, as a viewer of the play, you would only see translated into the acting. Most of the time, the translation of the acting (and staging and whatnot) is going to add a lot more than you lose by not getting the description, but seeing the exact words can be so funny and so telling.

Overall, the plot was a bit forced, and the characters pretty one-dimensional--which is probably why they don't seem true to the original characters, who were all far more complex than presented here--but this will hit hard in the nostalgia department. I think the Cursed Child is best summed up as this: we were all excited to go back to Hogwarts with Harry, but we actually went back with Albus, and he doesn't much like Hogwarts.

author: Lauren B.
title: This is ACTUALLY a script
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content:
First to clear some confusion - this book is actually a script. It's not a book that the play was based off it, it's actually the script of the play. As such, reading it is a little awkward.

Secondly, I'm a huge Harry Potter fan, and downloaded this book immediately. I wish it had been a bonafide full-length action-packed book like the originals, but maybe nothing can really live up to those? I finished it in a few hours. I found parts of the plot to be a little forced, and it was admittedly strange reading about Harry, Ron, and Hermione all grown-up.

The book follows Harry and Ginny's youngest son Albus over his first year at Hogwarts. Like his dad, he gets into trouble. Harry is OK at being a dad, you forgive him because despite how cool he is; he really did have terrible role models growing up. However, the action is like when you're watching a romance film and everything bad happens because of a misunderstanding. Unlike in the original series, where Harry and friends are forced into crazy situations, in this book it all sort of seems to unfold because of poor decisions. I do think that had it been more drawn out there could have been other plot lines to help round out the story and make it more believable.

That said, I'm VERY much looking forward to when I can snag myself some tickets to see the play. I think that it'll be great in play form, lighthearted, and just enough to sate the Harry Potter appetite.

author: Kurt Russell
title: Middling Wizarding
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content: Having never read a single Potter book but familiar with the films, I read this little play more out of curiosity than voracious affection. The puny read takes but a few hours, and is a pleasant enough diversion through the wizard’s world, but it is definitely designed with diehards in mind. With an extremely clunky time-travel narrative, the book is really more of an excuse to revisit Potter’s greatest hits from yesteryear, where many favorite scenes and characters are replayed covers like a fan-fic tribute. Some might find these replayed scenes blasphemous and unnecessary, others will rejoice at witnessing the greatest hits. Also, to read the script also sacrifices the spectacle of witnessing the fully-produced play too. I’m sure as many people will love this work as hate it. To one without any horse in the race, it may have been simple and unnecessary, but it was still a nostalgic and well-paced diversion.

author: Lauren
title: Harry Potter and the Out of Focus Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child by J. K. Rowling, Jack Thorne, and John Tiffany is a sequel of sorts to Rowling’s tremendously famous Harry Potter novels. This is probably one of the only things people who’ve read it so far will agree on. Now, the book was released because the play is only being shown in England and fans elsewhere would have thrown a fit if they weren’t able to experience it in some way. It’s important to remember going in that this is a play script rather than a novel. That actually affects a lot in this review as well as my general feelings towards the book.

The story follows Albus Severus, his friend Scorpius, and Harry Potter the father who could do better as Albus and Scorpius attempt to set right what once went wrong. Albus and Harry have nothing in common, something that we are led to think gets thrown in Albus’ face quite a bit at school. He can’t measure up to his famous dad and Harry doesn’t have the time to spend with him for them to work through that. So he grows bitter over the first few years he’s at Hogwarts, until an overheard conversation leads him to stealing a time-turner to go save Cedric Diggory. This is all fine, I’m good with this plot line.  What I feel like the script needed was a little more attention to each different version of the timeline, consequences essentially. I would have also liked to have seen more of the villain prior to the very end.

All that said, is it a good Harry Potter novel? Well, no, if you walk into reading this expecting a Harry Potter novel you will be very disappointed. The language used for a novel and a script are very different, with plays being as visual as they are the book lacks a lot of the description that a novel would have and you don’t get much about how characters feel beyond the occasional note for clarification. The story also feels disjointed in places because of scene shifts and not being able to see the actors’ reactions directly. That said, it’s a script, so I can’t really hold it to novel standards. As far as scripts go, I could have gone with more stage direction in the book itself to help follow what was going on, but it wasn’t bad.  My big problem with Cursed Child is that it lacks the scope the series proper felt like it had, the weight of consequence when characters made choices. Partly because of how directly involved they were in things compared to how successful they were, the villain also felt very small, again, I’d have liked to see more build up there.

As to the good parts, I really liked Scorpius and the way that wanting to take care of him humanized Malfoy. The friendship between Scorpius and Albus was also pretty fun, I would have actually like to have seen that used to give us more insight into some of the other young characters. I appreciate that the golden trio mess up massively, even as adults, especially things like Harry not keeping up with his paperwork. More effort needed to have been given to showing that Harry is under a tremendous amount of stress though, there is a scene that feels very out of character because of this lack.

So, what’s the long and short of this? How does Harry Potter and the Cursed Child rank? For me, it gets a solid three out of five. There was a lot wrong that could have and should have been worked out better, especially given that plays tend to go through multiple runs. The language was off, again that difference between novels and scripts, and didn’t feel like J. K. Rowling’s Harry Potter. The characters could have all been more developed. But, the story is pretty good if a little too much like early aughts fan fiction, and it makes me want to see the show. That I think is the big thing here, there isn’t a sequel to worry over, but reading the script does make me want to see the play. I think that’s a pretty fair measure of it doing its job.

author: Taylor
title: I see where they were going with this...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
There may be some "spoilers" in this post, so you've been warned.
I see where they were going with this story. I really do. But I feel as if it was executed pretty poorly. The eighth story being in script form isn't what made it poor, although that didn't help either.
The plot line itself is a sort of an interesting one. Voldemort having a child seemed pretty crazy, but intriguing nonetheless. It also interested me that Snape was in the mix along the way (I'm a huge fan of Snape) and that Scorpious was nothing like Draco and more like a Hermione type. Blah blah blah.
What didn't interest me though...the rest of the story. Yes, Ron, Harry and Hermione showed glimpses of the Ron, Harry and Hermione we knew in the first seven books but I feel like they were not true to character in the eighth. That may be JKR and the other writers trying to convey how people can change with age but it did me no justice as an HP fan to learn that they had turned into pretty boring adults.
I think JKR needs to write a full story with no contributions from anyone else and with a few differences in the plot line...and just maybe it will be a good eighth installment to the series I revolve my life around.

title: Meh...
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2016
content: I don't even care that this is a screen play. But most of it was repeated scenes from the original novels and redone plot. Harry felt weak and moaned about, Ginny was a nag, Hermione was her usual self, and Ron was a bumbling idiot. But hey, Malfoy was awesome. I liked his change. Nice to see some old characters again, even if bringing them into the story felt contrived and forced. I honestly wondered where the novel was going when, after a quarter of the way in, it was still so humdrum. I must have missed a few details on the way, because a few things didn't make sense. Okay story. Anti-climatic.

author: Jessica
title: Disappointing Adaptation
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2018
content:
After reading the expansion on the Harry Potter world, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, I was really excited to dive into Harry Potter in theater format. However, I was disappointed in the execution for several reasons. First, the material was hard to picture as a stage adaptation. I have not been able to see the play in person, and while I’m sure the production is top-notch, as a reader, it was hard to picture the actions in my mind. Secondly, the plot moved too quickly, resolving itself in a non-realistic way for the Harry Potter universe. Third, the magic wasn’t there for me. At first, the plot seemed to mimic the friendships readers saw in the original Harry Potter series. I admit I was excited to see the characters I grew up with as an older generation. But, it just seemed off. It’s hard to explain a feeling or lack thereof, but this adaptation was not my favorite. It’s difficult to say that because I absolutely loved Fantastic Beasts in both formats—written and on screen. Fantastic Beasts captured the magical universe of Harry Potter instantaneously, while Cursed Child failed to draw me into the basic plot.

Despite this adaptation not being my favorite, I could not give it lower than a 3 out of 5. It is still linked to the Harry Potter universe, which I believe gives it some credibility. There were certain scenes I enjoyed, although they were far and few between. The main reason, I gave it a 3 out of 5 is because I would be interested in seeing it as a stage performance. I think the screenplay is missing the experience of sitting in a theater and watching a live performance. That in itself is truly magical.

author: Chris
title: Pretty goof fanfic here.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content: I have to begin by saying that I love Harry Potter and this book was a welcome trip back to the passion I have for the rest of the series. As I read the last pages I was both sad that the book was over and sad that it had only offered a semblance of the main series. It didn't pave new and interesting aspects of the magical world and it lacked the whimsical and well written scenery that was depicted in the main series. The "magic" of Rowling's magical world was something the reader got as they read between the lines and put together the scene, the play, perhaps by venture of being a screenplay, fails to capture that same slowly unfolding magical scene that enchants the reader. Writing style however is not the real crux of the issue here (SPOILERS AHEAD) is the use of time turners as the central plot point, in an entire magical world with endless possibilities for other stories we just get a collection of time travel tropes. However beyond any amount of bad writing and poor plot devices, I was appalled at the poor facsimiles of our former heroes. I won't even begin to bring up the newly created plot holes should you accept this book as canonical. (END SPOILERS) In summary, it's a fairly good fan fiction at best or an insult to the long standing fans of the series.

author: woahhally
title: Recommended book for any Harry Potter fan
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2017

author: Lorraine, New Zealand
title: special effects would carry this play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: The special effects would be the star of this play, covering up quite a bit of stilted writing.  Play-goers would exit the theatre happily excited by the goings-on but thinking more of the special effects than the writing.  i cant believe that a couple of kids would start out on such an adventure on such a flimsy premise - this part reads a bit like a 1950 Enid Blyton book.  I also have trouble with the stuffy Harry-speak.  He would never say Â«nor meÂ» (twice).  Its a tired old time travel plot but i will admit that even this Harry Potter book/script is better than no Harry Potter book.  I liked Scorpius, he was the only character in my opinion who actually had a personality.  I would have liked Albus more to the fore.  Except for excerpts from the actual books, the script did not have J K Rowling's voice.

author: Potter
title: I believe this might be her story but the play itself doesn't sound entirely like it's in her voice (in my opinion)
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2016
content: I am obsessed with Harry Potter and J.K. can really do no wrong in my eyes. That being said, I believe this might be her story but the play itself doesn't sound entirely like it's in her voice (in my opinion). This could be because of the use of the playwright to write it in its present format. It was wonderful to enter back into the world of Harry and I enjoyed the themes explored in this book. I've heard many describe it as similar to fan fiction and I'd agree with that. While I liked this story... I LOVED the originals.

title: Interesting, but falls flat.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
Of course nothing could live up to how I feel about the original 7 books, but this was okay. I felt that the story development wasn't really there and it jumped around a lot. I understand that this is a play script and not a book, but I still would've like to see the story be less choppy.

If you're a fan of the Harry Potter Universe, this is still a must read. Lots of interesting story about the post Epilogue world. Just don't expect this to be book 8.

While the idea is a good one, because the main characters are kids I found myself continuing to roll my eyes by the choices of the characters. I know that is the point but it left me unmotivated to actually read the story.

author: Nubb
title: Harry Potter Lite
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content: I think it's a bit difficult to fairly judge Harry Potter and the Cursed Child because it's written as a play's script and not a fully fleshed out novel.But taking that into account,I'd say the story is weak.It's like they took a Star Trek script about time traveling and replaced all the Trek characters with Harry Potter characters.I love Star Trek as well but I'd rather read something that's more Potter-flavored.I like that they gave Draco Malfoy more background and I think Scorpius Malfoy is and excellent addition to the many characters in the Potter world.It was also good to have Snape back even in a limited role.Overall,I did enjoy The Cursed Child but I was hoping for more.From what I've read,J.K. Rowling has stated that this will be Harry Potter's last adventure and I think it would be a tremendous shame to send him off like this.Give us just one more full fledged Harry novel,Ms.Rowling and I believe all will be forgiven.

author: HAMAMAN
title: Worth reading….but don’t expect a typical Harry Potter book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: Interesting story and it kept my attention. It is a script, not a book, so don’t expect the normal intricate detail and storytelling. I do agree with some reviewers that the characters didn’t always seem true to themselves, but certainly people can change, especially if you haven’t “seen them” in 20 years. Again, it was an interesting story. It is a little pricey, considering it can be read in several hours, at the most. Check it out at the library or wait until it is in paperback. Biggest disappointment was that I preordered it, not realizing that meant I wouldn’t actually get it until 3 days after it came out in stores.

author: Cecilia Del Lucchese
title: Good script for theater or movies.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content: The book is a script for the theater. I am a great fan of Harry Potter's books. This story is very interesting, but could be better developped. As a film, or a play, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child shall be a great success. I missed the depth of former books.

author: Thomas O. Morrison
title: Underwhelmed, but worth a read
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
I am a huge fan of the Harry Potter books (and movies) and revisit them often. I found this latest offering to be "underwhelming" to say the least.

I was intrigued with the notion of looking at the next generation of kids in Hogwarts as they faced new challenges and experiences.I think the idea of the principal characters' kids interacting in a fairly small world would open up a lot of cool interactions, [SPOILER] especially the idea of a Potter in Slytherin[ SPOILER]. Sadly, this play took the easy way out and just sort of threw a bunch of situations together reminiscent of the previous books and sprinkled in favorite characters here and there for the cheap emotional pop.

In the end, it feels like average fanfic. It reminds me a lot of the Star Wars books (Expanded Universe) that came out after Return of the Jedi... you know, where every book had the plot of the return of a super weapon and threat to whole universe. Sadly, what I liked about Harry Potter 1-7 is that even though there was one long threat (not 7 cloned ones), the real story was in the regular life happening as the story progressed.

This book/play flies through the story and gives little time for character development. The old characters are cardboard representatives of themselves and often behave out of context (especially poor Ron). The new characters have no depth. There are sprinklings of very shallow representations of Snape, Hagrid, and others

That said, this is a quick and easy read and it does feel good to read about favorite characters in a wonderful world again. I would like to see the play... perhaps with talented actors it will add some depth to it. What would I really like? A story about the next generation without Voldemort trying to return, with an emphasis on their lives in Hogwarts and new threats to face. I would read a lot of that!

I have to recommend this book to completists and say that it is not a waste of time., Just keep your expectations low and be ready for a lack of depth and some out-of-character issues.

[SPOILERS]

author: Brittanycrowe
title: Meh.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2017
content:
I was very excited to read this, as I have been a huge HP fan from day 1, and I did enjoy it. For the most part. My only complaint is that the story in this screenplay is very disjointed from the HP series in that it simply does not fit. The main villain of the story is the love child of Voldemort and Bellatrix Lestrange, who gave birth to this child right before the Battle of Hogwarts. This is highly unlikely as Voldemort as he has been described up to now would not have the desire to be with Bellatrix or any woman and she was not said or even remotely described as being pregnant when the trio were at Malfoy Manor in The Deathly Hallows. Unfortunately, this big twist and essential part of this storyline makes absolutely no sense and therefore the entire story unravels piece by piece when dissected even the slightest bit.

Having said that, if you were not a big Potterhead and just take the story as is without thinking too deeply into it, it is an enjoyable read and it was so very nice to have the trio together again. I would recommend this to any fan of Harry Potter and I will read it again, I was just a tad bit disappointed with this story and felt it could have been done much differently and more in keeping with the HP storyline.

That said, it's a fun ride with a few new characters as well as a few surprises from old friends. I'm sure it's fantastic as a live play.

author: JC
title: Disappointed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: Okay, I just finished reading this book last night. I was most curious as to whether others felt the way I did about the book, and it appears most did.  For one, why just do a play?  If you're putting it out there and touting it as Book 8, why not just make a full fledged Book 8.  I was thrilled to be reading another Harry Potter, but the characters here were too one-dimensional, stiff and lacked complexity, as J.K. Rowling is more than capable of presenting.  I love reading her short stories on Pottermore as she explains more in-depth about her characters. However, on a more positive note, I enjoyed the storyline of the book and thought it was so apropros to have Harry and Draco's children becoming best friends, which presented a message here, albeit they came across as more juvenile at their ages then Harry and the others.  I agree with most reviewes, Harry was very out of character and it made it hard to believe his actions, as was Ron's character.  As much as I love the books and am truly a geek for Harry Potter, I don't think I would read another book like this one, or even attend a play about it at this point.  I was generous with the 3rd star--it was a solid 2½.

author: Nick
title: Not what I expected
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2017
content:
I will start by saying this- I am among the biggest HP fans out there. I loved the books- have read the series through multiple times. I've watched the movies many times... I love it all.

This story, however, did not  quite live  up to the rest of the series. I don't mind that it is written as a play- I majored in theatre. If anything, that was a part of the draw for me. What I minded was that is is written as a play without all of the marvelous detail and  backstory and intricasies and humor that made the books as magical and as wonderful as they are. It's as if this story counted on the  brilliance of Rowling's world to carry it, without contributing any of its own. The storyline is familiar, albeit told in a unique way, I failed to really connect with Albus, due to poor character development, and I felt disconnecfted to the new "mopey Harry".

In summary, this was a book that was a decent read,  but, forr me, failed to live up to all of the hype about it, or the world from which it came.

content: The script format inherently loses the great characterizations found in the original novels. It would be a treat to see the characters come alive in the stage version, but the writing alone falls flat as the plot underwhelms.

author: FutureWriter21
title: Good read but...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2017
content:
I don't know what to say about this one.
1. It's not an actual book. (It's the broadway play's rehearsal script.)
2. As an avid Harry Potter fan, I still have my reservations.
3. I'm still not sure who the cursed child is. (Harry or Albus Severus?)
4. I didn't like the whole time travel/ time turner plots. It just... you don't mess with time, ever. Doesn't matter what the circumstances are. In fiction, it's still a tricky concept.
5. JK Rowling herself said that Cedric would have turned out evil anyway, so it's a good thing he didn't survive.
6. I still love JK Rowling and her work. I just.. it's not an actual book written by her. So... yeah...

author: Onikoroshi

I missed the relationships with everyone in the series, and while Albus and Scorpius kind of reminded me of Harry, Ron, and Hermione when they were kids, their adventures were somewhat lacking.

author: nicole
title: I miss the novels!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I haven't read that many plays, but I expected more with this. I expected more humor, more detail, more creativity. author: Spiral
title: Probably an ok play buuuut....
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
I am a longtime stalwart Harry Potter fan. Here's a short list of points/criticism/things to consider.
1. This was not written by Rowling. It is essentially a fanfic IMHO.
2. Read this from the perspective that this is a screenplay, and knowing it simply doesnt translate from literature to screenplay. If you dont understand what I mean, read the screenplays of the other HP canon. You will see much is lost without the fullness of explanation.
3. There's an incredibly convoluted plot of time shifting, which in a HP book or heck even a HP movie would be explained better by reading in a book or watching in a theater.
4. The characters don't always act like themselves. For example, Snape would use Veritaserum to determine Scorpius' true motivations. There are other examples but they are apparent as you read along. That being said, some interactions are bang-on and well staged. It feels more legitimate, like Dumbledore's heartfelt interactions with Harry through his Hogwarts headmaster portraits.

All the minor inconsistencies, convoluted plot and lack of character development lead up to a read which is in the main rather disappointing. It touched on topics that were heartfelt, but the playwrights couldn't seem to decide if it was character driven or plot driven. Overall, it might make a passible play, if it was full of audience impact. An interactive experience counts for a lot in that medium, and might go a long way to help clear up the confusing scene changes and plot twists. However, the book as it stands does not adequately introduce its new characters and truly make you care about Albus or Rose. Moreover, the canon HP characters were sort of placed into the play as if we should just know them -- bad form, even if we do, because then you don't even care about the new world order under the Dark Lord.

In summary, this could have been done much better. Although I will reserve final judgement until I can see the play, for now I am merely saddened by the lack of attention to detail.

author: T
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Thank You
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I'm not a die-hard HP fan/reader, but not quite casual either.  I've pre-ordered six out of the seven books, watched all the movies, spied on fans over at the Mugglenet forum over the years, and enjoyed talking about the series with other people.

One-two months ago, I was looking forward to this script play. I didn't really mind that this play wasn't written by Jo, herself, at that time, because she still gave it her approval. Wanted to give this new writer a benefit of a doubt, because who knows? Then, it came out on stage, and I started to hear mixed (non-spoilerage) reviews. The media press seemed to have gushed out positive things on the stage version, but the non-media people --- namely, HP fans ---- easily gave it constructive criticism that made me alarmed.

Familiar fan-fic/story tropes like:
- A lot of OCs (with inconsistencies)
- Time traveling (which can either can be good or bad, depending on how it's done. It went okay in the Chamber of Secrets, but here?)
- The non-original characters not acting like themselves.
- Questionable plot details

So, I pretty much agreed with their thoughts that it sounded like a Harry Potter fan-fic on stage. As someone, who writes both original and fan-fic stories, I can tell when story-telling goes awry. Especially, if you added in a ton of OCs, who you're not familiar with.

On top of this, this reminded me of Jo's last written HP book. Book 7's epilogue ending left a bitter taste in my moutb, because it felt like a fan-fic compared to the rest of the entire series. When a set of characters, you've grown to love, have an instant time skip and suddenly have kids....  It did feel a little cheesy, but I'm glad the film adaptation pulled it off better.

So, going back to Cursed Child... I pretty much held off buying this book, because of the mixed stage reception. As of today, July 31st, I've officially made my decision not to purchase the play thanks to a lot of reader reviews over here. I waited past midnight, and this morning, just to see everyone's reactions. I expected the reviews to be as mixed and polarized as it is. I still didn't even see the actual major spoilers,  but the general gist from what I'm getting out of your reviews...

To add to the list:

- Clichés
- Deus ex machina - The awful crux of storytelling. Used only as a plot convenience to end something quickly.
- Mary/Gary Sue - Depending on how it's written, I can sometimes be ok with these, but guess in this situation, it's not so nice.
- A lot of plot holes. Even for a stage play, you shouldn't really have these (or more than two) to have a good story. I've seen numerous Broadway, off-Broadway and non-musical stage plays. I never thought of "plot holes" in any of them. Even the ambiguous "Waiting for Godot" is done that way for a reason, so I don't think of "plot hole" within its playwright.
- Where's Harry Potter? All next gen kids, so, the name feels mis-leading on the non-originals taking a back seat. (Somewhat subjective, but understandable.)
- Didn't add anything too new or it's boring. (Likewise, all subjective statements.)

Understandably, there is suppose to be a novel updated version next year written up by Jo. So, I may look out for that, but I just can't get Book 7's epilogue off my mind. I live near NYC, but I'm not going to bat an eye for Cursed Child when it comes here. The up-coming "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" definitely looks good, and will super look forward to it.

I wish I can give a non-star neutral post, as someone who didn't buy the book so it may come off as an unfair review, but I felt compelled enough to write this as a concerned HP reader. Three out of five stars feel justified to make it neutral. If I really read it, I know I'll give it either a one or two stars rating.

So, even with Jo's involvement, I'm very much surprised that she allowed her baby to be touched by someone else. The movies were one thing. A new stage play that is said to be canon? I still recall the distant past when Jo had issues with HP fan-fiction.

Just the fundamental story writing no nos, alone, make the disappointment feel like I've seen it already. You can make the story very flashy and have energetic characters with various personalities, but when you have story + character inconsistencies visible enough on stage, you are seriously missing the heart of everything you loved about the original author's writing. :(

My only advice to others, should you come this far, is buy or rent/borrow the physical book. If you like it, that's fine, but if not, at least, you can get your money back if bought.

author: Kathryn Halbert
title: Passable Attempt
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: I just finished reading the book and while I enjoyed it well enough and I'm not sorry I bought it, it didn't wow me. There were problems. For instance, who exactly was this written for? People who read Harry Potter as a kid and liked it but don't remember it very well? Newcomers to Harry Potter will be confused due to the amount of required prior knowledge, while hardcore fans will be frustrated by the numerous plot holes and inconsistencies that other reviewers have already listed in depth. And I do feel like the play formatting hurt it as a reading experience. Without the visuals of a live performance or the detailed description of a novel, the more action filled and magical parts fell a bit flat. I was aware of what I was missing and it didn't fully come alive. The original books were average length to quite long, whatever it took to tell the story properly, while the Cursed Child was often choppy and abrupt. I was constantly aware of the time constraints inherent to making a play while reading it. I knew what I was buying and I'm cool with the idea of there being a play, but I think I'd be happier if they'd also put together a novel or even a novella and sold me that instead of the script. Some people will happily eat up anything Harry Potter and some people are really into theater, but I feel like it's a lot to ask of your audience to suddenly be cool with a huge time gap and a bunch of new characters and then add on a completely different style and formatting as well. Of the new characters, I liked Scorpius but was unimpressed with the villain of the piece. The dialogue sometimes felt forced and there were also moments when the boys just didn't sound their age at all.  So yeah...that' a fair bit of negative, but again, I did enjoy it alright. If you're a Harry Potter fan you should probably go ahead and satisfy your curiosity, just don't get your hopes too high.

author: Chip Crain
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
content: If this was a novel, rather than a screenplay, Jo Rowling could have created a more complete story with deeper storylines. It feels like more of a Cliff Notes version of Harry Potter than a novel, which it isn't of course. Perhaps seeing it performed would allow me to like it more.

author: Lauren O'Malley
title: A Lackluster Finale for the Golden Trio
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The nostalgia is quickly replaced by heartbreak as you realize how out of character and overly simplistic (and sometimes downright ridiculous) this story is.  Scorpio Malfoy is a delight and his relationship with Albus Potter carries the play, but even so I think I'd have preferred to leave Harry and the gang with the final words of The Deathly Hallows: "All was well."

author: Trisha Faulk
title: It would be easier as a book
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2017
content: This would be so much nicer to read as a regular book and not as a play manuscript. It was hard to follow at times because of it. And it would be so much better if you could get a better sense of what the settings were and the people were like. A play manuscript doesn't do that. It doesn't make you feel like you're there, mostly because the sets and actors do that. We're not at the play, so the read is lacking what most of the Potter books had. It would be better as a book, and but it would still be neat to follow Albus and Scorpius on further adventures, just in book form.

author: brownsugar21
title: Fell short of magical
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: *contains a few spoilers* I am a HUGE Harry Potter fan and could not contain my excitement for this book to come out. I also just finished the entire series (again)  to prepare for this book. I KNEW it would be a play, so it would be a little different. I tried not to go into the book with any expectations other than being excited to return to the Wizarding World, which was exciting enough. And it was... underwhelming. The beauty of HP and of JK is her ability to craft these amazing, complex, insightful, in depth characters with an intricate plot, which sucks you into their world. And because the formatting was a play, it was hard to be really immersed into the world and into the characters as in the original books. It all felt rushed and everyone felt underdeveloped, especially the new characters. I loved the friendship of Albus and Scorpious but it was also a bit flat and some of their character development was lost in the writing (or really lack there of)  JK Rowling is my favorite author, so I guess I missed the details of her writing through this format. Luna, Neville or Hagrid do not make an appearance through the book, boo! The ability to connect with the characters and really love them/ or even hate them in the original books is what made them so...magical. So, the book was okay, NOTHING compared to the original story where you really connected with the characters. I do hope the JK Rowling returns to Harry Potter, maybe the year after the battle when Harry, Ron and Hermione return to Hogwarts for their last year and how the battle impacted them all afterward. Love you JK Rowling and I hope you keep writing in the magical world, a full book would be great next time, because of course, I will always love Harry Potter. Always.

author: M. Berg
title: Hmmm,did I just read a faux HP book?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
Ok, everyone's pretty well covered what's right or wrong already. I agree, Rowling should've been the only author IF this was a novel. It's not, it's a script for what I imagine is a great play.  I hope she will decide to do a novelization because we would then get a full blown characterization of these people we've known and want to know better(i.e. The kids). Ron would've never been a magic/joke/trick store owner unless he took over the wands store or worked in the dept of magic development program for devices or such. I see Ginny as second in command in the ministry and I'm not being a feminist here, I'm simply seeing the strengths the women had in the original 7. I do see HP working through PTSD but c'mon he  comes across as a real whiner here!
I found the beginning and end better written and the middle section frustrating and just filler. It gets 3 stars because, face it, we got another HP book. Almost a 4 until that middle section bored me. It took me less than 4 hours to read so that was good- but that wasn't so good until I remembered, it's a script. Ms. Rowling, I hope you'll either put it in novel form or continue the story with further exciting adventures we are used to.

author: Travis A. Swafford
title: ... will be a difficult one because the bar for good is very hard to clear
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: Any installment in the Harry Potter world will be a difficult one because the bar for good is very hard to clear. It's hard to read something as a script and I might enjoy the actual play more, or even a book on tape. You just don't get the detail that you expect from a Harry Potter story. It's hard to connect with new characters, and the old ones never feel like they're written quite right. The plot has flaws, but it's still a decent story that I think any Potter fan will want to read. It's also a very quick read, easy to knock out in a day or two even for a slow reader like me. Just go in realizing it will NOT be like the books that you fell in love with the first time around and you will probably be able to enjoy it for what it is.

author: Maddie Calhoun
title: Not the Same Wizarding World We All Know and Love
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
content:
I have pretty mixed feelings about this one. As a lifelong Harry Potter fan (yep, I went to premieres, read the books a bunch of times, etc. Especially in my teen years, I was obsessed with the books. They easily shaped me into the person I am today), I was thrilled to hear about the publishing of this play. Never in my wildest dreams did I imagine I'd ever give anything with Rowling's name stamped onto the cover less than five stars. But, here I am. I did like the Cursed Child, but I didn't love it. After reading spoilers, I was skeptical going in. I think my expectations, while low, were met. The story itself was okay, but I was still disappointed at how much was left out and missed the magic that I felt whenever I read the other Potter books.

This review will probably be all over the place. As much as I hate to admit it, I do agree with the general critique that this play reads like fanfiction. For me, it's clear that Rowling did not actually write it. I thought the ending had a bit of her voice in it, but otherwise, it all read as if it were a story written by a teenage fan. The characters that I've grown up with did not sound like themselves. I realize that they would have aged by this point, but the dialogue still felt very forced. The trio, especially, was off. It wasn't terrible to the point where I immediately noticed it, but as the story went on, I constantly felt myself questioning how well I remembered them. I would stop and think, "That doesn't sound like something Hermione would say... Or am I just not remembering her tone well enough?" There were many subtle out of character moments.

To elaborate a little further, Harry Potter's character was completely off. I couldn't stand how the writers changed him. He turned into an angry, rude prick. Sure, the angsty fifth year Harry Potter might have yelled at Dumbledore, but I cannot imagine Harry as a full grown adult treating his elders  as he did here. His parenting was also just awful. Sure, he didn't have a father growing up, but he had plenty of father figures. At one point in the play, Harry says this:

"Most people at least have a dad to base themselves on--and either try to be or try not to be. I've got nothing--or very little. So I'm learning, okay?" (306)

I wanted to throw my book across the room and never pick it up again. I understand that James wasn't present in Harry's life, but he still had plenty of father figures to learn from. What about Sirius, Remus, Dumbledore, Hagrid, and even Arthur? I'd call those people father figures. To say Harry didn't learn anything from them is a pure insult to their characters. It made me so upset.

Hermione and Ron didn't feel like themselves, either. Hermione was present, but not as witty and intelligent as before. Ron turned into a sitcom dad. He was reduced to dumb jokes and felt so out of character (he sounded more like a George Weasley knock-off than anything). There were also so many great characters left out. Obviously there's only so much time in a play, and to acknowledge every single character from the series would be impossible, but I still expected some of the important ones to appear. Where was Hagrid? Luna? George? The list goes on. I was especially annoyed that Teddy Lupin didn't appear, because the epilogue of book seven made it seem as if Teddy had been heavily involved in both the Potter and Weasley households.

The children were actually okay. I loved Scorpius. He was fantastic. Albus was fine, as well. However, I couldn't quite get over the fact that he was so quickly abandoned and bullied at Hogwarts. I've been on Post Potter roleplay forums. There are Weasleys EVERYWHERE. I find it difficult to believe that Albus wouldn't have had some familial support. I don't care which House he's sorted into-- there's no way that someone wouldn't have reached out to him (over and over again at that, if he didn't respond initially). I also find it hard to believe that James was such a douche to him. James Sirius, Lily Luna, Hugo, and many other children didn't appear much in the play. It felt weird without them. Given the plot, they definitely should have been around more.

Character rants aside, the plot wasn't actually as bad as I had thought, after reading spoilers. It all somehow worked, with the exception of a few scenes. However, it was way too fast paced for a play. There was no down time. We didn't get to see the daily lives of the kids at Hogwarts or any of the magic of that world. The Potter books were always great, because they had drama, but also slower parts where we got to see the kids attempt to be kids. That didn't happen in this play. They tried to put in some comedic relief, but all of it was silly and out of place (it felt like a 90s sitcom).

While I do believe that the plot WORKED, it still felt unnecessary. I don't understand why the play had to go back in time. We've read the books before-- we know what happens. Going back was a nice trip down memory lane, but it was still cheap. I wanted to expand on the Wizarding World, not relive it (don't get me started on how THE ONLY JOBS that they acknowledged in this play were Quidditch and jobs at the Ministry. They referenced them so many times). Going back in time didn't hurt my image of the series, luckily, but it didn't bring anything new into it, either.

I could go on forever about my feelings about this play. I think a big problem with it is that it is just a play. I enjoy reading plays (I was a theatre kid growing up) and I'm sure this was awesome to see live. Reading it just condensed the plot into something that wasn't as deep and wonderful as the other Harry Potter literature. Also, I missed Rowling's voice so much. If she had written this story as an actual novel, I think it might actually have been pretty good. The plot, while a little far-fetched, would be so much better if it was just expanded upon.

In the end, this wasn't terrible. I should probably rate it two stars, but I'll leave it at three. There were some beautiful moments in this mess. I liked going back into the Wizarding World, but I still think it was unnecessary. This whole thing felt like a cheap attempt to bring back in fans. For me, it didn't work. There were many plot holes. Even the writers seemed to know that they were there, because every time a really obvious one came to mind, they literally addressed it in the script. But even their explanations fell flat. The play got better as it went on, but there were a lot of weird, out of character parts. I liked Albus and Scorpius. I wish we had gotten a true eighth story, about their adventures with the rest of their family members.

2.5/5 stars.

author: Angie Warren
title: A Disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2016
content:
How disappointing. Having established the Harry Potter series in the first 7 books, I'd come to expect a certain kind of storytelling. The characters from the first seven books portrayed in the Cursed Child did not fit the part, especially Ron. He came off as a complete idiot. Harry doesn't know how to be a father. Hermione is the closest adult to the child she played.
The play wouldn't have been so bad if it weren't for all of the time turning that took place. One time turn is okay, but several are just unnecessary. They played that theme to death.
I don't know...this is just not the quality of work I'd have expected from J.K. Rowling.

author: JBranh
title: Back in the World I Loved. Sort Of.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I fell in love with the book immediately... In the sense that nostalgia flooded back to me, desperately looking for the feeling of reading a brand new Harry Potter book again-- for the first time in 9 years.
When you get further in the book, however, you realize how much is missing. After all, it's written as a script. No descriptive paragraphs, no narration of Harry's inner thoughts.... Just dialogue. That loses a lot.
For years I have wondered how Jo would write another book. Would it be about Harry's kids? Harry's Parents? Random wizards? I personally think it would be difficult to grip the audience without the unique situation of Harry and Voldemort. My thoughts were confirmed by the direction of The Cursed Child. SPOILER---- the use of time-travel to characters and events from the original 7 Harry Potter books was a huge crutch to the imagination for the wizarding world. Most of the book was a "throwback".
I think it was painfully clear JKR was not the main author. From the way each character spoke, to the entire plot. It seemed like fan fiction. It was rushed, not extremely substantive, many things go unexplained.

I enjoyed getting a hint of the world I knew and loved as a kid. But next time, I hope it is a full-on book, written by Jo, and written with depth, passion, and detail.

author: Amanda T.
title: Instead of imagining the world of Harry Potter to be super deep and realistic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
It's hard for me to read a script without picturing actors stomping around on a stage.  I also read that the play itself had a lot of slight of hand as an interpretation of the magic.  Instead of imagining the world of Harry Potter to be super deep and realistic, I could only see a cheesy play.  I know it's incredibly difficult to get as deep as the novels when we are only reading dialogue and stage directions and maybe I would feel more enthusiastic if I were watching the play on the stage.  I felt the characters were off and the emotions I was meant to feel, I couldn't.  It was hard to connect and I think there was a lot of back story that would've made this more believable.  I don't think it's the worst idea to have a book about returning to the past, but I see two major issues with this story.

1. Slytherin is often thought of as the evil house, but is supposed to contain wizards with great leadership skills.  This tends to be why we see people like Snape and Draco being kind of power-driven. Snape is on a power trip in his classroom and Draco walks around like he owns the place with his goonies. The qualities they possess can also be shown as positive and Albus and Scorpius had a chance to show fans that Slytherin House occupants are also kind leaders.  I feel a great opportunity was missed.

2. How does Delphi come up with the conclusion that saving Cedric would change the world? And I have trouble believing that Cedric could ever become a death eater, no matter how embarrassed he may be.  I understand the idea behind linking "the spare," but still find this to be very unbelievable.

I think a lot more could've been done to bring Harry and his son closer together.  I think the Pensieve could've been used to help Albus understand his father by seeing more of him and achieving that flash back idea that connects the old plots with the new one.

I honestly think a movie would offer a better level of realism and stronger connection with the characters.  I think the lines of the main characters from the books we loved could be tweaked, but I think it really has more to do with delivery and that's hard to grasp from just a script.  As Potter fans we are used to depth, grand scenery, and strong characters.  This format doesn't give the same effect. I would love to see this as a novel written only by Rowling and maybe a move adaptation along the way.

I wouldn't have chosen this direction with the plot, but since Rowling has made this the 8th official book, I really hope a novel follows up to save this story from losing the feeling of the characters.

Although, plays are meant to be watched.  Perhaps I am missing something.

author: A.Rose.Burns
title: not really developing things as well as I would have liked, and the characters didn't really feel like the
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content: To be honest, it seemed to jump around quite a bit, not really developing things as well as I would have liked, and the characters didn't really feel like the originals

author: Shay
title: I wanted to love this book!
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2019
content:
Soooo.... There is a lot I could say about this book. For starters, it is not the 8th book. Please, please stop calling it that. That's pretty much saying that any popular HP fan fiction could be classified as a plausible book in the series. They aren't. Some are amazing! But they are NOT books in HP.
I don't appreciate that they didn't do proper character study when approaching this. Too many personalities changed too much. Before anyone starts on the whole "19 years later" thing I KNOW! But that doesn't excuse the portrayal of everyone. Just because something is years into the future doesn't mean that the initial characters should be changed that drastically!
The best thing you can do is to separate this book from the HP series and you may be able to appreciate it for that. Think of it more like a bizarre AU. So much of this play doesn't quite add up with what we HP fans already know about the world.

That being said, I didn't hate it but I clearly didn't love it either. I can appreciate what they have done and the fact that they brought something inspired by HP to life on stage! It's impressive! I wish I could actually see the play. Reading stage directions in a book is one thing but being able to see it is another. I love plays. Maybe it would improve my overall opinion of this book.

Look, I understand why it's being heralded as the 8th book. I get why it is a hit. I get why it's praised so highly. Yet for me, I cannot get over the inconsistencies. I wanted to love this book! I wanted to heap joyous proclamations of it's existence to anyone who would listen! I wanted to do these things! But this script has failed me. It simply doesn't give me enough to love and praise.

author: Kathy Eckhardt
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Not up to par with Harry Potter series.

author: Siameezer
title: Read it.... But be prepared for the format and lack of satisfying writing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
This is, of course, a must-read for anyone who loved the Harry Potter stories.  That said, it's clearly NOT written by JK Rowling.  And, being formatted as a screenplay, it misses SO much of the satisfying detail of the original seven books.  The amazing wordplay is totally lacking.  Often, the words and phrases of characters we know and love seem.... foreign.  So many times, I found myself saying.... there is no way he (she) would have actually said that.

For the first 1/3 or so of the 'book'.... I actually hated it.  I almost quit reading it, which of course NEVER happened in any other book of the series.  However, after your mind accepts the bare-bones format, and accepts that you won't get the satisfying writing and word play.....  the story is good.  It's convoluted and complicated, and really, at some level, pretty satisfying.  It does feel like it could have been a continuation of the story.  I found some major flaws in the story (like.... that could NOT have happened... didn't they consider the limitations of....... kind of thing).  But, overall, I'm glad I read it and enjoyed it.

I would have MUCH rather waited longer and gotten a REAL story from JK Rowling herself.  But, I'd still suggest reading this if you loved the Harry Potter books.  Just... prepare yourself for superficial - something you've never gotten from Rowling before.

content: It's HP so I was thrilled to get more of the story, but it doesn't come close to the original story. I was very disappointed in what they turned Ron into, the story felt a little forced and I left the story unclear on who exactly the cursed child was.

author: Ashok G
title: Just OK!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016
content:
I have been a big fan of the books, and was eagerly waiting for this book. Though already knew that the format was screenplay, expected more substance. This book lacks the depth that the other HP books have. There isnt sufficient effort given to develop the character, to explain the situations or circumstances which form Albus Severus's personality. The situations seem forced, and the plot itself was very predictable!
Was also very disappointed with they way they shaped Hermoine's character.
It was not an utter waste, as at least it made me nostalgic about the earlier books but definitely not worthy of an HP series!

author: Texcee
title: Just a So-So Story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
I have just finished "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child", the published script of the play currently on stage in London. My rating? I'm giving it about 2-1/2 stars out of 4. The story picks up exactly where "Deathly Hallows" leave off, on the platform by the Hogwarts Express. The play revolves almost entirely around Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy. A good deal of the storyline takes a look at the estrangement between Harry and Albus, and that of Draco and Scorpius. Both of the boys are lonely, losers, and burdened with the legacy of their famous fathers, especially Albus. There is a convoluted time travel plot that weaves throughout, and a new villain who I had figured out by the second act, although the exact identity of who this person is remained a mystery until the fourth act.

I am perfectly conscious of the fact that this is play, not a novel, but my overall impression is that it is simplistic, one of shallowness and an almost juvenile plot. That is not necessarily a bad thing. After all, "Sorcerer's Stone" and "Chamber of Secrets" are essentially kids' books and the story doesn't start getting really dark until "Azkaban." The main characters are, after all, young teenagers. However, all of the adults in the story are almost shadows or parodies of their former selves. They mainly wander through the scenes with nothing much to do, or agonize over their parenting skills (which suck, IMHO). There are WAY WAY WAY too many "cameos" by past characters, again who seem to put in an appearance simply to satisfy the fans. It drags down the story. My take on the plot is that it's not very well written fanfic. A good editor would have cleaned this mess up. In fact, if the story had been submitted to one of my fanzines, I probably would have rejected it.

As for the structure of the play itself, it seems to consist of two minute scenes that contain a few snippets of dialogue, some special effects, and frantic background changes. There are so many changes of location (presumably with scenery and set dressing), that I cannot fathom what it must have cost the play's producers in backgrounds alone. Of course, I have not seen the play, so I am only going on reading of the script to imagine this. The play is divided into two separate productions, each two acts long. IMHO, it could have been rewritten as one 3-1/2 hour or so play and smoothed out a lot.

 And one final comment about the play. There is one major question that remains unanswered after all is said and done -- who exactly is the Cursed Child? Albus Potter? Scorpius Malfoy? The new villain with the shocking and evil background? I suppose it's up to us to decide.

author: Debra Frisco
title: I wasn't able to use the accents that make the characters so fun. We'll keep reading just to know what happens
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I am reading Harry Potter books out loud to my Grandson.  We jumped ahead to read the Cursed Child, but I soon found that in play form it was nearly impossible to find a flow. It was stilted, and lacking depth. Because I was trying so hard to determine who said what, I wasn't able to use the accents that make the characters so fun. We'll keep reading just to know what happens, but I wish she would re-release in novel form.

Story had a couple good twist but the end was what I expected.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It's... Not Bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2016
content: Well, it's more of the same, but written to be performed as a 3 hour play, so there is a lot less of it. The character chemistry was really the highlight of HPATCC. I found the characters afinity (or antipathy) to be surprisingly palpable and both of our two new young heroes, Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy, are quite engaging in their own right. The plot is servicable if a bit same-y. The only real failing - and I can not overstate the magnitude of failure here - is that despite ostensibly revolving around the misadventures Albus and Scorpius, the story is never really theirs. Rather than being given their own 20-years-later version of the Potterverse to pluckily fumble about in, they are cordially invited to join our other Potter favorites in their world, under the strict guidelines that no matter how much stage time they get, Harry is the star. Some element actually feel like a late season TV clip show, with the characers emotionally retreading their pasts, pasts that we have already experienced with them. Some fans may be interested in the day-to-day domestic trials of the Boy Who Lived, or in revisiting the 80s and 90s with the HP gang, but I am not that fan; and with all the untapped potential energy of Albus, Scorpius, and Rose Granger-Weasley, I feel like HPATCC is a missed opportunity.  I would not go so far as to recommend against reading HPATCC, but as HP canon goes, it is a cutesy, disposable light read, and nothing more.

author: Denise
title: Not on par with the others

author: Nicole Levesque
title: 2016 Fantasy/Play Recommended for anyone who didn't love the original books I ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child: Parts One and Two
by J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany & Jack Thorne
Arthur A. Levine Books, 2016
Fantasy/Play
Recommended for anyone who didn't love the original books

I don't have much I want to share on this. I wish I hadn't read it, that's sort of the extent of it. I wanted so much more from my reunion with the original characters. I do NOT think scripts are my preferred style of writing. I want the meaty descriptions, not some stage notes. Aside from that, the story was flatter than I'd hoped for as well. The idea is excellent, the execution fell flat for me.

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: I guess i have to acknowledge that this is a script.  I am sure that the play will be a success, however I can see the disappointing aspect of this story. There really isn't any likeable characters in this story.  Harry is cruel at times. Albus plays the victim like every other teenager.

author: Kristina James
title: is full of disappointment in many ways
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: As a 90s kid with a big heart and a bigger passion for reading, the Harry Potter series has been an almost tangible part of my life. It is with some regret that I must admit that this play, written as such, is full of disappointment in many ways. As a student of dramatic writing, I was excited to see the world I loved be set forth under the intimacy and the magic that the drama form allows. Regretfully, I found the Cursed Child to be repetitive and empty in its plot construction. Much of the characters seemed to be shadows of their book selves, or just a beat off of who I knew them to be. Much of the action and spectacle of the play relies on the audiences ability to see it live and preformed which, especially in my opinion, shouldn't be necessary to the enjoyment of the play as a whole. I enjoyed reading the play simply for the thrill of seeing these familiar names once again on new pages, and appreciated a lot of the information given about Albus Potter, and the fates of the next generation. I suggest fans give it read with a guarded mind; this isn't the work of our plot-master JK Rowling, or even the characters as we know them best, but it is a reminder of the beloved past, and will satisfy the longing- if only until Fantastic Beasts comes out.
