author: Timinoh
title: A flat and disappointing reading experience
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content: I confess that I wanted to like this book the way I liked all the others.  Time travel backwards into the previous scenes created by Rowling in past books seemed a convenient way for her to avoid to avoid allowing outsiders to mess up her masterfully created fictional world. I liked the new characters' angst, but the story seemed to depend too much on that and not enough on real suspense. I have read many time travel stories and this one was not particularly  original or ingenious, particularly because the places the visited were already places I'd been to in the first 7 books. I likely expect too much from a play script after a steady diet of Rowling's masterful narratives in her 7 consecutive Harry Potter books. This script ready-made for movie land, and I'm sure I will enjoy it on the big screen, but I found the script reading experience flat and unexciting.

author: Marta Saylors
title: An entertaining read while you're reading it...
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.

  The first review I saw was by a 10 year old who sped read it and gave it a 6/10 rating.  I wasn’t thinking of being that harsh, but upon reflection, I’d have to concur for similar and differing reasons.  First I will say, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is an entertainment.  You will most likely enjoy reading it and think it was fun.  The issue comes with reflection.  Now, the majority of Harry Potter fans are, I would dare say, a reflective lot.  I bought my copy at a midnight book party with costume dress and trivia leading into the purchase hour.  One of the trivia questions asked, “What was Harry Potter’s Mother’s maiden name?”  I have no Idea.  But there are Potter fans that know this.  And with this book, they should know they are getting a script of a West End play.  An entertainment.

  Myself, I started reading the Harry Potter series of books after the first movie came out.  I saw Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone, and then picked up a copy of The Chamber of Secrets to read.  I read the rest of the books and saw the movies as they came out.  And, to be honest, I haven’t actually finished reading the original one, since I had seen the movie.  I have saved it to read with my child, and as we read it, I’m continually surprised by the addition of things I didn’t know – the differences from having only seen the movie.

  The first flaw, I have with the book/script,  is that that is exactly what it is.  If you see the play, there is no need to get the book/script.  If you read the script – as I said, it is an entertainment and you will probably very well want to see the play in its original intended version.  The pictures on the internet did look amazing.  But releasing this as a definitive addition to the Harry Potter mythology, I feel, breaks the nice symbiosis that the movies and books had with each other.  The movies are great, they’re awesome, they’re a visual masterpiece that manages to capture the soul and intention of the book as well as it can.  And you can always go back to the book and enjoy the parts they omitted for the sake of getting it to the screen in a bit over 2 hours.  In this book/script, what is omitted does not exist.

  The final scene from the original Harry Potter series takes a leap 19 years into the future.  It lays down 19 years of “not much going on here – scar not hurting” and ages our protagonists to the point where they are able to have their own families and “enjoy” a “normal” existence.  In a world as robust as the one Rowling created – I felt a little jipped.  I thought there was loads of room, in that interim, for stories to take place in this world that would stand on their own 2 feet.  And even though the Fantastical Beast Movie is to take place before the Potter era, Rowling has already expanded the historical lore and mythology of her world to accommodate the entry of this piece.

  So, If we can swallow and concede that 19 year period, as we must, this is where the Cursed Child starts.  And it starts exactly at this point, on the platform of 9 ¾ with the new generation of Potters, Weasleys, Graingers and Malfoys boarding the Hogwarts express.  The book/play exists within the next 4 years.  Taking it for what would be a fourth year setting – which coincidentally would be the Goblet of Fire year - feelings and conflicts that developed and molded the original Potter protagonists in 4 books and 4 movies – occur in the span on a one book/two part play.  And with that, the playwright uses up 4 years of what could be rich character development.

  In place of this development, the play really does rely on the audience to bring the beloved book/movie series with them as supplement.  Rowling said in her farewell to the Potter series.  “So, I never wanted to write another novel, but this will give the fans something special.” That is, at times, what this book/script feels like.  It feels a bit like fiction specifically for a fan.  Albeit, entertaining fan fiction.  It brings in the beloved characters, even ones long, long dead.  And they make their way across the stage to have their curtain call.

  It is not, admittedly, as simple as that.  There are some special things in it.  There is a scene on the Hogwarts express that develops a character in a crazy and amazing way.  There is a friendship among the two main protagonists that will really make you wish you had a book series to go back to in order to get the full effect.  And one series original bad guy is fleshed out and matured in a way I think many fans will like.  But the story plays in the Potter Universe, it doesn’t essentially expand it.  And that was the brilliant aspect of each book.  Each book grew the universe in a unique and ingenious way, introducing small aspects that would eventually play into the grand conclusion.

  The play/book is entertaining, and I think even the strongest critic may be able to honestly pull out something they thought was interesting, exciting or nice to see.  But as an endorsed conclusion to the series, it felt a bit like a hasty farewell.

author: Jennifer Tiao
title: SPOILER ALERT!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Just as the number of stars indicate, it's okay. If you really want to read it, then I don't think you'll be able to resist buying it even if you've heard whispers of discontent about the plot.

I think it's pretty fair to say JK Rowling was pretty clear that this wasn't a full out novel, it's just the published script of the play in London. So my review is not because I thought I was mislead. I was extremely aware this was the script.

My quip is with the storyline itself. It's pretty clear after a few scenes in, you realize there's very little to JK Rowling's actual writing style, but you're curious enough anyway to continue reading to see how the story progresses. Obviously, it's not going to read like a novel narrative, and the story is told through conversations that are happening in very specific situations.

There are the obvious moral undertones to the story.
- The Father/Son Dynamic between Harry/Albus, Draco/Scorpio and all the torrential feelings when a parent is trying to understand their child.
- Going back in time to change the past doesn't necessarily make for a better future

And things of that sort. So the story line does have some depth to it, and there's that moment of small gratification that Severus gets.. and it's satisfying for a person that's always been a fan of his character.

But otherwise.. the rest of the plot just leaves you head scratching. How time turners are used in the Cursed Child vs in the original series is different. And there's a huge focus on time travel, and it's kind of disorienting. I appreciate the flashbacks of the original story line, but I'm here for NEW material.

And really.. the biggest thing I had a problem with was the love child of lord voldemort and bellatrix. Really? We just had to go there? Trying to imagine the lord of absolute darkness and evil, the person who was willing to split his soul into 7 pieces, an indiscriminate murder who's M.O was strictly for finding revenge on HP and returning to power, having a love child in the middle of all that? And yes, I've heard the argument that he would've wanted an heir, but clearly, if he could survive in Prof. Quirrell's head, would immortality really be an issue for him? Would an heir actually be necessary? The whole prospect seemed pretty absurd to me.

All in all.. I was just left confused and just wondering... why?

author: Kelly B.
title: Wished for something better!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2016
content: Fans of J. K. Rowling's massive popular Harry Potter series have begged for more to the Harry Potter series. With Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, we have received exactly what we asked for. It was nice to see all the characters that I have grown to love come back and tell some more of their story. While it was nice to learn more about what happened with Voldermort during the Battle for Hogwarts, the story went by too fast. One of the major things that bothered me was the format of the story. Since it was in a scrip format, the story took a couple of hours to read and didn't have the same writing skill that I have come to know and love with Rowling's writings. I would have much preferred to see the story in prose instead of a script. I miss so much of the detail because of the format the story was delivered in. As for the plot, it reminded me of Charles Dicken's A Christmas Carol with issues for the future. I would like to see Rowling turn this script into a novel, then it would be something I would cherish and add to my prized Harry Potter collection. I still think fans of Harry Potter should read this book. It feeds our thirst for more of the magical world.

author: Louise R.
title: but it's not a masterpiece like the other books
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
content: As so many other people my age I grew up with the HP books and reading the newest addition to the HP universe did make me feel a little nostalgic. Obviously as a true HP fan I had to buy it, but it's not a masterpiece like the other books. To be fair, it's a screenplay and it's not necessarily meant to be read but watched, which I have taken into account in my review. But the story has some obvious plot holes and timelines that just don't add up. The first few pages were fast paced and the story line irritiated me so much I even stopped reading it for a few days. But it did get better towards the end and it gives you a glimpse into what could have happened, if a few things had been different. It's entertaining enough but probably only really enjoyable to die hard HP fans.

author: Travis Messina
title: A script, REALLY?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: While we're sure this will be a good play, it was a disappointing book.  It lacked the extra 300 pages of JK's incredible imagination and excellent sense of humor in most of the story.  Our family has lived and breathed the Harry Potter series for ten years and we did not enjoy this book, especially with the extra authors.  Can we please have the story published in a format not adapted for the stage?

author: Shell
title: Being written as a play made it less enjoyable. ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2017
content: Being written as a play made it less enjoyable.  The story line wasn't as appealing as the original Harry Potter Series.

author: S. F. K.
title: Not required reading for Harry Potter fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
This book made me sad.  I love all the Harry Potter books.  Or at least I did.  I wish I had skipped this one.
The books starts as the Epilogue of book 7.  Probably copied word for word.  We already know who married who and who the kids are.  But that was ok.  The real problem is how stupid and contrived everyone is.  The "old" characters (Harry, Hermione, Ron) are caricatures of their childhood selves.  Harry and Hermione really have those positions at 40 years of age?  Ron is bumbling idiot.  I hated seeing these guys reduced to these boring people.  The new characters are just as bad.  Albus and Scorpius are whiners.  That is really all I can say about them.
What would have been great would have been to continue the story with the "old" characters and to really fill them out.  Or to pretty much exclude them all together and only concentrate on the kids.  It felt like character development was in short supply.  Yes, I know it is a play.
The story itself is interesting and a lot could be done with it.  Too bad all the the sappy, whiney characters got in the way.

author: Melissa @thereaderandthechef / @yabookscentral IG Manager
title: Reads like a fanfic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I never thought there would come the day where I would be reviewing a new Harry Potter book. Not a new edition, but actually an eighth novel. For that, I was tempted to rate it 5 stars before actually reading the book because it's HARRY POTTER, the boy who lived! Even though this book wasn't written entirely by J.K. Rowling, the fact that she supervised its production was enough for me to already love it and, of course, wish to apparate to London to watch the play.

But now that I've actually read it, I can clearly say two things:

a) I LOVE SCORPIUS MALFOY SO MUCH.

and,

b) Despite that it is the "eighth" Harry Potter novel, it doesn't quite feel like Harry Potter.

It's not that I didn't enjoy the book (I sort of did), but the magical feeling I used to get when reading a new HP book was almost non-existent. I know lots of readers say it's because of the script format, but that wasn't my case at all. It had more to do with what happens to the characters, how they have developed over all these years, and a few other things that were definitely too far-fetched (and totally bonkers) to belong in an HP book. And by far-fetched/bonkers I mean so many WTF moments that fellow readers actually warned me about.

HOWEVER, all the silliness of Cursed Child made me laugh out loud constantly. I couldn't help it, it was just too much. So despite it all, I enjoyed it. After my initial shock, rage, and disappointment, somewhere around the middle of the book I allowed myself to relax and think that everything I was reading was nothing more than a reaaaaally small gift for us readers from the HP world.

With that said, I won't tell more about it in fear of spoiling the book (because trust me, just the minor detail spoils a lot) but I will say that the only thing that is like HP, and what readers WILL probably enjoy, is the friendship that blooms between Albus (Harry's son) and Scorpius (Malfoy's son). I liked it. And Scorpius Malfoy more than anything else because he is the one that steals the spotlight in this book. He's very well the reason why everyone should read Cursed Child.

Final Verdict:

In other words, Harry Potter and the Curse Child is basically like a J.K. Rowling approved fanfic, nothing more. At least, that's how it felt like to me. So if you are looking for a mind-blowing and powerful novel at the same level of the other HP books, then I'm afraid you'll be terribly disappointed. And a bit ragey? Maybe a lot.

And yet, I do suggest reading it because it's a short read and you all have to be in the loop anyway. Don't let peeps tell you! Check it out of the library if you don't want to pay so much for a copy (it IS quite expensive and not that worth it). But you do have to meet Scorpius Malfoy one way or another. You have to meet him. So do it for him, okay? Good. :)
4 likes ·

author: esizz
title: RIP Albus Severus Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content: I can't give it less than three stars because it's a Harry Potter book but to say I was impressed with the book would be a lie. Not surprised though, you can't add on to something that's a legend.

author: Alyssa
title: The script-style of writing made it fairly easy to read through quickly
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content:
"We haven't become anything — we simply are as we are."

I wasn't one of the people lined up at midnight to get the book, but I was interested to see where JK Rowling pictured the story going for the next generation.

The script-style of writing made it fairly easy to read through quickly. We get a feel for the characters and what's changed and yet there's a lot of overlap with what we saw in the books/movies. It felt like a lot of re-used material and things thrown in that we've already seen. Once or twice would have been enough, but it felt like a lot was things that already happened. In fact, that's basically the premise of the book.

And it's heartbreaking that so few characters have moved on from the lives they had back at Hogwarts in the '90's, but I just didn't love this book. There are some nice insights and I liked how Scorpius and Draco's relationship mirrored Harry and Albus's. I think had it been a story that focused on family alone it could have been really great.

But to have pretty much every character have a child to have a next generation of kids (and to send them all to Hogwarts!)  this story was so ambitious in trying to cram everything in it just tried to much in too little space.

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content: Interesting plot, but I felt some personality components of certain characters were inconsistent with those from the original series. For instance, Ron's sort of bumbling, almost insecure nature in this reading made no sense against his teenage self. Looks as if marrying Hermione really turned him into a wuss. Also Harry seems to have lost some personal fortitude over the years. There are points in the cursed child that Harry feels a little too ordinary and thin compared to his younger days. Overall, I would say that the storytelling itself is inferior to the original Potter books. Perhaps some sacrifices were made to adapt the story as a play, but it made for a somewhat disappointing read. Still, it had a lot to live up to.

author: Sarapedia
title: I suppose I would like it on stage or screen more, because the notes explain so much of the action it takes away from the story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content:
I am one of the huge Harry Potter fans, and credit J.K. Rowling with creating a place where most of us would have liked to sample. The fluidity of her books and to a lesser degree the moves actually transported us to every location in and out of the wizarding world. I also saw at the end of the last story a different path. And as much as my creativity and writing in know ways  compares to Ms. Rowling. I would have rater seen development of some of he the other  characters; like Luna Love good or Neville Long bottom than to tear away at the Legend of Harry Potter. I understand there are few really happy endings in the real world, this one took the long way to arrived and was somewhat anticlimactic. Delphi was a Red Herring, And I don't like Red Herring it is a somewhat lazy way to get to the heart of the story.  I also believe Albus picking someone more likely than not is a bit of a stretch after vocally voicing his fear just at the mere idea of becoming a Slitheren moments before there was more of a relationship. He spoke to his dad rather than his mum. I understand father and sons frequently have daddy issues as much or more than women, but this wasn't how it was left in Deathly Hallows.  For all intentions totally ignored the the Epilogue of the final book.
I admit I am a purest and a stickler for details and continuity, and this story had very little. I was thrilled to see another Harry Potter story, but it is hard to believe a man who clearly had always wanted a family, a life time of abuse, could have followed a number of paths to swear not to be anything like Vernon and Aunt Petunia, cruel, cold and making his life of misery, and be the best father possible, not cruel and cold. I know parents make lots of mistakes, I lived through my fair share. And I know it is as painful as mothers and daughters, and men hide their feeling more I know all that rubbish. At sometimes you accept them for who they are. And there many things worse than a famous Father, with all the perks that come with that. Scorpius put him in his place and I liked. It was more contrived and had the feeling that the special set and effects held too high a priority. It was a quick read, and I am sure every person regarding them self as the book already. I know grown up that I am, that I stood in line at real bookstores to get my at Midnight special openings, but this was just unnecessary to bring us back to show how flawed Harry was and  his son that had precisely Lily's eyes, and what was in the  ending of Deathly Hallows story Albus Serverus was afraid and waited to speak with his father alone not his mum. Dad would understand guy stuff. Even wizard's guy stuff. It didn't take too my much of my time so I say read  probably more  than 50% will probably love it.

author: Chris Stevens
title: ehh
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: Maybe my expectations were too high.  Maybe it was the format.  Either way, the worst of the Potter stories -- but still fairly good.

author: Befortfamily
title: Wanting more
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: Wish she had taken the time to see this story into book from. Throughout the book I felt like this story could have been so much more potterlike if only jk hadn't rushed to make another million off of a quickly written play.

author: theashoxford
title: One Dimensional Characters
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content:
** spoiler alert ** I was so excited for more Harry Potter but I sure would have liked to have seen Harry during all the times I'm sure he was being a good dad rather than this time of being a cruddy parent. I also did not like how Ron, Hermione and Draco were written as such extreme versions of themselves. Like could Ron have been any dumber?! I do see how he could have been comedic relief in a play but it didn't read well on paper.

The highlight for me was the villain, Delphi. I liked hearing about her backstory with Voldemort. I was also surprised when she was revealed not for just being a bad guy, which I saw coming, but for how she became bad.

I give the book 3.5/5 stars but rounded down from how much I disliked them making Ron so one dimensional.

author: Teyanna Necole
title: Jo Write Fan-Fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: It was great returning to Hogwarts! I loved revisiting characters from so long ago. Unfortunately, there were some plot points that were a bit juvenile in creativity and completely contradictory to the HP series canon. The screenplay read easily enough like a book and I was alway reminded that it was such when there was a reference to someone leaving the stage. Overall, I enjoyed the screenplay and believe that reading it was better than seeing it live. I highly recommend for any serious HP fans, but those who only watch the movies can pass on this.

author: Colleen
title: most of it I liked..
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2016
content: most of it I liked... some of it I didn't. I didn't feel like J.K Rowling had anything to do with this. it felt more like a fan fiction to me. but other than that I liked it.

author: Aycie
title: Good plot; script doesnt sate for character development
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content: This play script plot is interesting and captivating. However Harry Potter novel fans crave character development since its the characters they love. The genre is somewhat limited. It relies heavily on its popularity to supplement that absent quality. In its place is a moral quality that reads more preachy than her normal writings, about the dangers of stereotyping. The adult angst is more about unmet childhood needs than quality storytelling. Its a good play, but her writings are great. And her stories are better than this. Her characters all have flaws but these overly discussed moral flaws dont touch our hearts the way her storytelling does and it sounds more like a therapy reenactment at times than a relationship.  No one wants a stereotyped Harry Potter, but perhaps thats the best that can be achieved in a play script. We cant hear his complex thinking or feel the sublties of ambivalence and shifting thoughts. Overall its good but far less mature than JK Rowlings' stories.

author: Nicole Angerstein
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2016
content: Good for a quick read

author: Deb Albritton
title: Just not fulfilling
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2016
content: I have loved every book in this series and was so very excited for this final piece of the masterful puzzle. I very much enjoyed the characters including the old favorites but also the next generation but this format was just not as fulfilling for me as reading a novel. It felt like it ended abruptly without full satisfaction to the reader. In fairness to J K Rowling this was written to be performed not necessarily to be read. I truly hope I can have the opportunity to see it performed in the near future. However it still felt wonderful to reconnect with those literary friends and reenter into the wonderful wizarding world of the Potter universe!

author: Justin M. Woodward
title: Harry Potter in the cringey cringe
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
Seriously. This is s***. But it's s*** covered in a fine candy coating. Meaning, I couldn't wait to buy it and read it and go back to that world, but that's the trick isn't it? They have our money already, they always would. But, oh well. We knew we had to read it so what is there to say about it?

Well, the name Scorpius is downright godawful, cringeworthy every time I read it.

A lot of the dialogue was cheesy as hell! People getting mad and saying cliches like "you won't get away with this!" I don't know it was just annoying A LOT of the time.

The pros? It's Harry Potter. That's about it.

1.5 stars for story + 1.5 stars for nostalgia.

Pick up the book (Fantastic Beasts is in a 3 book set along with the book on Quidditch and the short bedtime stories) and read up on the Beasts before watching the movie and you will be able to recognize Newt's Beasts as they're introduced in the movie. author: Lee
title: For some, possibly better borrowed than bought.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: It's not news at this point, this does fall short of the standard set by the previous stories in the series. I'd be crushed if I didn't have faith that we'll see a return to form in the new film series. As others have said, the characterization too frequently feels wrong, and too much of the past is revisited. It just isn't inspired. There are lots of spells but no magic. The live experience may make up for at least some of the script's shortcomings, though, and I do still hope the stage show comes to America. Likewise, I hope for more Harry Potter stories in the future, set farther in the future. Let's leave Harry's past well behind and see him move beyond You Know Who.

The original characters weren't true to themselves at all, and the new characters weren't well developed.  The story itself wasn't nearly as clever and well thought out as the original series.  I wish I had realized going in that JK didn't write this herself.  It doesn't sound like her at all.

author: Gigi
title: It will give you the fan "fix" of getting to spend time with your favorite characters again
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I'm a Harry Potter fan and have reread the books more than once or twice. I was very excited about this next installment of the story. This is no where near her in depth stories with details that put you in the moment. It will give you the fan "fix" of getting to spend time with your favorite characters again. However, after finishing the book, I feel let down by the lack of substance and that is probably partially due to it being a play and not a book. The story could have been developed better and had potential to be a great book but because it was not developed fully as a book and had to be put in a play it lacked a lot of the feeling you get while reading a Harry Potter book. I guess the best thing about the story is that you got to be with the characters again and had a glimpse into their new world.... That is about it.

author: h.kosti
title: Eh. *shrugs*
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
content: I've read some fan fics on the internet that have been better than this story. Although I realize the format is for theater, I don't think it changes the overall quality of the story. There were some elements I liked and expected, however there were some plot twists that just seemed utterly ridiculous and something out of like an alternate universe. While I realize, it was not written by JK, I was hoping it would still have more of her thoughtful tones, but I was disappointed. It's a quick, easy read, and I'm not sure if I recommend it.

author: jackie
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2016
content: Don't get much of a feel of Harry Potter, It's a play and not all that interesting.

author: Yigit Cinar
title: After all these years...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2016
content:
After all these years, it was very nice to get a held on this book, even if it is a script.

Reading is not so easy if you are not used to reading plays or similar kind of documents but story is amazing.

author: Jacqui Voland
title: Not as good as the original series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: Had very high expectations, and was a bit disappointed. The characters were not a well-developed and the story line seemed a bit far-fetched.

author: RT
title: did not like
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017
content: i did not like this book and i think its not good like the other books because the characters weren't the same and allmost every thing was ridiculous and didn't make sense.

author: Kay Hightower
title: Feels like fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2017
content: While the story is interesting, I found the actions and lines of the characters did not fit who we have known them to be based on the original series. It did not feel like it belonged in the Harry Potter universe and felt more like mediocre fan fiction. JK Rowling signed off on it so I accept what is said and done as Cannon, though reluctantly.

author: Paisley
title: Good not great...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Contains spoilers!
As an avid HP fan I was ecstatic that we would finally be getting new material in the the world. I read this book in less than 3 hours. While I thought the story itself was fantastic - I was disappointed on the format. JK Rowling is an author, not a playwright. It almost reads as really good fan-fiction. We are missing the great detail and imagery that JK is so great at describing. After 9 years I was hoping to be immersed into the world again and was sadly disappointed that I was only about half way there. I'm sure that this stage play is excellent, but it was almost like seeing a decent movie before reading an excellent book.
Oh, but how I did love learning about the original HP characters as adults and their children. Harry, Ron, and Hermionie haven't changed much since we last saw them. Even more so, I love the Albus/Scorpius dynamic! Getting to know Draco's son and by extension learning about Draco in a new light was so refreshing. The end of Deathly Hallows showed us that the Malfoy's, above all, value family. It was sad to read that his wife died and he was left to raise a son on his own the best he could. It's so sweet to see that Draco chose a more loving path versus his own more competitive and pressured upbringing that his father gave him. I would have loved to learn more about this little family.
I did not understand the line drawn with Albus wanting to become involved in helping the Cedric death. It did not make sense to me. and why did they decide to go to eat individual task in the Tri Wizard Tournament to mess him up when it was the final task that he actually meets Voldemort? That doesn't make any sense to me. It just felt like they were doing whatever they could to tie in something from every book... It didn't seem clear enough why Albus wanted to get involved when the story was presenting him as a moody, Slytherin teenager. Why help with something in his father's past? A father he was mad at?
It was nice to see that the Dursley's had a small role to play in this, that Dudley sent Harry the blanket he arrived in as a baby as Privet Drive. It would be nice to see their reunions and communication to develop this relationship.
It was, however, farfetched to believe that Bellatrix is the mother of Delphi, as she is the daughter of Voldemort. I recall from the original books Bellatrix was so loyal to Voldemort that she was in love with him. How was a pregnancy concealed and what exactly was the timeline involved? Bellatrix was already a crazy person so is that why no one suspected a pregnancy? How was he even able to reproduce? The guy doesn't even have a nose... There are a lot of questions that I would like answered here.
All in all, I was happy with the story but definitely would like the rest of the questions answered. And would love to see a series spin-off with Albus Potter to continue the journey!

author: Emilee
title: Fan fiction Theory
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
content: Alright, so the kicker here is that it's not everything everyone made it up to be. We were all expecting/hoping/praying for it to be the eighth book in the series, to continue on our childhood, however, it got blown way out of proportion. While it reads well, and has an intriguing theory, it's nowhere near the quality of writing we came to expect from J.K herself. It's a well wrote fan fiction, that is really just a theory. Read it- if you loved the Harry Potter series, really read it, but don't expect it to be the answers to your prayers because it's not. If you can get past that, then you'll probably enjoy it.

author: Jodihuff
title: Probably not the best genre for a story this size
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I couldn't wait to get my hands on this new story even while questioning the genre and readability. Overall the story works. The characters read flat, perhaps because they are intended to be acted. I felt as though the characters didn't age realistically and did things not realistic to who they are. Overall, it was okay. If you are a fan, you probably need to read it just to maintain your sanity. Was it worth 14 dollars, probably not, but I couldn't not read it. I had many of the same issues with it that I had with the second half of book 7.  It was okay, but if you're really needing a fix, go back and reread the series. You can't go home again, and it's true.

author: Steven Lubliner
title: Harry Potter and the Missed Opportunities
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Reducto! Didn't work. The book is still too long for its substance.

If I knew any transfiguration spells (potions?), I would perform them. I would turn this into the screenplay that, with its short, choppy, plot churning scenes, it so obviously is. More likely, I would turn it into a novel, adding J.K. Rowling's rich description and, more importantly, invention, both of which are lacking here. Using my divination skills, I can foresee a good novel. I can foresee a good movie. I have a hard time foreseeing two satisfying nights of live theater.

That said, there is good stuff here. Good stuff about fathers and sons. Good stuff about unlikely friends. Good stuff about middle aged life. Good stuff about living out someone else's vision for you. Etc. However, with one notable exception--okay, maybe two, #keepthesecrets--none of these human dramas is really embellished by the magical adventures that ensue.

At the end of Deathly Hallows, we jumped ahead 19 years and were led to believe all was well. It's not giving anything away to say that a few more years pass and then it appears that all might not be well. Been there. At this point, I wonder--just like I still wonder how Christmas fits into the wizarding world--what wizard life looks like in the periods between the wars. Is it easy utopia, or does it lend itself to a portrait of suburban discontent and domestic madness as easily as '50s America--or modern America--does? That's the "what happened next" story I would rather have seen.

Finally, much has been made about the casting of a black actress to play Hermione. Ignoring for a moment that J.K. Rowling missed an opportunity for the saddest moment in literature by not having the muggle-born Hermione die in the Ministry of Magic--by then, Nazi central--in Deathly Hallows, the unobjectionable casting hardly matters. Hermione, like Ron and Ginny, are just thin sketches of the characters we knew for so long. Harry and Draco fare somewhat better.

I'm glad I read it. I guess I'll see the show if it comes my way. That kind of love, while it may repel a killing curse, shouldn't blind anyone to the problems with this story.

author: Jay
title: Not Up to expect ions

This might work better seeing it on stage or as a movie although I won't be running to buy tickets to the show if it ever makes it's way over the pond.
Let me just go back to re-reading book 1-7, I can keep doing that forever.

title: but I am honestly disappointed with this play as much as I hate to ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2016
content:
I have been a Harry Potter fan since they were first published, but I am honestly disappointed with this play as much as I hate to say it. The characters we all know and love are painfully nostalgic to see, but are also not as dynamic as they once were. Perhaps it's because I already had head full of ideas of how these characters grew up, or maybe because I am not the greatest fan of time travel themes, but I could not put my heart into this book.
The plot was tearfully predictable which is greatly uncharacteristic of J.K. Rowling and I felt like I was reading a fanfiction from a stranger.

author: AWeis
title: meh !
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content:
I was so excited to start this book, but also scared at the same time, being a Potter Head and growing up reading the original Harry Potter series. I couldn't help but wondering if it would meet my expectation or be a great disappointment.

Well it was an epic failure on all levles. It was pretty disheartening,  I mean the stroey line was so dry and just very predictable. I knew where it was headed very quicly. There was no mystery or pull to hold the reader other than you hoped it was going to get better but it never did.

Maybe I expected too much or over hyped it in my head. Non the less it was a fantastical diaster my personal feelings. I really felt like she going to over milk the Harry Potter franschies. It felt a little like she use the killing curse on the series at this point." Avada Kedavra"

Being a big Harry Potter fan and reading all the books as a kid this book kind of take away from the orignial and leaves you more angry than satisfied.

The plot wasn't very good and just left you annoyed. It was very boring and many holes in the story line with a lot of unanswered questions that didn't even needed to be asked. It really makes Harry look stupid in general and just annoys the readers to the end. I stress this  especially if you have read and love the series thus  far.

Its coming to a point where she needs to leave the character alone or shes going to just screw up the whole series if she continues down this road. It did have the potential for greatness tho. She just has to stay away from certain aspect of the old books. She also needs new material not the same old ones recycled. Maybe its just me and I am over judging.

This book was a big let down  in so many so ways plot wise. I really felt like I wasted my time on it, however if you are a fan you are going to most likely want to judge/ read it anyways. I fell like she preys on the fact that you will want to read it no matter what at this point. I recommend if you are going to read it at least borrow it from a friend or library before you commit. Just to form your own opinion.

I am happy I read it, but the whole story was predictable and a very sloppy story line. It wasn't that originally Harry Potter lure. It lasck the pull, mysteries ,fun, and adventure the original books had. It also feels like shes just rewrting the same books only changeing a few deatails.  I wouldn't recommend it but if you are a fan you have to read it for your selves like I said earlier.

It isn't a great disappointment ...read with caution Harry Potter Fans. Its a big let down but now you have a warning so many it wont be so bad.

My best review without givng aways the story line. No Spoilars !

author: amber Kyle
title: Not one of my favorite J.K. Rowling books
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2016
content: I am an absolute Harry Potter fan, but this book was just a bit disappointing.  The whole book was about time travel and sometimes they could travel in time and come close to destroying the world by altering future reality, but sometimes they could do things that should make a bigger difference, but just don't.  Also, it is hard to follow a book about time travel that uses the same or similar names for the second generation children as the adults from the first generation.  It is even more difficult to follow with the unusual play format.  I always found myself wondering if we were seeing the older Harry or the young Harry or Albus Dumbledore or Albus, Harry's son.  I just felt that the story was either poorly thought out or poorly executed.  It wasn't what I've grown to expect of Rowling's story and character development.

It was really disappointing. It was a great story but I really missed the  classic Potter feel of the books. Overall big let down.

author: Amazon Customer
title: A huge let down.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I'm a die hard Harry Potter fan and the fact that it was a play threw me way off. I didn't know that buying the book. I pushed that aside. I grew up going to every Harry Potter book opening as a child as well as the movies. I wasn't able to go to the crushed child's opening because of work. I picked the book up today and while reading I melted. This is not J.K. Rowling writing. This is a lot of someone else's. There is no excitement, no magic, no feeling. The only reason I have given this book 3 stars is because part four is J.K Rowling writing and you can feel it with every ounch of your body. Part four brings you back to the Harry Potter you grew up loving. I will say no true Harry Potter fan won't cry in part four because of the history behind it. We all have that moment when we wounder about potter and James death and what Harry would do and this bring you to that. I haven't cried like that since Severus killed Dumbledore. Part four makes the whole book. Sadly this can never be a movie with out there being more heart to it.

Either way it was a good story, nice to see the gang again and revisit previous situations from new perspectives.

I can't shake the feeling of this being a money-grab however as it wouldn't have taken too much effort to actually write a novel based on this story.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Advice to true Harry Potter fans like myself, don't go in with high expectations
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: Advice to true Harry Potter fans like myself, don't go in with high expectations. It is much different than the original series. It is obvious Rowling did not write a lot of it. Remember, it was written as a play first, so it is probably a much better play than book (just like the original series are better books than movies). Because it's written for a play, it moves very quickly from scene to scene. As others have noted, the characters are much different. I tried to keep in mind that they are 20 years older so obviously people change and evolve. But a few of the main ones did seem too different from themselves. The first half of the book is pretty bad and it's hard to get used to the new characters and the old characters with their new personalities. But, the end of the book is much better. The moral behind the story follows was Rowling portrayed with the original 7 books. It's still worth the quick read. But just don't expect it to be just like the others, because it's not and I don't think it was supposed to be.

author: Carol
title: J.K. Rowling

content: So, uh. When you click buy just know you'll be actually BUYING the Kindle version of the book IMMEDIATELY. When I say immediately I mean the moment you click buy, it's bought, and there are no refunds. Don't make the same mistake I did! I wish they had put it in all caps that it was a KINDLE version. And possibly at the front of the title, too.

author: Lizzie
title: It's alright.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content:
It's good in that I missed seeing these characters and being in the Wizarding World, but know that what you're reading is going to be vastly different from the writing you're used to. First and foremost, it's the script. A lot of the action, scenery, and setting that are so vitally embedded in Rowling's work are left for you to conjure up for yourself--the stage notes aren't entirely helpful. Furthermore, to be quite honest, it reads more like fan-fiction than a true continuation of the rest of the series. I did expect more, particularly with the understanding that Rowling was part of the writing process. Some of the plot points didn't seem to fit quite right, others seemed very far-fetched even within a world based in magical happenings. More still seemed to be out of character with the characters we know and love, even considering the fact that this is set many years after the series proper concluded.

I enjoyed reading it; it was fun to go through and I'm sure that seeing the play brings the story to its audience in a better way than simply reading the script. If you choose to get and read this, go forward with the understanding that it will be a different experience than the books.

author: Sara Krzykowski
title: As a stand-alone story, 5 stars. As a Potter book, 2 stars.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content:
I have been reading (and re-reading) the Harry Potter series for roughly 16 years now, ever since I was eleven. I grew up with the books when they were released, and went to midnight release of Deathly Hallows when I was 18. I feel like I went to Hogwarts and grew up with Harry, Ron and Hermione. These characters are very real to me and very dear to my heart. When I first heard about the Cursed Child back in maybe January or February, I was very wary of it, especially when I found out it was going to be written as a script. As the release grew closer, I got a little more excited about it and decided to preorder it. I knew it would be nowhere near as good as the core series, but I wanted to see what it was all about anyways. When it downloaded onto my Kindle on July 31st, I read it straight through in about 3.5 hours. I couldn't put it down. I found it to be exciting, thrilling, and emotional; I admit I teared up quite a few times. After the initial emotions subsided, I felt a bit empty inside. The easiest way to sum up my overall feelings about the Cursed Chld would be this: it is an excellent stand-alone story and will be undoubtedly great on stage. But, as a Harry Potter story, it's not fantastic by any means, and just does not feel the same, for reasons that have nothing to do with it being a script.

What I Liked:
-Albus being sorted into Slytherin and becoming best friends with Scorpius Malfoy
-Seeing the gang all grown up, and the different struggles that they face as adults, which I could relate to very well
-I thought the time travel and the different outcomes were fun, even if it was not very believable.

What I'm Neutral About
-Voldemort having a child. There's no way it would ever happen or even be possible, but I still thought it was a cool idea to explore.

What I Didn't Like
-The trio's professions. I know this seems minor. But, knowing these characters like I do, Hermione would NEVER accept the position as Minister for Magic. After everything Harry as been through, I find it highly unlikely that he would want to step foot in the Ministry ever again, much less work there. Ron running Weasley's Wizard Wheezes with George is better, but I still don't really agree with it or think it would actually happen.
-There were some inconsistencies when retelling past events, such as the maze in the third task. In the Cursed Child script, the maze is a 'living' maze like in the Goblet of Fire movie. In the Goblet of Fire book, the maze was not like that. It sometimes felt like they were spinning off of the movies instead of the books.
-I missed Hogwarts and wish we could have seen more of it. Besides the characters, the time spent at Hogwarts is my absolute favorite part of the books and I wish we could have seen more of Albus and Scorpius adventures within the castle and throughout their classes.
-What I was most disappointed about, however, is the lack of Rose, James, Victoire, Teddy, etc. I was really looking forward to getting to know the 3rd generation and I was a bit shocked that they weren't more involved.

There is more I could write, such as the dialog and the characters not always being true to themselves, but the above reasons were the hard hitters for me. It was definitely an entertaining story and I will read it again in the future sometime, but to me this is not the 'eighth' Harry Potter book, and something that I will never view as canon.

author: Caliguy
title: So far I love the story
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content: Huge Harry Potter fan here.  So far I love the story.  But with that said I do not care for how it is written as a script.  I definitely recommend reading it though if you are a true Harry Potter fan.

author: Jennifer Zamboni
title: Wish I could see the play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
Okay, so I went into this one with a bit of apprehension. I'd read reviews first with phrases like fan fiction & wish fulfillment. I also went into it knowing that it was a play, and not written by J.K. Rowling herself.

After I got used to the format. I quite enjoyed it. Scorpius is a new favorite for me, & I quite liked Draco. Harry, however, ticked me off a few times. Ron was a bit more like movie Ron, than book Ron (more bumbling).

The first part was quite a bit more intriguing than the second.

Also, the time turners function completely differently, than they did in Prisoner of Azkaban. The future is affected in the play, in major ways. In the books, nothing changes, what is always was. Big error, in my opinion.

I'd love to see the stage play, but alas, I am an American without the budget. I think they should film the stage play, so this story could be enjoyed by all, in it's intended form.

author: Bryan Paschke
title: Meh.  Maybe the play is better.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2016
content: It was nice to dive back into the HP universe, but I've honestly read better fan fiction.  Maybe I would think better of it if I actually saw the play.

author: Miriam N. Paschal
title: A STAGE PLAY?!?!?!?!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content:
I'm very disappointed that this was in stage play format. I know there was a big to-do in London about the stage play, but the format is a poor substitute for a novel, if you're reading. There were no details in the writing: the kind you found on every page and in every sentence of the original Potter books.

I didn't even get a true sense of the characters. And because the format was designed for a finite amount of time on the stage, some characters got short shrift, particularly Ron, who hardly appears at all.

It was a good story: a VERY good story. I just wish Rowling would have given it the broad narrative it deserved.

author: Linda G.  Price
title: Harry's child's story
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Would rather that it was a story to read instead of having to read it as a play, but enjoyed the further in time story.

author: Hducle
title: Pretty boring. Have not finished the book yet
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: Pretty boring.  Have not finished the book yet.

author: ModernThirst
title: Reads a bit more like hopeful fanfic than Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
While then overall story is a bit of a let down, it's nice to revisit the harry potter world again, if even only a tertiary drop-in.  Still, the need to rely too heavily on scenes Rowling already vividly illustrated in her works feels far more like a literary or artistic crutch here than an homage.

For a last-ditch Harry Potter fix, it's fine, but this isn't really a continuation.  Canon, it may be, but don't put it on the same level as Rowling's direct works.

author: dust128

author: Zombie_Gunslinger
title: 18 Years Later...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
3.5 stars...but let me explain...

Like most fans of Harry Potter, the idea and possibilities of an 8th entry into the series was always something fun to ponder and discuss. Rowling leaving us with the image of Potter's kids going off to Hogwarts, following in their famous father's footsteps also helped fuel the speculation and fan theories. However, that was one of the most perfect endings in all forms of entertainment. Aside from Breaking Bad, I honestly don't think there was ever a more perfect conclusion to a series.

So when the announcement of The Cursed Child was made a while back, I, as I'm sure many other fans did, felt a sense of excitement, while, at the same time, that nagging worry that, as Hollywood has shown with horrible and unasked for sequels (here's looking at you Zoolander 2 and Dumb and Dumber To), The Cursed Child would be a huge let down.

Thankfully, I can safely say that The Cursed Child in and of itself was not as bad as I feared. The format is definitely odd (we will get to that in a moment), and it's pretty damn obvious that though this is Rowling's concept(s), it is not her voice on paper (also more on that later), the story and overall feel is Harry Potter through and through. The wonder of Hogwarts still exisits, the dark magic of Voldemort and his death eaters still permeates and gives the story the dark feelings of the later entries into the series, and Albus and Scorpious aren't necessarily as strong and Harry and his friends, but together they make a good team; ones you can't help but root for, even if Albus is a huge ass brat most of the time. It's also an incredibly fast and easy read (I read this in 2 days, while in the midst of one of the busiest and hectic weeks of 2016), which should come as no surprise since pretty much all of the Harry Potter books are that way.

I just wish that Rowling and everyone else involved would have chosen to go down the normal, safe path and publish this as a novel instead of the script format. I have no problem with the idea of doing the entire thing in a play production. In fact, I think that's actually a pretty cool idea, especially now at a time when things like Hamilton are all the rage. The problem, however, is that it completely fails when translated to the page. Maybe it's because I've never been a big fan of the stage, or had any interest in being an actor, but whatever the case, trying to read Harry Potter in strictly dialogue and stage direction wasn't what I would call easy. Unlike a novel that flows together in paragraphs and sentences, a page of speaking instructions and commands to actors is jarring and takes the reader out of the story. I'm not saying it doesn't work (go read Shakespeare's Star Wars to see what I mean), I just don't think it did here. Don't get me wrong, I think this would look absoleuylt beautiful on the stage in London, but it sure doesn't look beautiful when you're trying to read it.

And while it's true that Rowling's fingerprints are all over The Cursed Child, I don't think she was the one that did any of the actual writing. It was like she gave Jack Thorne and John Tiffany an outline and let them have at it. While the dialogue between characters is clever and realistic, the feel is gone. I don't know if that makes much sense, but when reading this, there never seemed to be any of Rowling's original touch. Not that I'm totally blaming her (she has the Cormoran Strike series to write, a movie to produce, and a personal life to live), but without her at the helm of the writing process, it shows.

I really wanted to give The Cursed Child 4 stars, and I very nearly did. The problem is that in all honesty I couldn't. Of course it was better than expected in the story part, and the twist at the end, had I not accidentally read about it before, was one of the better ones I can remember in recent memory, however that can't be overlooked by the disinteresting format and the absence of Rowling herself. Not that my review is gonna stop sales, however. The book is already a worldwide bestseller and on track to be England's fastest selling book of all time. Not to mention tickets for the play are coming in at upwards of 1,500 bucks. So in that regard, it's still a rousing success.

author: Drew
title: I medium'ed it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
First off, be careful which reviews you place your stock in.  So many people are giving it 1 star because they thought this was a book, not a script.  Lack of knowledge/awareness shouldnt be reflected in the scores.

That being said, this book isnt great.  It was enjoyable at times but there were way too many issues.

For one, there was no character development.  And I understand that this is hard to accomplish in a play format but its definitely possible.  As a huge Harry Potter fan, I just didnt feel a connection to any of the characters.  Few, if any, felt authentic to the Harry Potter universe that we know.  I thought they butchered Ron's character more than any.

The plot holes though are the main issue.  Not only was the plot rushed, but quite frankly at times it didnt make sense....even directly conflicting with things that we know(?) to be true from the original 7 books.  I won't go in to detail as I want to avoid spoilers but it was very clunky, awkward and forced.

In the end, I based this review on the way the book left me feeling. It definitely left something to be desired.  There is no questioning that.  Even with all of it's huge flaws it had its touching and funny moments and made me smile.  I will likely never read this book again but I also dont regret reading it.  It didnt take away from the previous 7 or ruin the legacy in any way. Give it a shot.  Pick up a copy, give it a read.  Don't listen to all of the negative reviews.  You're allowed to love it.  You're allowed to hate it.  And you're allowed to "medium" it like me.

author: Sam
title: I'm a huge Harry Potter fan and I feel like I"m being generous when I give this book 3 ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Ok, I'm a huge Harry Potter fan and I feel like I"m being generous when I give this book 3 stars. I was prepared to read this as a script and in an odd way, I actually enjoyed it that way because it left more to the imagination of the reader. I could interpret things better and give it a more magical feel that it deserved. Albus and Scorpius had a wonderful relationship and I was happy to see it.
But the book felt...recycled. The whole first chapter was just rehashing the epilogue from the Deathly Hallows and I felt like the characters were just echoing things that they said in previous books. The characters didn't come alive or feel fully developed.
This book really does feel more like a fanfic. But it was still an enjoyable read.

author: Arthur elias
title: Not for older Potter fans, but good beginners play.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
The play is just that, a play. Doubting that most Potter fans read plays often, this play might be something they dislike. The story telling is alright. The characters don't truly grow until the last few pages, and the direction is very very limited. This is not as immersive as the books in any way. The structure of each writer is fairly easy to pick out, and a lot of it feels bland.
All that being said the play was ok. It felt like a good introduction to higher level play reading, which is good for the younger generation of Harry Potter fans. If you're an older fan that grew up with the books/movies this might not be for you. There are a number of plot-holes as well as unanswered questions, and completely missing characters.

author: mandipaige
title: I tried, I really tried....
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: I wanted to love it. I really, really, really wanted to love it. But there were too many things that really bugged me. I will say, I did think the relationship with Harry and Albus was understandable: having to live up to your dad's reputation probably sucked. And Scorpius was definitely my favorite character, as well as how Draco was handled. I don't think anything about Ron in this book was like the Ron we've all read about since we were kids, and that was incredibly disappointing- since, you know, he's one of the core characters!- and hard to get past. Ron and Hermione's kids were hardly mentioned, as were two out of three of Harry's. One thing that really irked me was that Hagrid was not mentioned AT ALL as his present self, only in flashbacks to Harry as a baby and getting him from the Dursley's. Do they really think Hagrid was just not important anymore? Did he just leave Hogwarts? I wanted to see at least a little bit of Hagrid, as well as all the other Weasley's--how is George doing? And some things about the alternate reality just did not sound believable in terms of the characters. So it was nice to sort of revisit this world that I've loved so much over the years, but I was totally fine with putting this book down and back on the shelf when I finished it instead of that little pang in my heart when I finished the others.

author: A. Al-salem
title: Enjoyable, but had MAJOR issues with it. Review by a die-hard fan.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Let me start by saying Harry Potter is basically my life. I was 11 years old when the first movie came out (Just as old as Harry in the movie,
coincidentally). I have re-read each book atleast 5-6 times, in addition to almost memorizing the movies line for line. Harry Potter is a part of my life and soul, has been and forever will be. Now, on to the review:

!!! Spoiler Alert !!! You have been warned !!!!!

The story has one huge major issue: Time-Turners.
Over and over, it has been established in the Harry Potter verse that Time-Turners can't take you way back in time. A solid concrete rule right?? Don't believe me? This is from JK Rowling on Pottermore.com about Time-Turners: "The longest period that may be relived without the possibility of serious harm to the traveller or to time itself is around five hours. All attempts to travel back further than a few hours have resulted in catastrophic harm to the witch or wizard involved." See, told you, a CONCRETE rule.

WRONG. Suddenly out of nowhere, a death eater was able to "make" a Time-Turner that goes back years. WHAT?????? Do you understand what the ramifications of this are ??? Yet, in the Cursed Child, they use the Time-Turner constantly, going back and forth in time with no consequence :O This made struggle so hard with the credibility of the story and it quite honestly felt like (poor) fan fiction :O Which it is, to a degree, since the script was penned by Jack Thorne, not Rowling herself. I really question how much Jo was actually involved in the story and cant for the life of me understand why she approved it. The whole plot revolves around the (broken) Time-Turner plot device. I could go on and on about the inconsistencies with regards to the time travel in the Cursed Child, but I digress (for more: check out Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, which set the rules for time travel).

  Second, and this is a BIG one: Voldemort had a daughter with Bellatrix Lestrange. WHATTT?????????
It says in the book that she was born in Malfoy Manor just before the Battle of Hogwarts. Did every death eater/ Malfoy living at Malfoy Manor not know this??? Really? No one cared to mention that they saw/noticed/heard that Bellatrix Lestrange was pregnant/gave birth ? REALLY??? And who took care of her all these years (shes twenty-something in Present day) and taught her magic ?? It felt like a huge hole that didnt make any sense at all.

 Third issue I had, the dialogue sometimes felt a bit off-character for our beloved trio (especially Ron which became like a copy of Fred and George) and the characters sometimes saying cheesy things which felt REALLY odd. It really exemplified the fact that script was not written by our beloved Jo Rowling.

Fourth, dragging Cedric Diggory through the mud and saying he can turn into a death eater because of humiliation at the Triwizard tournament (This one made me laugh and gave me a good chuckle actually). Sigh. Not even going to explain this one.

So you see, even though I mildly enjoyed this entry into the Potter series, I did have some problems with the narrative, which I'm not used to with the past HP books. But hey, at least its an update on our favourite Trio and where they are in life and the occasional humor. Am grateful for that, at least.

Thank You for reading.
6/10

author: L. Retzlaff
title: A Bit of a Disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I have been a Potterhead for years and have been looking forward to this publication for some time. Jo Rowling has been pestered by fans for years to continue Harry's story and let us know how their lives continued after Deathly Hallows ended, and this book does give us that much.  While this story may make a spectacular play, the book is a bit of a disappointment. It was nice to visit old friends, but their characters are mere shadows of everything that made the original series a blockbuster.  Rowling has said that the actual performance is much more fleshed out than the script; but sadly, many of us will probably never have the opportunity or means to see it. Although I felt this book was lacking, I am stop glad that I read it, although $14.95 (or more for the print version) is a bit steep for what you get. I think Scholastic is taking advantage of HP fans and their wallets.

author: KDodge
title: Meh
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2016
content: I was initially disheartened by the lack of "flushing out" that comes with script writing.  The essence of the scenes are reduced to minor commentary that may or may not make sense.  It's simple.  More like reading a cliff notes version of a good book, except this book is just ok.  Harry hasn't grown at all, the most interesting character is Draco and he has a rather blandly normal aging arc.  Everyone else is fairly flat or boring.  The plot is fair, but the only twist being a witch we never learn much of anything about leaves me wanting.  This is my least favorite Harry Potter installment by far- the movie will likely be better than the book.

content: Disappointing, short, not 'believable' enough (the characters' reactions, not the plot)... Sorry, I'm a spoilt reader and, thus, was expecting so much more ;)

author: Linda A Gross
title: New format makes a difference to reading enjoyment.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
Clever twist at the end. Difficult to keep suspense reading it as a play. I'm sure it
works much better visually. Good to revisit Harry Potter world.

author: Janelle
title: just disappointed at the lack of content
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2016
content: Not the same as the other Harry Potter books, interesting take, just disappointed at the lack of content.

author: Amazon Customer
title: oh no
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: This was a disappointment to myself and friends as the plot did not capture the "essence" of Harry Potter. The storyline  seemed overemotional to say the least and I feel like I have to reread the series agin so that I can appreciate Harry Potter  again. Nothing in this story truly followed the  Harry Potter style of well placed action/drama/moral etc. leaving the story filled with holes. Because nothing in this  story was  in an consecutive manner meaning that the action was poorly placed and overall thius has just made  me sad. Very sad. I still love the author  and the original works but....

author: William A. Ronke
title: Probably better on the stage
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Cursed Child is an entertaining story, though the pace of reading a script doesn't exactly resemble reading a novel. All the magic of JKR's wizard universe is a little harder to find here, since nearly everything is dialogue. I imagine the stagecraft would make up for it.
The plot contains some surprises, but if you can excuse somewhat of a spoiler, a significant portion just feels like Back to the Future II. The handling of time travel in the play is not as tight as what we saw in Prisoner of Azkaban, and it occasionally felt like a retread of Harry's Greatest Hits.
I like that the primary characters, Albus and Scorpius, weren't just younger copies of their parents. I think the exploration of parenting and living up to parental expectations could be quite moving with the right cast.
Overall, it's nice to be back reading Potter again. Reading Cursed Child was like attending my High School reunion. It's great to catch up with these old friends, but we're all going to be relieved when it's time to go home.

author: Sam
title: but this book is not as good as old ones
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content: I don't know if I'm too old now, but this book is not as good as old ones. Main idea of the book is very beat up, we saw bunch of movies with the same plot. Was kinda disappointed, stopped reading in the middle of it

author: Ashley Grimm
title: It is in fact a playwright (which never occurred to ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2017
content: It is in fact a playwright (which never occurred to me until starting to read it). I feel that it had a similar writing style than all the Harry Potter books. My biggest complaint though was it had a lot of jumps into the story that created a feeling of fast forward. This may have been okay for a play but it definitely felt that it was lacking for a literature piece. I also felt the storyline had glimpses of greatness but was definitely not expounded upon as it is written for a theater performance. Overall entertaining and not hard to read once you got into it.

author: Jules
title: Easy read
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content: Despite it being a play write, it's an easy read. I'm not a fan of the story itself. It seems hastily put together, and not all thought out. I guess that's because of the use of time.

author: Jake
title: Not bad but makes you long for traditional form
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2016
content:
The play format is a downer. It makes it very hard to stay engaged and when the scenes have power,
it would be so much more powerful written in skillful prose.
The plot isn't bad. Not great but I like how it turns our feelings about the good and bad characters
inside out. If you are sold on Potter, you should enjoy revisiting the characters. Just don't expect
it to satisfy like a Rowling book.

author: C. Drakulic
title: Eh, so so, just okay...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: I can say that this book was just OKAY.  Not that it was horrible horrible, but it does not stand up to the expectations of past Harry Potter books.  It was a very easy, very quick read.  It just seemed that a lot of the vividness and descriptive nature of J.K. Rowling found in prior Harry P. books was missing.  I am interested to read her upcoming tales about Hogwarts.  This book as not turned me off to reading her work, but this was definitely somewhat of a disappointment in regards to prior books in the series.

author: Erin Bones
title: A hit or miss- But a must read for original HP fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: I did not dislike this book. However, it was a bit of a hit-and-miss for me. I will start off by saying I do miss the original novel composition of the Harry Potter books. I also felt that like other reviewers mentioned, this should have been written by J.K. Rowling and Rowling alone. Having two other writers contribute to this book tainted it in a way that you didn't feel as much of the magic as you did when you read the original 7 Harry Potter books. I could easily feel which parts of this script Rowling had most likely written and which parts she did not. When I found myself most absorbed and familiar with the characters and surroundings, I could sense J.K. Rowling's involvement. Other parts of the book, the characters didn't quite sound like the one's we all had come to originally know and love in this novel's predecessors. Like the majority of readers, I grew up with the books as well as with the films. So, I could not not read this book, nor could I put it down once I started reading it. What I did enjoy about this book most was where Severus Snape was involved. He has been my ultimate favorite since "always." Not only that, but I loved that I could feel and imagine very clearly the Snape as was portrayed by the late Alan Rickman in the films. I could hear his dry sarcasm so perfectly. The only thing that was odd to imagine was Snape calling Ron and Hermione by their first names. As for Delphi (WARNING: SPOILER), it was very predictable that her mother was only non other than Bellatrix Lestrange. I knew it from the moment I found out Voldemort reproduced. So overall, while I enjoyed some portions of this version of Harry Potter, I found other parts to be predictable and not all quite original (thanks to those other two contributing writers). I give it 3 out of 5 stars because I did enjoy it. It wasn't my favorite HP book, but if you are a true Harry Potter fan, it's impossible to give it complete thumbs down review, only because well, it is Harry Potter.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Three Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content: Felt more like weird fan fiction

author: Kindle Customer
title: I'm really trying not to be disappointed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: I had really mixed feelings about this book/play. I've tried to keep in mind this is a play. if you are hoping for the magical world of harry potter it definitely falls short. Also I felt this book/play lacked a complexity of characters. This book/play was really about 1 person and tells very little of other the other. Overall it was okay, I'm really trying not to be disappointed.

content: I really wanted to love this. I knew it was not a BOOK but a PLAY script. The story, however, was very predictable... I wish it were longer, and Delphi was ry underdeveloped. But, I loved seeing the future of Harry and the gang.

author: Christine Blue

author: M.R. Whitman~Oklahoma

content: Hard to appreciate after the depth and detail of the novels.  I would have preferred this as a novella, by really,the story just wasn't great.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Yes and no...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content: I am a huge Harry Potter fan. I can't remember how many times I've read the books - I basically know the books and movies by heart. But after reading all the critics I was dreading reading it, I didn't even buy at first. But then I changed my mind, and I'm happy I did. If you decide to buy it, just don't start reading thinking this is another Harry Potter book. It's not. It doesn't really feel entirely like Harry Potter. That said, it's a short read and a nice reminder of the story. My advice is read it, but don't expect it to be like the others.

author: Ms. Karle Warren
title: Still a fan of Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016

title: Should be more.

author: G. Scot Phillips
title: Good, but not Great
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content:
It was an okay read but not good, and certainly not spectacular. This was not Rowling's best work. I think if it had been an actual book instead of a script it might have helped. I know there is only so much you can convey during a live performance, but the story felt rushed. There was too much jumping around. I didn't really care for any the characters except for Scorpius, which is sad. I wanted to like them, but every single one of them seemed to have drank from the "I'm so self-obsessed I can't see things from anyone else's point of view." Scorpius was the only one  I really cared for. I liked him from the beginning. I am with others in feeling that this read more of wish fulfillment fan fiction.

If I could recommend one thing to Rowling and company, it would be to redo this book and give it the attention it deserves.
